TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 248th report of the Committee relating to the Report of the Auditor-General-April 1985, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for its courtesy. Following the tabling of the report of the Auditor General in April 1985-honourable members will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General-the Committee sought written submissions from 10 departments and five statutory authorities in respect of 22 items. Further information and clarification by way of supplementary submissions were sought from six departments and one statutory authority. Report 248 is a departure from the usual practice of the Committee. Due to an increasing work load the Committee decided that the Parliament's attention should be drawn to the salient features of the Auditor-General's report in future. Consequently the principal matters on which the Committee sought comment from departments and authorities were addressed but public hearings were not held on any of the matters raised on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: This report comments on the responses of the departments and authorities to criticisms raised by the Auditor-General. Conclusions drawn by the Committee reflect remedial action taken or proposed to be taken in addressing those items. In particular there were three matters that the Committee wished to bring to the attention of members of Parliament. The first was the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations wage pause program; the second, the Department of Territories administration of the Commissioner for Housing loans scheme and, third, the financial statements of the Australian National University. The Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982 provided for the expenditure of up to $200m through a wage pause program of public sector job creation. The money partly represented expected savings from the 12 months suspension of salary increases for Commonwealth employees under the salaries and wages pause legislation. Under the established guidelines the States were required to submit employment projects to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and if considered suitable details were forwarded to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for approval. Projects which were to receive consideration for approval were required to be labour intensive and to promote greater equality of opportunity particularly for the long term unemployed.

The audit review of the scheme sought to establish whether the procedures introduced to administer the program within the area of Commonwealth responsibilities were consistent with the aims and objectives. The Committee was disturbed by the administrative difficulties which developed following hasty implementation of the wage pause program, and in particular from the inadequacy of interdepartmental co-ordination. In view of this concern and the fact that this program ceased in mid-1984, the Committee sought supplementary submissions from both the Employment and Industrial Relations Department and the Finance Department with respect to another similar employment program. The House will be familiar with that program, the community employment program.

While this program is not subject to audit, the Committee considered it important to assess the administrative arrangement governing it. From the respective departmental submissions, it is clear that the administrative and financial arrangements for the community employment program differ quite markedly from those which applied to the wage pause program. The Minister for Finance has limited executive responsibilities and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations clearly has carriage of the legislation and program administration. Clearer working guidelines and funding through annual appropriations have, to a large degree, clarified the obligations and responsibilities of the agencies concerned.

The second matter was the housing loans scheme operational in the Australian Capital Territory. Under the Housing Ordinance 1982 the Commissioner for Housing in May, subject to the control of the Minister for Territories, administers schemes for providing or assisting in providing dwellings in the Australian Capital Territory. On 10 September 1984 the Minister for Finance, pursuant to concern expressed by Cabinet about the management of funds in the scheme, requested the Auditor-General to perform an audit of the recent operations of the scheme in the light of recent over-commitment of funds. Audit findings were that, first, the housing trust account was overexpended from 4 July 1984 to 18 July 1984 in breach of section 34 of the Audit Act, secondly, that there were deficiencies in the administration for controlling equipment; and, thirdly, that the estimated shortfall of $7.9m in funds was an unreliable estimate. The Committee was informed that the Department has now instituted amended procedures and practices in order to eliminate any future problems with over-commitment of funds. Further, the Department has implemented a range of measures to improve the financial and administrative procedures and staffing arrangements of the Housing Branch. These amended procedures and arrangements implement many of the recommendations of a joint review of the scheme by the Public Service Board and the Department of Territories, conducted during September 1984, and of the Fisher Review conducted during the first half of 1985.

The Steering Committee for Housing Loans is continuing to meet on a regular basis to implement the longer term recommendations of the joint review report and will continue to do so until all recommendations are satisfactorily implemented. The Committee notes that Audits comments on these amended schemes and procedures should eliminate future problems. However, I want to emphasise, as I particularly have this view, that the Committee will continue to monitor the Department's operation of the scheme and may subject it to further review in the light of future comments and the Committee's own consideration of more detailed information to be made available to it by the Department.

The Auditor-General also reported on an inspection of the accounts and records of financial transactions of the Australian National University for the year ended 31 December 1983. Among other things audit noted serious deficiencies existed in supporting documentation for the university's 1983 draft financial statements, both in their original form and in the revised draft submitted some months later. Audit was concerned that in some respects the university's accounting practices were at variance with those prescribed in the guidelines on the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings issued by the Minister for Finance in May 1983. The Committee notes that the University has significantly reformed its financial administration and that this reform process is continuing. The Committee anticipates continued improvement in the University's financial administration, particularly with reference to its financial statements. The Auditor-General now reports twice each year on audits undertaken. In addition separate reports are made throughout the year on efficiency audits performed by the Auditor-General, and annual reports on the financial statements and his activities.

During the currency of the examination of the Auditor-General's report of April 1985 the Auditor-General presented an annual report for 1984-85 on his operations. This was the first time the Auditor-General had reported in this manner. The report referred to, amongst other things, a number of issues concerning the role and proper function of the Auditor-General, particularly his relationship with the Executive. The Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts looks forward to discussions with the Auditor-General on these matters. I commend this report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report which has just been tabled by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) is a most important report because the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts is a watch-dog of the Parliament and a watchdog of the public purse. As a member of parliament who is not a member of that Committee I want to make a brief comment in relation to one aspect of the report, and that is the first part of the three investigations referred to by the honourable member for Dundas relating to the manner in which $200m had been dispersed. Those funds came about as a result of the wage pause legislation of 1982 which, it should be remembered, was brought into this Parliament by the Fraser Government. It is important to note that it was as a result of that legislation that some $200m became available to this Government, the Hawke socialist Government, which was then supposed to do something about getting young people into the work force. I see that honourable members on the Government benches are finding some amusement in this. I do not think that $200m being put aside to help young people into employment, particularly those who have been unemployed for lengthy periods, as the honourable member for Dundas pointed out, is a laughing matter. I think it is a very sad thing that the report has revealed--
—You are a joke.

—It is all right for you, grave robber, to turn this debate-about which I am trying to make just a short comment-on your Government's failure to deliver $200m worth of efficient employment opportunities to the young people of Australia into a laughing matter. The young people have had the Government. It promised that it would get them jobs but in fact the level of youth unemployment today is higher than it was when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister. It cannot be laughed off either by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) or anybody else when the report contains comments such as `hasty implementation', `inadequacy of preparation' and `non-compliance with guidelines'. This is not a laughing matter. We are talking about $200m provided as a result of a Fraser Government initiative which should have gone towards providing worth-while and permanent employment to young people in this country, and sadly it has not.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I draw to the attention of the House the membership of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts so it will be seen that this is not just the view of the Opposition but also that it is the view of a committee which is broadly based, representing both Houses in this Parliament and both sides of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —All factions of the Labor Party.

—All factions of the Labor Party; the left wing, the right wing, the centre, the old guard, the new guard, the mudguard. They are all represented. The Liberal Party and National Party of Australia also are represented. We have representation also from both sides of the Senate. I would like to take this discussion further but I shall not abuse the indulgence that the House has granted. I simply say this: When this Committee reports to the Parliament that $200m of taxpayers' money, which was deliberately set aside to provide work for the young people of this country, has not been used to the best advantage, sadly this is yet another example of the utter financial incompetence, negligence and recklessness of the Hawke socialist Government, which is now on its last legs and, by divine providence, will be out of office at the next election.
—Order! I understand it would suit the convenience of the House for the sitting to be suspended until 8 p.m. If there is no objection, the chair will be resumed at 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General transmitting particulars of proposed expenditure and recommending appropriation announced.
Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
In doing so, I present the Budget for 1986-87.
Over the past year the factors which determine Australia's national prosperity have changed dramatically.
The strong economic growth and the huge employment growth of the last three years have now been slowed due to the sudden collapse of our export earnings.
The prospects for our future growth, built on the expectation that we could readily sell our traditional products, have been substantially diminished.
Many Australians have wondered why the economy was doing so well in 1985 and yet, apparently, doing so poorly in 1986.
The answer lies in the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices since late last year.
We have been placed in a position where we are failing to cover the cost of our imports to the tune of more than a billion dollars a month-and inevitably our growth had to slow.
With the world having slashed our national income by over $6 billion we could not continue on as though nothing had happened.
To try would see the world force destructive adjustment on Australia making it hostage to the international financial community.
And that is not a position acceptable to this Government.
We believe that Australia must maintain control over its own destiny and this can only be done by facing the problem squarely and making the remedial changes quickly and decisively.
This the Government will do through this Budget and other policy changes.
It is imperative that our domestic economy and our standard of living adjust to our changed trading circumstances so that we can make an early return to higher growth and stronger employment.
What precisely are the adjustments required?
As a nation, if we are to become more independent and self-sufficient, we need to invest more and consume less.
In other words, we must save for the future rather than spend for the present.
The Government can help this process directly by spending less and borrowing less, thereby improving the climate for lower interest rates and for private sector investment.
The savings and tax decisions in this Budget are also designed to restrain the growth of private consumption.
But the Budget alone cannot achieve all of the changes Australia requires.
It is also essential that Australians exercise restraint over wages and prices.
We simply cannot allow the inevitable inflationary effects of the dollar's fall to feed into our cost structure.
Contrary to the beliefs of some, Australia is well equipped to make the adjustments to rectify its problems.
We have made enormous progress in the past 3 years in modernising and freeing up the economy.
We have a much lower wage cost structure, a vibrant financial sector, and vastly more competitive industries than a few years ago.
While we have now encountered serious difficulties in our primary export markets, through our combined efforts and continued restraint we can turn those efforts towards new opportunities.
For these reasons, the Budget incorporates a very large cut in spending and a very large cut in Government borrowing.
In making these vital decisions we have sought to ensure that the burden of change is spread as fairly as possible across the community.
Even in difficulty, however, we have maintained the Labor Party's traditional commitment to the most needy.
But we have not shirked our responsibility to take hard decisions where these have been required.
Reflecting this, the Government has been able to bring the deficit down from $5,726 million last year to $3,503 million this year.
I repeat, this Budget cuts the deficit by $2,223 million to $3,503 million.

It is also important to understand that while in total the Commonwealth has budgeted for a deficit of $3.5 billion, much of this deficit arises from spending abroad on defence equipment and other items.
Allowing for these overseas transactions there will be an estimated domestic budget surplus of $805 million.
Combined with reductions in State borrowings, the large cut in the Budget deficit will dramatically lower government demand for borrowed funds.
In fact, total public sector borrowings will be cut by more than $2 1/2 billion in 1986-87.
The Government's bond selling program has been cut from $5.7 billion last year to around $3 billion this year.
As a result, the net bond selling task will be zero.
I would point out that the large reduction in the deficit this year has been made notwithstanding economic developments tending to increase it.
Wage restraint tends to lower taxes more than outlays in the short term.
As I shall discuss later, the Budget figuring incorporates a 2 per cent discount to wages in the next National Wage Case.
Without that assumption, the deficit would have been some $400 million less.
The Government's resolve and achievement in this Budget is well reflected in the fact that if we had taken no action on outlays or receipts the deficit would have been $7.5 billion.
We have brought it down by $4 billion, or more than half.
THE BUDGET MEASURES
Madam Speaker, the deficit reduction in this Budget has been accomplished by an examination of outlays of unprecedented rigour.
If we had done no more than provide for ongoing programs, outlays would have increased by 2.7 per cent in real terms.
We have cut this back to zero real growth.
To achieve this result, nearly $3 billion has been cut from existing programs.
Cutbacks have been made in most areas, with major reductions falling on social security, health, education, defence and overseas aid.
In social security, the Government has decided on cutbacks of over $500 million.
Included in those decisions, future six monthly indexation increases to beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full but will be deferred for six weeks.
This means that the 4 per cent increase due in early November will now be paid in mid-December.
In addition, the measures announced last year to relax income testing arrangements for pensions and benefits will be delayed 8 months until July 1987.
These are the only changes to the general pension and benefits area.

While seeking a contribution from this part of the Budget towards the resolution of our national problems, the Government has ensured that there will be no reductions in any existing pension or benefit payments.
What is being required is a minimal sacrifice when compared with that being asked of wage and salary earners.
There will be a crackdown on cheating and fraud in the social security system.
We will not compromise our deep commitment to assist the genuinely needy.
But abuse of the system will not be tolerated.
Special reviews will be conducted by teams of officers to identify and disqualify those wrongfully receiving unemployment benefits.

Additionally, reporting requirements for all unemployment beneficiaries will be tightened and it will be much harder for New Zealand citizens who are visiting Australia to qualify for unemployment and other benefits.
There will also be reviews of sole parent beneficiaries to verify continuing eligibility.
The Government is committed to implementing the Australia Card with a photograph, which will also assist in combatting social security fraud.
Child maintenance arrangements are being reformed so that non-custodial parents will shoulder more financial responsibility for their children, rather than throwing the burden onto the taxpayer.

In line with the Government's aim to target welfare assistance to the most needy, the family allowance for student children aged 16 and 17 will be income tested so that families with household income exceeding $39,000 will no longer receive it.
In the same vein, the Government will in this Budget provide further assistance to the most needy, low income families with children and to the handicapped.
These discretionary adjustments are detailed in the Budget Papers.
The Government has taken a range of measures to help contain the growing cost of Australia's health system.
Spending in this area will be cut by $300 million.
First, strict measures have been adopted to reduce what were clearly excessive pathology charges by some medical practitioners.
Second, the wage restraint asked of the workforce at large has been extended to medical practitioners by deferring increases in schedule fees until 1 November 1986.
Third, the maximum patient contribution for medical services-I stress the maximum, not the typical-is to be raised from $10 to $20 from 1 November.
Fourth, the bed day subsidy to private hospitals will cease from 1 October 1986, but some charitable hospitals will continue to receive assistance.
But even with these savings, and particularly with the recent increases in salaries for nurses, the cost of the health system is continuing to rise.
The Government therefore believes that the Medicare levy should be increased so that it makes a greater contribution to health costs and so that Medicare is self-financing.
Accordingly, the Medicare levy will rise by a quarter of a per cent to 1.25 per cent from 1 December.
Increasing the levy is a more equitable means of responding to unavoidable increases in health costs than the alternative of severely curtailing Medicare benefits.
Pharmaceutical benefits have been another area of burgeoning costs in the health system.
This has been a concern to both the Government and the very sick.
New arrangements will reduce costs to the health system and provide relief to those most in need.
From 1 November prescription drug users now paying a $5 contribution will pay up to a $10 maximum.
New safety net arrangements mean individuals and families requiring more than 25 prescriptions a year will receive prescriptions beyond that number free of charge.
Pensioners will continue to receive items on the Pharmaceutical Benefits list free of any charge.
The Government believes it is only fair that participants in the higher education system share some part of its costs.
Consequently a charge of $250 per year for all higher education students will be introduced in 1987 to offset administration costs.
This charge represents only a small part of the cost of providing higher education, and will contribute towards an additional student intake of 3000 in 1987.
Lower income families will be protected; holders of tertiary allowances and post-graduate awards and overseas students paying the overseas student charge will not be affected.
Spending on defence is to be held at 1 per cent real growth, saving $190 million, and overseas aid will be cut by $140 million from its forward estimate.
Expenditure on the new Parliament House is to be reduced by $30 million, sports facilities by $8 million and the Bicentennial Program by $25 million.
The number of Commonwealth public servants will be reduced by 2000 over the year to June 1987.
The Government has made numerous other expenditure cuts in reaching its $3 billion expenditure savings; details are set out in the Budget Papers.

Madam Speaker, the overwhelming concern of the Government in bringing down this Budget has been to achieve an outcome appropriate for a nation with a trading problem of the magnitude now facing Australia.
That is why spending has been held to zero real increase.
That is why we have sought to produce the lowest practicable budget deficit.
The Government has held outlays and the deficit well below the trilogy requirements.
Outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product have been reduced to 29.4 per cent, compared with 30.1 per cent last year and 30.4 per cent the year before.
The deficit has been reduced to only 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product, back to the average prevailing during the late 1950s and the 1960s.
It is the fourth consecutive fall from the 5 per cent in prospect that we inherited from the Coalition Government in 1983.
In pursuit of this objective and given the urgency of our predicament the Government has decided to lift the tax ratio about half a per cent above the 1984-85 level.
This decision has been taken to achieve an even larger reduction in the deficit, and to do so in an equitable way.
Our trilogy of fiscal commitments was directed at restraining the size of Government over the medium-term and we reaffirm that fundamental objective.
The Government has been spectacularly successful in lowering expenditure growth and the deficit.
Moreover, it is our objective to bring the tax ratio back to 25 per cent of gross domestic product next year.
This year, however, the first stage of the very substantial cuts in personal income tax provided by the tax reform program will be delayed three months.
These cuts-at the previously announced rates-will now apply from 1 December this year.
The second and final stage-reducing the top marginal tax rates to 49 cents and 40 cents-will apply from 1 July 1987 as scheduled.
Legislation implementing both stages is being introduced tonight.
These cuts-as well as improving incentive-will return to taxpayers about three times the revenue raised by the tax reform package.
Madam Speaker, the Government has adopted a number of other revenue measures.
In the main, the measures will restrain real household disposable incomes and consumption, consistent with the need for our living standards to be trimmed for a time.
Wholesale sales tax will be increased on a range of consumer products including luxury motor vehicles, wine, certain non-alcoholic beverages and swimming pools.
The sales tax law is also to be amended with effect from midnight tonight to curtail avoidance of taxes on computer software.
The excise on petrol and diesel fuel will increase by 3 cents per litre from tonight.
Because of the existing diesel rebate arrangements, this additional excise will not fall upon farmers and miners.
The rates of the Bank Account Debits Tax will be increased by up to a half from 1 December 1986.
The tax deferral advantages enjoyed by some companies with substituted accounting periods will be phased out over three years.
PRICES AND INCOMES POLICY
Madam Speaker, the Budget I have outlined tonight will greatly assist Australia to adapt to the new international trading circumstances we face.
However, budget policy must be supported by continued price and wage moderation.
The restructuring of Australian industry facilitated by the depreciation of the dollar will accelerate provided we stay competitive with the rest of the world.
Staying competitive means having a greater ability to supply our own market with Australian-made goods and to win a larger share of world markets.
Over the past 3 years Australia's working men and women have shown commendable income restraint.
More than any other single factor, their co-operation and good sense has been responsible for the creation of 630,000 jobs since April 1983.
Over this period real labour costs have fallen by more than 7 per cent.
It is not the fault of wage and salary earners that export prices have fallen.
Just as it is not their fault that the dollar has fallen, pushing up import prices.
But we cannot afford to let wages grow automatically in line with this price surge.

If adverse trading conditions and a depreciating Australian dollar are the cause of the Consumer Price Index rising, it follows that to allow those increases to flow through automatically into wages would compound our problems.
We would be adjusting our wages upwards not to compensate for the problem but to build the problem in.
This would only lead Australia into a price and wage spiral.
I am certain that all Australians will understand and accept that we cannot have our national income slashed by over $6 billion and at the same time seek to fully maintain our wages in real terms.

Accordingly, at the next National Wage Case when the combined 4.0 per cent movement in the March and June quarter Consumer Price Index will be considered, the Government will argue to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent.
This means that wages will rise by 2 per cent less than the increase which would fully compensate for inflation.
There are good and clear reasons for this.
Last year award wages grew by 4 1/2 per cent.
With a 2 per cent discount, wages are expected to grow at about the same moderate rates as in 1985-86.
This means that over the course of the next year Australian wage increases will be broadly comparable with our major trading partners.
A 2 per cent discount would therefore maintain our competitiveness and preserve our ability to compete on favourable terms with the rest of the world.
The Government will also seek a further adjustment of the wage increase in the case commencing around April next year if economic conditions applying at the time warrant it.
In determining its attitude to that case, the Government's main focus will continue to be on Australia's ongoing competitive position and our terms of trade performance.
With its past record of success, the Government reaffirms its confidence in the Prices and Incomes Accord.
The Accord framework will continue to deliver more economically and industrially responsible outcomes than any other real world alternative.
The challenges now presented by severely depressed commodity prices demand a continuation of this approach.
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK
Madam Speaker, it will take some time for the ground lost in our export markets to be recovered, and a stronger growth path to be resumed.
As a result, we expect growth in the non-farm economy to be around 2 1/2 per cent in 1986-87 compared with 4 per cent last financial year.
Most of that growth will stem from our improved international competitiveness; it will show up in the winning of new export markets and the replacement of imports with locally produced goods.
However, the lower growth rate means that fewer jobs will be created over the next year than in the last twelve months.
Employment growth is expected to slow to between 1 1/2 and 2 per cent, and as a consequence, unemployment could rise a little.

Just as it will take some time for the benefits of the depreciation of the dollar to flow through the economy, it will also take some time before the adverse price effects of the depreciation are behind us.
Consequently, reflecting the recent falls in the dollar, we expect the Consumer Price Index to increase by around 8 per cent on average in 1986-87.
However, the trend in the latter part of the year and beyond will be downward.
Madam Speaker, the Budget I am presenting tonight responds decisively to the new international challenge facing Australia.
It constitutes one of the basic and fundamental responses required to permanently improve Australia's trading performance.
It makes the major shift down in Government spending and borrowing that will permit the new investment opportunities to be seized:
- real spending growth has been cut to zero;
- the deficit has been dramatically brought back to its late 1950s and 60s levels;
and
- Government calls on the nation's savings have been substantially alleviated.
This Budget provides Australia with the opportunity to surmount its economic problems and maintain control over its economic destiny.
It demonstrates the Government's absolute determination to do what has to be done to safeguard Australia's economic future.
It demonstrates once again that, by resolute action and by some sacrifice all round, there is no problem that we cannot face and defeat together.
OUTLAYS
Madam Speaker, I now provide more details of the expenditure cuts that have been made.
Budget outlays in 1986-87 are estimated to total $74,764 million.
As I stated earlier, this represents zero growth in real terms.
In the previous thirty years lower real rates of growth have been achieved on only three occasions.
This outcome reflects the determined approach which the Government has adopted to expenditure control.
Details of individual decisions are contained in the Measures section of Statement No 3; additional information will be provided, as appropriate, by the relevant Ministers.
The Prime Minister will also be making a detailed statement on Public Service staffing matters in the next few weeks.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND WELFARE
I have already outlined our major initiatives in this area.
I stress once again: The Government has a commendable record of directing assistance to those in greatest need.
Over the term of the Hawke Government there have been significant increases in the real value of pensions and benefits, and large gains in assistance provided for children in low income families.
This Budget continues the Government's focus on improving benefits for those in need, on removing anomalies and attacking fraud.
In addition to the measures I have already announced, action is to be taken to prevent some people qualifying for dual benefits.

From 1 November 1986, where a newly eligible war or defence widow pensioner is also eligible for a social security pension, the maximum level of the social security pension will be frozen at $60.05 a week.
I mentioned earlier that some benefits to the most needy in the community were to be increased.

To assist pensioners and low income families with children, there will be a $1 a week increase in the additional pension and benefit per child and a $1 a week increase in the rate of the Family Income Supplement from November 1986.

In recognition of the difficulties and additional costs facing disabled people who undertake employment or vocational training, the mobility allowance will increase to $11 a week from November this year.
The handicapped child's allowance will increase by $7 per month to $92 per month from November 1986.
And also from November, the orphan's pension will increase by $4.30 to $60 per month.
A clear need has been established for the Government to provide additional income support for 16 and 17 year olds who are the victims of abuse within their own families or cannot live at home.
Consequently, a Young Homeless Allowance of $23.28 a week has been introduced to supplement the income these young people receive from education allowances or unemployment benefits.
Expenditure in 1986-87 for that purpose is estimated to be about $9 million.
HEALTH
When dealing earlier with the Government's major proposals in the health portfolio, I stressed that we were adamant that health funding must be kept within reasonable bounds.

Consequently, in addition to those other measures, we will investigate the payment of medical benefits which are growing at above average rates and review mechanisms for further restraining growth in health costs.
The Isolated Patient Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme will be transferred to the States.
Extra funding of $11 million this year and $22 million in a full year will be provided to the States and Territories to enable them to provide more effective arrangements.
Funding has been increased in a number of important areas in the health portfolio.
These include health promotion, public health, hepatitis B vaccinations, medical research, family planning and assistance to diabetics.
EDUCATION
I have already mentioned the Government's intention to impose an administration charge on higher education students.
In addition, the overseas student charge currently applicable to university and CAE students will be extended to secondary, TAFE and other previously exempt higher education students from overseas.
Together with increases in existing charges, this extension will yield $7.3 million, offsetting the costs of providing education to overseas students in Australia.
An anomaly exists in current arrangements whereby some social security beneficiaries can receive both student allowances and pensions or benefits.
This is to be removed for new entrants from the 1987 academic year, saving $4 million.
A special payment of $15 per week will instead be made to invalid and sole parent pensioners who are also students to encourage their education and later employment prospects.
LABOUR AND EMPLOYMENT
There has been a significant re-ordering of priorities within this function and, overall, a real cut in spending.

Flowing from last year's decision to implement the Priority One program, expenditure on job training programs will increase by $67 million, including an increased allocation of $33 million for the Australian Traineeship System.
This accords with the Government's intention that training and education opportunities available to our young people be significantly enhanced.
Increased emphasis on training is to be complemented by reduced emphasis on Government job creation schemes.
Consequently, outlays under the Community Employment Program will be reduced by $90 million to $200 million.
The 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages is to be extended to former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel receiving Government superannuation benefits.
ABORIGINALS

Assistance to Aboriginals will undergo a significant change in emphasis following the Government's endorsement of the general principles espoused in the Miller Report on Aboriginal Employment Training.
The emphasis of existing programs will be changed from short-term job creation and welfare measures towards policies to establish long-term employment opportunities.
Commonwealth expenditure directed towards Aboriginals will total $570 million in 1986-87.
DEFENCE
Real growth in defence spending has been cut to 1 per cent in 1986-87, a significant reduction on the 3.75 per cent allowed for in the Five Year Defence Program.
Nevertheless, average real growth in defence spending under this Government remains greater than that under our predecessors.
Recently the Government has begun the most thorough and comprehensive review of this country's defence priorities since the Second World War.

In light of the Dibb Report and prevailing economic circumstances, the Government will now prepare a White Paper on Defence which will set down the development of Australia's defence capabilities well into the future.
This report will reflect the need to maintain planning at achievable financial outcomes.
Such a disciplined approach will ensure that essential changes can take place in equipment and force structure.
CULTURE AND RECREATION
The Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are to be amalgamated, and their combined funding reduced by $16 million from last year's allocation.
The specialised charter of the SBS will be preserved under the amalgamation.
Gross savings from shared facilities, accommodation, equipment and administration in the amalgamated organisations should be about $2 million in 1986-87 and much greater in future years.
We are also reducing the cost of administrative assistance to the arts.
As a first step, the Australia Council's administrative expenses for 1986-87 are to be reduced by $1 million to allow increased support for the arts.
A wide-ranging review of the Commonwealth's funding of museums is to be undertaken.
The construction of the National Museum of Australia in Canberra will not proceed on the timetable previously conceived; its future will be considered following this review.
INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE
All production bounties other than those applying to fertilisers and shipbuilding are to be reduced by 20 per cent from tonight, saving $43 million.
There will be a phased reduction in the shipbuilding bounty rate from 25 per cent to 20 per cent.
The consumption subsidy for fertilisers will no longer apply to imported products and the savings will be reallocated to increase subsidy rates on locally manufactured phosphatic fertilisers.
The ban on uranium exports to France has failed to serve its original purpose and was in fact bestowing a benefit by allowing France to contract elsewhere for uranium at lower prices.

—Order!
—Madam Speaker, I must make the point that the sale of uranium to France is not the policy of the Labor Party.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will resume his seat.
—Madam Speaker, as the ban was exacting--

—I am sorry, but that is not the fault of the Treasurer; it is the fault of those on my left who are preventing the rest of the people of Australia from hearing the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced in May that it intended to recoup $40m in aviation expenditures by implementing a cost recovery plan.
These savings are now to be expanded to $49 million.
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION
The cost of fulfilling Freedom of Information requests is currently estimated at some $14m a year, compared with offsetting revenue of $60,000.
While the Government remains firmly committed to the principles of Freedom of Information, it believes that a greater proportion of the costs should be borne by users of this service.
Charges will be increased but free access will be maintained for inquiries relating to personal income maintenance documents.
NORTHERN TERRITORY ELECTRICITY COMMISSION

The Commonwealth remains committed to sharing the cost of constructing Darwin's new power station but has informed the NT Government that it will be halving, as of tonight, assistance with operating costs reflecting in the main the lower costs of its oil feedstock.
This will save $21 million this year.
CHARGE FOR LOAN GUARANTEES
Commonwealth business enterprises receive a significant interest rate benefit due to the fact that their borrowings are guaranteed by the Commonwealth Government.
From 1986-87 an annual charge will be applied to borrowings by the Commonwealth's business enterprises which are guaranteed by the Commonwealth.
This measure is expected to raise about $7 million in 1986-87.
RECEIPTS
Madam Speaker, I have already indicated the major revenue measures in the Budget.
I shall now give further details.
The measures are more extensively described in Statement No 4 of Budget Paper No 1.
MARGINAL INCOME TAX RATE CUTS
Madam Speaker, the fundamental cuts to marginal income tax rates that I announced as the centrepiece of the Government's Tax Reform Package will proceed.
The 60 cent rate will be cut to 49 cents, the 48 cent and 46 cent rates to 40 cents and the other marginal tax rates to 29 and 24 cents.
These massive income tax cuts will produce a fairer and more efficient tax system, under which all Australian taxpayers will be better off.

However, as I indicated earlier, the serious international economic predicament which Australia faces has required the deferral of the first stage of these tax cuts until 1 December this year, reducing the cost to revenue in 1986-87 from $2085 million to $1435 million.
Legislation to give effect to the lower rates of tax, including those to apply from 1 July 1987, will be introduced tonight.

These reductions are only possible because of the Government's moves to eliminate the inequities and abuses of our tax system which have persisted for so long and because of our demonstrated ability to restrain expenditures.
They are an integral part of our overall program to establish the foundations for Australia's future economic growth and prosperity.
SALES TAX

To reduce the heavy tax discrimination against beer and spirits drinkers in favour of wine, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider is to be increased from 10 per cent to the standard sales tax rate of 20 per cent from tonight.
This is expected to increase revenue by $47 million in 1986-87.
At present carbonated soft drinks and mineral waters are subject to sales tax of 20 per cent while other non-alcoholic beverages are exempt.
In order to reduce this discrimination, sales tax at 10 per cent will apply from tonight to packaged flavoured milk, previously exempt fruit juice products and non-alcoholic wine and cider.
This measure will yield revenue of $60 million in 1986-87.
From tonight the rate of sales tax is to increase from 20 to 30 per cent on luxury cars and station wagons.
This will affect broadly those vehicles whose retail price exceeds the depreciation cost limit for income tax purposes-that is $29,646 in 1986-87.
The revenue yield in 1986-87 is $28 million.

Avoidance of sales tax occurs through the device of selling only the discs and tapes on which computer software is embodied and licensing the consumer to use the software itself; sales tax is then payable only on the value of the discs, which is a small fraction of the total price.
The sales tax law is to be amended, with effect from midnight tonight, to ensure that the taxable sale value of the computer discs or tapes encompasses the software on them.
The production of ``in-house'' software will not be affected by the change, nor will exports of software or business purchases of software which are exempted as an aid to manufacture.
Expected revenue raised from this measure is $80 million in 1986-87.

Finally in the sales tax area, the Government has decided to change, with effect from midnight tonight, the classification for sales tax purposes of a number of goods so as to reduce anomalies and inconsistencies.
The areas affected include swimming pools, hand tools, photographic developing and bathroom fittings.
Details are provided in Statement No 4.
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX
The Bank Account Debits Tax rates will be increased from 1 December 1986.
The highest rate will increase from $1.50 to $2.00; other rates will increase by up to a half.
Revenue will increase by $45 million in 1986-87.
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS
I announced earlier that excise on petrol and diesel will increase 3 cents per litre with effect from tonight.
This will yield $625 million in 1986-87 and $715 million in a full year.
The decline in international oil prices and consequent reduction in import parity prices had substantially reduced Government revenue from the taxation of petroleum products.
Even with this measure, total Commonwealth revenue from the taxation of petroleum products will be little changed from 1985-86.
A.C.T. TAXES
The Commonwealth Grants Commission has found that the financial contribution from the Australian Capital Territory continues to be low relative to that in the States.
In those circumstances it is considered fair that revenue raised in the A.C.T. be increased.

The Minister for Territories and I are releasing a separate statement detailing the measures to be taken, which include introduction of a land tax on business properties and increases in gambling taxes and stamp duties.
PROVISIONAL TAX

An anti-avoidance measure will be introduced to overcome arrangements whereby members of closely held partnerships or trusts have sought to avoid provisional tax by manipulating the distribution of income between partners or beneficiaries from one year to the next.
This will raise revenue by $50 million in 1986-87.
VALUATION OF NATURAL INCREASE IN LIVESTOCK
The Economic and Rural Policy Statement of 15 April 1986 announced changes to stock valuation arrangements for animal stud breeders generally.

As the tax deferral advantages associated with stock valuations are generally much greater for horse breeders, the Government has decided to restrict valuation changes to them, and then only in respect of service fees.
Other animal breeders, such as sheep and cattle breeders, will not now be affected.
A separate statement gives the details.
COMPANY ACCOUNTING PERIODS
A small number of companies receive substantial tax deferral benefits through adoption of an accounting year for tax purposes which finishes on a date earlier than 30 June.
Relative to other companies, such companies are able to defer payment of tax for up to six months.
To remove the tax deferral advantage, it is proposed to advance the due dates for payment of their quarterly instalments and assessments.
This change, which affects only the timing of tax payments and not the size of tax liabilities, will be phased in over the three years starting 1986-87.
Less than 5 per cent of all companies will be affected by the change, which is expected to yield about $220 million in 1986-87 and in each of the following two years.
PAY OF DEFENCE FORCE RESERVE
The Dibb Report on Australia's defence capability envisaged an enhanced role for the Defence Force Reserve.
The Government has decided to reinstate full taxation exemption of the pay of Defence Force Reservists from 1 January 1987.
At the same time the special reserve allowance will be discontinued as an offset.
MEDICARE LEVY
As I announced earlier, the Medicare levy will be increased from one per cent to 1 1/4 per cent, from 1 December 1986.
The estimated gain to revenue is $175 million in 1986-87.
Threshold levels are to be raised to ensure that low income earners continue not to pay the levy.
BENEFICIARY REBATES

The taxation rebates for people receiving unemployment, sickness or special benefits will be increased again this year to ensure that people wholly or mainly dependent on such benefits are not liable to tax.
INCOME AVERAGING FOR
SPORTSPERSONS AND PERFORMING
ARTISTS
From the 1986-87 income year, sportspersons and performing artists are to be eligible for income tax averaging provisions designed to smooth out tax liabilities on fluctuating incomes.
Anomalies in the existing authors and inventors scheme are to be removed.
PASSPORT FEES
The validity period of Australian passports will be extended from 5 to 10 years and the fee increased from $30 to $60.
MONETARY POLICY
It is the Government's intention to shift some of the present burden from monetary policy.
Lower interest rates would be compatible with stronger domestic economic activity and balance of payments adjustment provided other policies are taking more of the weight of that adjustment process.
That is one reason why it has been so important to achieve substantial cuts in the Budget deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement in 1986-87.
As I said earlier, total public sector gross borrowings are estimated to fall by over $2 1/2 billion this year.
As a ratio to GDP, the gross PSBR will fall to about 4.4 per cent, compared with 6.0 per cent in 1985-86 and a peak of 8.1 per cent in 1983-84.
Treasury Bond Tenders in 1986-87 are expected to total around $3 billion.
In net terms there will be no new bond raisings.
The whole program will be accounted for by the roll-over of maturing debt.
The gross program compares with $5.7 billion in 1985-86 and a peak of $9.7 billion in 1983-84.
Consistent with this reduced program, the Treasury is announcing tonight details of the next Bond Tender for an amount of $400 million.
Last year's move to a more even spread of tenders over the year was well received.
A similar schedule is planned for this year.
These measures will help to ease pressures on domestic financial markets and to lower interest rates.
Actual interest rate movements will depend also on what happens to overseas interest rates and to inflationary and exchange rate expectations.
In assessing the appropriateness of monetary policy, we will continue to review a wide range of current and prospective financial and general economic indicators.
The Government's basic objective for monetary policy is for it to play its role in full support of other policies.
We will maintain a firm monetary policy, consistent with the need to reduce inflation and to finance a current account deficit which is likely to remain large in 1986-87.
CONCLUSION
Madam Speaker, in conclusion I wish to return to the main theme of tonight's Budget.
I have made it clear that our prime concern was to set in place the pre-conditions for a turnaround in the current account deficit.
Already there is clear evidence that the underlying forces are working as expected.
Last financial year there was a 7.4 per cent increase in the volume of Australia's exports.
Import volumes declined quite sharply-in the first half of 1986 they fell at an annual rate of more than 10 per cent.
This is the beginning of the necessary structural adjustments which I have described-the switching to new products and activities.
But this welcome improvement in export volumes and reduction in import volumes were over-shadowed by the big falls in world commodity prices.
As quickly as we lifted export volumes, export prices fell.
And in the shorter term, while we still maintain our heavy dependence on primary exports, our problem with commodity prices is not going to go away.
Large falls in import volumes are in prospect this financial year, and further export growth is expected.
But once again we must expect those positive outcomes to be masked by poor prices.
As a result, on present indications, little change is expected in our current account deficit as a percentage of GDP for 1986-87 as a whole.
For seasonal and other reasons, we expect a number of large monthly deficits over the remainder of this calendar year.
Looking further ahead, the fundamental adjustments now underway in the economy should help to achieve substantial reductions beyond 1986-87.
Madam Speaker, when this Government was elected to office in March 1983 we inherited from our Coalition predecessors a massively debilitated economy.
We faced a Budget deficit of unprecedented magnitude, double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and the first negative growth in 30 years.
Over the past three and a half years, with absolute determination and the co-operation of the Australian people, we have overcome these legacies.
With historic levels of economic and employment growth and our sweeping reforms to the financial and taxation systems, our record of achievement is an enviable one.
Now there are new challenges to overcome.
The sudden collapse in the prices of our exports and the resulting loss of national income has forced a range of essential adjustments on the nation.
The 1986-87 Budget which I have presented tonight rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.
Earlier I said that by resolute action and some sacrifice all round we can face and defeat any problem.
This means staying competitive with the rest of the world and trading out of our difficulties.
This is the only path to higher growth, real independence and greater prosperity.
This will be this Budget's crowning achievement.
I commend the Budget to the House.
(The Budget Statements for 1986-87 are included as an appendix at the end of this day's proceedings.)

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COUNCIL FOR INTER-GOVERNMENT RELATIONS REPEAL BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to abolish the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations following on the report of the Task Force established in September 1985 to review the ACIR. The Task Group presented its report in January 1986 after extensive consultations with the contributing parties and written submissions from the public. I have tabled the report earlier today in the House.

ACIR was established by the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations Act 1976 with the object of improving inter-government co-operation between the spheres of Federal, State and local government through research and recommendations made under directions provided by Premier's Conference. In addition to representatives of governments, the Council has included representatives from the Commonwealth Opposition, and citizen members.

As noted in the Task Group report, ACIR has not established a reputation for high quality research generally, and has tended to be remote from the practice of inter-governmental relations. Nor have its recommendations on the whole been acted on by participating governments. As a result ACIR has had limited success in improving inter-governmental relations, particularly Commonwealth-State relations. The decision to abolish the Council has been agreed to by all States and the Northern Territory, with the exception of Tasmania. The Government considers that existing mechanisms, including Premiers' Conferences and Ministerial Councils, are adequate to provide effective inter-governmental consultations without the need for a separate research body. I commend the Bill to the House, and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill I am introducing tonight is to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Freedom of Information (Charges) Regulations to reduce administrative costs and increase revenues. The main points are:
introduction of application fees for requests for access to documents and for internal review of decisions;
to increase the hourly charge for search and retrieval of documents;
to introduce an hourly charge for decision-making time;
to exempt persons seeking personal income maintenance documents from all charges and fees;
to maintain after 1 December 1986 the present 45-day time limit for processing requests;
to strengthen provisions for refusal of requests on workload grounds;
to reduce the grounds for remission of charges;
to reduce the obligations on agencies to publish section 8 and section 9 statements and to report statistics; and
miscellaneous amendments of a minor nature.
Background

As is clear from the introduction of this Bill tonight, the Government continues to be concerned by the costs of operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act and by the very low contribution made by users towards meeting those costs. Honourable members will recollect that in June 1985 the Government issued new directions designed to maximise disclosure of information whilst reducing the costs of administering the Freedom of Information Act. Administrative aspects of those measures, particularly the clearance role of my Department, have been valuable in reducing the number of disputes about release of information. Furthermore, costs of processing requests have continued to decrease as agencies gain experience and improve procedures. However, the other major aspect of the Government's directions-changes to the Charges Regulations designed to simplify charging procedures and recoup a more significant contribution by users of the legislation-were frustrated by the Senate when the amendments were disallowed on 13 November 1985.

In 1984-85 the operation and administration of the FOI Act cost the Commonwealth between $16m and $19m, depending on the precise allowance made for overheads, and the preliminary figures for 1985-86 indicate a cost between $14m and $16m. Although there is some indication that the total number of requests is levelling off-preliminary estimates for 1985-86 are 36,000 to 37,000 requests as against 33,000 in 1984-85-it is clear that administration of the Act will continue to involve very substantial Commonwealth expenditure. It is also clear that under the present charging structure only very small contributions will be received from users of the legislation-about $22,000 in 1984-85 and perhaps $60,000 in 1985-86-or rather less than half a per cent of the administration costs. Australia simply cannot afford such a situation. The problems identified by the Government in June 1985 remain. Ways must be found to reduce costs and encourage efficient use of the Act.

Economic circumstances are such that the Government must take action now. In recent months an inter-departmental committee has been examining options for FOI costs savings. This Bill draws on the work of that Committee, though there will doubtless be further possibilities for longer term consideration when it reports. The operation and administration of the FOI Act is also currently under review by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That wide-ranging review will doubtless encompass costs questions.

Whilst the urgency of the current economic situation requires government action now, this does not preclude further consideration of the issues in the light of the reports of the inter-departmental Committee and the Senate Standing Committee.
I shall briefly describe the main features of this Bill. Further details may be obtained from the explanatory memorandum. (Quorum formed)
Application Fees

The Bill proposes a $30 application fee for all requests. This will cover the cost of basic administrative procedures involved in processing the request. The existing $8 charge in respect of administrative procedures will be subsumed in this fee. It will be necessary to pay the fee when making a request. Until the fee is paid there will be no obligation on the agency to deal with the request.
Processing Charges

The existing charge of $12 per hour in respect of time spent searching for and retrieving documents is to be increased to $15 per hour. This increase takes some account of increases in wages and other costs since the charge was set in 1982.

Where requested documents cover sensitive areas such as security, law enforcement, business, policy development and the like, it is often necessary for agencies to consult widely about possible implications of disclosure and to give very careful consideration to the consequences. This can be a costly process which must often be carried out by senior officers. It has accordingly been decided to introduce a new charge of $20 per hour in respect of the time spent determining what access can be granted to a document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they take all day to decide it?
—Well, that is $20 an hour.

SPEECH.PARA: Internal Reviews

Whilst internal review is certainly less costly than review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and is therefore a desirable intermediate stage, there is nothing in the existing charges structure to encourage an applicant to first consider whether he has been properly treated by the agency. He can always hope that review will result in release of more material, or in other favourable action, at no cost to himself. It is accordingly proposed that there be a $40 application fee for internal review of agency decisions.
Personal Income Maintenance Documents

No fees or charges will be payable by persons seeking access to their own personal income maintenance documents. The only exception will be where the person has already had access during the preceding three months and there has been no material change to the documents concerned.
Remission

The existing provision for remission of charges provides that account must be taken of whether a request relates to a person's personal affairs, whether payments would cause hardship and whether disclosure of the documents is in the public interest. The last criterion has caused particular administrative difficulty. In practice many claims for remission on public interest grounds have been generated by members of parliament who have other effective means of access to government information or by media organisations operating on a commercial basis which are well able to make some contribution towards meeting the costs of processing their requests. It is proposed to remove this as a mandatory consideration in considering remission of charges.

The existing remission provisions are not procedurally suited to dealing with remission of the new application fees. A new section will permit remission of an application fee on the limited grounds that payment would cause financial hardship and that the documents related to the applicant's personal affairs.
45-Day Time Limit

As the Act stands at present the time limit for responding to requests would reduce to 30 days from 1 December 1986. Meeting this reduced time limit would require extra agency staff. It is proposed to maintain the present 45-day time limit.
Refusal on Work Load Grounds

Some requests have absorbed very large resources, adding up to many staff-months or even staff-years. Three difficulties have been encountered in applying the existing provisions in the Act enabling refusal of requests on work load grounds:
First, only large requests directed towards classes of documents can be refused. Requests for large numbers of individually specified documents cannot be refused;
Secondly, there is no simple test of what constitutes an unreasonable work load; and
Thirdly, the tests take account only of time spent searching for and retrieving documents but not, generally speaking, time spent in consultation and deliberation regarding exempt content.

The first difficulty will be met by extending the exemption to cover requests for large numbers of identified documents. As for the second difficulty, whilst it would seem to involve a substantial diversion of resources in a large department to spend, say, more than five full staff-days processing a single request, such a diversion of resources could totally disrupt a small agency or office, particularly if it arose when staff were heavily pressed by other commitments. It is not therefore at this stage proposed to introduce an absolute limit on work load.

The test will simply be whether the likely total work in dealing with the request would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations; would interfere substantially with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions; or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests. The last point has been introduced as it would seem quite unfair that one person who made a large request should be able to hinder access to government information by other persons.

The third difficulty will be met by providing that the total work shall be estimated having regard not only to the location and retrieval of relevant documents but also to the consultation and deliberation involved in deciding upon exempt matter.
Publication of Information on Agencies

At present agencies are required to publish separately statements concerning their organisation and functions. This results in significant duplication of material normally included in agency annual reports. The Bill proposes that the publications be amalgamated.

The Act also requires publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of an index of manuals, guidelines and other internal documents used by agencies in decision-making. There has been little evidence of public demand for such materials sufficient to justify printing and publication in bulk. The Bill proposes that copies of the index be available for inspection and purchase at the information access offices already established. This `publication on demand' will avoid printing and publication costs without diminishing public access to the information.
Agency Statistics

I am currently required to report annually to Parliament on the operation of the Freedom of Information Act. A wide range of statistical information must be provided to my Department by agencies for this purpose at considerable cost. It is proposed to very much simplify this statistical information which must be reported. The Bill proposes a reduction to the minimum considered necessary for monitoring the general operation of the Act.
Miscellaneous Amendments

Apart from minor amendments consequential on the major changes described above, the Bill makes an amendment of section 45 to ensure that material provided in confidence to government by non-government sources will be protected even where the information has been incorporated in internal working documents.

As the Health Insurance Commission now has certain functions in relation to investigation of Medicare fraud and overservicing it is no longer appropriate that the Commission should be totally exempt from the operation of the Act. Its transfer from Part I to Part II of the Schedule will provide that it is exempt only in relation to documents concerning its competitive commercial activities.
Application
The new fees and charges in the Bill will take effect only in respect of future applications and requests.
Conclusion

It is estimated that total revenue to be derived from the above measures will be about $4m per year. Additionally, the measures in relation to publication, statistics and burdensome requests will result in cost savings of about $4m. Together, the measures will reduce the net cost of the Freedom of Information Act by about $8m or 50 per cent. This is a significant contribution towards meeting the Government's budgetary objectives. Honourable members will note that these savings do not result from significantly reduced rights of access.

The express exemption from fees and charges of persons seeking access to personal income maintenance documents will protect those who are most vulnerable in respect of access to information they need. The remission provisions will continue to protect other persons where hardship might otherwise prevent access to personal documents. In other cases requestors will make a contribution towards the costs of providing the benefit they receive. I commend the Bill to the House, I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In the Budget Speech and in a statement issued tonight by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), the Government announced details of its tertiary education policies for 1987. The Government will maintain the momentum of its policies, including the maintenance of growth, provision for disadvantaged groups, the development of stronger links with industry, and the maint- enance of rational steady planning as the basis for decision making. To support continued growth in the system, increased resources are required and, as a result of Budget decisions, funds available to tertiary education institutions will increase by 2.6 per cent in real terms in 1987.

In the budgetary circumstances outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), however, the Government has decided to introduce an administration charge of $250 per higher education student per annum from 1987 as a contribution towards the administrative costs of institutional budgets. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision in respect of higher education students in institutions in the States and Northern Territory funded by the Commonwealth. The charge will apply equally to all full time, part time and external students undertaking award course or courses which could form part of an award at a university, college of advanced education or other institutions where the Commonwealth funds higher education places.

Institutions will be required to collect the administration charge at the time of enrolment. For each institution the Commonwealth general recurrent grant payable for a given year will be reduced by an amount equivalent to 90 per cent of the revenue estimated to be derived from the charge. The remaining 10 per cent of revenue, estimated at $9.306m for the States and the Northern Territory in 1987, will be retained by the institutions for expenditure within the institutions for their own purposes. The Bill provides for an appropriate adjustment to be made to payments in the following year where the reduction in grant does not match 90 per cent of the actual administration charge collected. The charge will be indexed on an annual basis according to CTEC processes for adjusting administrative-that is, non-academic-salary costs.

The Bill provides for exemption from the charge for institutions' own award holders, full fee paying overseas students and both full time and part time students who are pensioners and beneficiaries in the categories eligible for an education allowance for full time studies. Beneficiaries under the age related education allowance scheme, incorporating TEAS, the post-graduate awards scheme, or PGA, and Abstudy grants, who are liable for the charge, will have their benefit increased by the value of the charge. Similarly, the overseas student charge applying to subsidised overseas students will be reduced by the amount of the administration charge.

Under these arrangements the Government estimates gross revenue collections by institutions in the States and Northern Territory at $93.064m in 1986-87 of which the institutions will retain $9.306m for their purposes. Adjustments to student assistance benefits and the overseas students charge will cost $27.7m. Revenue from the charge is therefore estimated at $56.057m in 1986-87. Consequential changes in respect of Commonwealth institutions are being made in other Bills being introduced today. I commend the Bill to the House and take this opportunity to table the explanatory memorandum.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend section 4 of the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979, to extend the charge liability to overseas students who enrol in government and private secondary schools, and courses at technical and further education level institutions for which Commonwealth funding is received. The intention is to recoup a proportion of the cost to the Commonwealth of supporting places for overseas students at Australian education institutions. Charge liability is also extended to include diplomatic and consular representatives, their staff and dependants, who undertake tertiary courses.

The further purpose of the Bill is to amend section 6 of the principal Act to fix the charge rates for the 1987 academic year. The new levels of charge are indicated in the Bill. As foreshadowed in 1985, the increase in the overseas students charge proposed in the Bill, for university and advanced education level courses, raises the contribution of a new student or one who commenced the course after 1 January 1986 to 45 per cent of the full average cost of a place. In respect of a student who commenced the course before 1 January 1986, the charge represents 32 per cent of the full average cost, or an increase of 15 per cent over the 1986 level.

The amount of the overseas students charge will be reduced by $250, the amount of the higher education administration charge to be payable by all higher education students in respect of the enrolment. TAFE overseas students who commenced their courses prior to 1 January 1987 will pay 32 per cent of the average Commonwealth contribution to TAFE costs, and new TAFE students will pay 45 per cent. All secondary school overseas students will pay a flat rate of $300. I commend the Bill to the House and take the opportunity to table the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to vary the categories of students exempt from the overseas students charge. This is affected by including in the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979, through inserting section 4A, those categories of students who are exempt from the charge. The current exemption provision relating to a postgraduate student who is the holder of a scholarship to the value of at least $3,500 per annum awarded by an Australian institution is now limited to a person who has been granted such a scholarship and commenced study before 1 January 1987. It is also proposed to withdraw the charge exemption provision for a postgraduate student who is the holder of a scholarship awarded by the Australian-American Educational Foundation.

The proposed extension of the charge, as from 1 January 1987, to postgraduate students who are awarded a scholarship by an educational institution in Australia on or after 1 January 1987, and to all Australian-American Educational Foundation scholarship holders, is expected to raise approximately $1.2m in 1986-87.

The further purpose of the Bill is to amend section 7 of the principal Act to restrict the capacity of a department or authority of the Commonwealth to discharge the liability of a student to whom that department or authority has granted a scholarship or like award, to postgraduate scholarship holders who commenced study before 1 January 1987. I commend the Bill to the House. I take the opportunity to table the explanatory memorandum.
