PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1986-87 and in subsequent years together with the associated prospective deficits in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Legally, payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed moneys available to that Fund. In order to meet any prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund it is customary to seek legislative authority to charge defence and other Consolidated Revenue Fund expenditure to, or reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from, the Loan Fund. This Bill therefore seeks authority to borrow money for defence and other purposes and to enable certain other expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

I should make it clear, however, that the Bill does not authorise defence or other expenditures additional to those otherwise authorised by Parliament under annual Appropriation Acts and under Acts providing for special or standing appropriations. The Bill is simply a machinery financing measure-the provisions of the Bill in fact explicitly prohibit borrowings for expenditures additional to those authorised by the Parliament.

Successive governments have, for many years, introduced legislation in the form of an annual Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures or to reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from Loan Fund in respect of certain non-defence expenditures. In view of the non-controversial, accounting nature of the legislation, which has been acknowledged by all the major political parties in the Parliament, the Bill has been drafted as standing rather than annual legislation. That is, the Bill would provide authority for the necessary financing measures for 1986-87 and subsequent financial years to the extent necessary in the light of the respective years' Budget deficits. Standing loan legislation will in no way detract from Parliament's ability to debate the Budget, nor, as I have already stated, does it impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to authorise, and appropriate moneys for, expenditures for particular purposes.

In the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the Budget deficit in prospect for 1986-87 is estimated to be some $3.5 billion. This gives rise to a prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund of around $5.1 billion-the Consolidated Revenue Fund deficit can differ somewhat from the Budget deficit as some CRF expenditures and receipts are classified as financing transactions in the functional classification of Budget outlays and, for the purposes of the Budget figuring, certain Budget outlays are met direct from either the Loan Fund or the Trust Fund.

Existing standing authorities enable some $2.5 billion of expenditure to be charged to Loan Fund in 1986-87, leaving a shortfall of some $2.6 billion for which separate funding authority is required. This Bill seeks authority to borrow moneys accordingly. The amount of borrowings that may be undertaken pursuant to the proposed legislation is, in the case of defence expenditure, the amount for which appropriation is sought for defence purposes in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1)-some $7.2 billion in 1986-87-and any moneys for defence purposes that may be approved in subsequent appropriation Acts for a particular financial year. The effective limit in 1986-87 is likely to be significantly less than appropriations as defence expenditures cannot be charged to Loan Fund until the legislation is enacted. The legal limit for borrowing for non-defence purposes is determined by the level of borrowing authority approved by the Loan Council. It is estimated that the 1986-87 limits will be sufficient to enable the financing of the Budget deficit.

In concluding, I emphasise that the Bill does not authorise expenditures in excess of those which have already been appropriated by the Parliament under Supply, appropriation or other Acts. It does not in any way impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to appropriate public moneys but simply provides a mechanism for financing expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament. In commending the Bill to the House I table an explanatory memorandum related to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Earlier this evening the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced, as part of the 1986-87 Budget, a number of changes to the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system that are to operate from midnight tonight. This Bill, and two others I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those changes. Given the comments already made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech and the details contained in statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 and the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members, I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed.

Firstly, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages is to be increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Secondly, certain presently exempt non-alcoholic beverages are to be taxed at the 10 per cent rate. These include packaged flavoured milk, non-alcoholic wine and cider and similar beverages and, broadly, all non-carbonated fruit juice products containing not less than 25 per cent by volume of Australian fruit juice.

Another change concerns the rate of sales tax payable on luxury motor cars and station wagons, including four-wheel drive vehicles. Where the wholesale price for sales tax purposes of such vehicles exceeds $19,892, sales tax will be levied at the top rate of 30 per cent. The amount of $19,892 is the tax-exclusive wholesale price, on which sales tax is calculated, equivalent to a $29,646 retail price. This latter amount is the present upper cost limit on which depreciation is allowable on motor cars and station wagons for income tax purposes. This amount will be adjusted each 1 July in line with the indexation adjustment to the income tax depreciation limit.

Finally, the Bill will correct a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the various schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The main changes are: Firstly, all swimming pools, spa pools, spa baths and hot tubs and accessories, which are currently exempt from tax or subject to tax at only 10 per cent, will become taxable at 20 per cent. Secondly, the tax payable on certain film and video recordings will increase from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Thirdly, household fittings and sanitary ware will be subject to tax at the same rate as other household items, namely 10 per cent. Fourthly, the rate of tax on gardening and industrial hand tools and machinery for business or industrial use will be increased to 20 per cent. Next negatives, transparencies and film strips that are produced from exposed film, will be brought within the sales tax base, at the 20 per cent rate. Purchases of computers, calculators and other scientific equipment by individuals such as teachers, students and others for use in schools or universities will no longer be tax exempt. Such purchases by schools and universities themselves will remain exempt. All aircraft, including hot air balloons and other similar aircraft, are to be eligible for exemption from sales tax if used for business or industrial purposes. Finally, several exemption items will be amended to confirm the scope of exemptions currently reflected in decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. I commend the Bill to the House. I table the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill will amend Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1 to 10) and the Sales Tax Regulations. The specific changes are as follows: The value of computer software has traditionally formed part of the Sales Tax base where its value has been reflected in the selling price of goods on which it is contained. However, in recent times those marketing such goods have, purportedly to protect copyright, used the technique of licensing the use of the software, thus separating its value for sales tax purposes from its carrying medium, for example, a disc or tape, which alone has minimal value. The Government could not stand idly by and allow this erosion of the sales tax base, nor permit its spread to other areas such as the marketing of sound recordings or videos. Measures in this Bill will ensure that the value of computer software, sounds or visual images when licensed separately from the carrying medium is brought back within the sales tax base.

As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has already indicated in his Budget Speech, in-house production of software will not be affected by these changes, nor will software produced for export. Software acquired as an aid-to-manufacture will also remain eligible for exemption.

The Bill does not seek to tax the electronic transfer of software by means of the telephone system or satellite communications. The Government will, however, be giving further consideration to this question.

The Bill will also change the sales tax treatment of swimming pools that are constructed on site. In the past, their pools, which are at the top end of the market, were not subject to sales tax. From midnight tonight, the construction of the container or shell of such swimming pools will be treated as the manufacture of goods for sales tax purposes and subject to tax at the rate of 20 per cent.

Until now the process of developing exposed photographic film did not constitute manufacture for sales tax purposes. This Bill will change that. The price charged for developing exposed film will be taxed at 20 per cent.

Finally, the Bill will bring the Sales Tax Law into line with the Customs law, by ensuring that goods imported into Australia on a temporary basis may be entered for home consumption tax-free, where they will be for use in connection with an America's Cup yacht race in Australia or the Bicentennial celebrations.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will declare the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1986-87 financial year and for the 1987-88 and subsequent years. In so doing, the Bill will give effect to the significant personal tax cuts announced as part of the September 1985 tax reform package, and their introduction from 1 December 1986 as announced earlier tonight by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech. The tax cuts are to be reflected in lower pay as you earn deductions from 1 December 1986.

Another tax reform measure to be implemented by this Bill will allow the tax-free threshold only on a pro rata basis in certain circumstances. The Bill will also declare the rates of income tax for 1986-87 payable on the 1985-86 incomes of companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies for tax purposes, as well as on the current year incomes of superannuation funds and certain other trusts.

As announced in the September 1985 tax reform statement, the company tax rate is to be increased to 49 per cent in 1987-88 to help defray the cost of the new imputation system that is to apply from the commencement of that year.

Legislation to declare that higher rate for 1987-88 and subsequent years, which will also be payable by trustees assessed in respect of trust income of non-resident company beneficiaries in 1986-87 and subsequent years, will be introduced later in these sittings. Accordingly, the rate of tax declared by this Bill for 1986-87 for companies and the other bodies taxed as companies will remain at 46 per cent. However, lower rates are to be declared by this Bill on the relevant income of some superannuation funds and on ineligible approved deposit funds as a consequence of the reductions in personal income tax rates. A further lowering of these rates, reflecting the second stage of the personal income tax cuts, will be contained in the later legislation to which I have just referred.

I turn now in more detail to the personal income tax rate measures contained in this Bill. The personal income tax burden will be substantially reduced by an increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100, and by a reduction of all marginal rates of tax, with major reductions in those rates applying at average and higher earnings. The reform of the rate scales will be in two stages. With effect from 1 December 1986 a five-step scale will apply and from 1 July 1987 this will reduce to a four-step scale. From 1 December 1986 the existing 25 per cent rate on income to $12,500 will be reduced to 24 per cent and the threshold level will increase to $12,600. The 30 per cent rate will reduce to 29 per cent and the next two rates of 46 per cent and 48 per cent will reduce to 43 per cent and 46 per cent respectively. There will be a significant drop in the highest marginal rate applied to incomes above $35,000 from 60 per cent to 55 per cent. From 1 July 1987 the marginal rates applying to income in the ranges $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 will both be reduced to 40 per cent, and the top marginal rate will drop from 55 per cent to 49 per cent. These changes to the rate scale will be reflected in the rates payable by non-residents.

Because of the commencement date part-way into the 1986-87 financial year, the rate scale for that year is to be an average of the 1985-86 rate scale and the scale to apply from 1 December 1986-made up of five-twelfths of the 1985-86 scale and seven-twelfths of the new scale. The average rate scale will mean a tax-free threshold of $4,890 for 1986-87 with the rate of tax on incomes to $12,500 being 24.42 per cent. A rate of 26.5 per cent will apply in the income range $12,501 to $12,600, 29.42 per cent in the range $12,601 to $19,500, while for taxable incomes in the range $19,501 to $28,000 and 428,001 to $35,000 the rates will be 44.25 per cent and 46.83 per cent respectively. The maximum marginal rate applying to income over $35,000 will be 57.08 per cent.

An adjustment is to be made to the maximum rate of tax on the unearned income of minors for 1986-87 to reduce the 60 per cent rate now applying to income over $35,000 to 57.08 per cent. For 1987-88 and subsequent years a flat rate of 49 per cent will apply to all unearned income of minors, subject to shading-in arrangements for such income just over $416. The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be 57.08 per cent for 1986-87 and 49 per cent in 1987-88 and subsequent years.

I referred earlier to the adjustment in certain circumstances of the level of the tax-free threshold. In 1986-87 and subsequent years, this threshold will be available only on a pro-rated basis in the year of income in which a person first ceases full time education at a school, college, university or similar institution. The adjusted threshold level will be the proportion of the full threshold that reflects the number of whole months in the year when the person was not engaged in full time education, including the month in which such education ceased. Where income is derived in the part of the year before the person ceases education, the adjusted threshold level will be increased by the lesser of the amount of that income or the balance of the full year threshold.

The tax-free threshold will also be available only on a proportionate basis where a person becomes, or ceases to be, a resident of Australia in a year of income. This measure will not affect the present treatment of non-residents receiving Australian social security pensions and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia. The provisions of the bill are explained in detail in a memorandum, a copy of which I now table. I commend the Bill to the House.

This Bill will amend various taxation Acts, mainly as a consequence of the reforms to be made to the personal income tax rate scale by the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986. The Bill will also give effect to some 1986-87 Budget proposals. It will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to increase the taxable income level, at or below which the maximum pensioner rebate of $250 is available, from $5,595 to $5,914 in 1986-87 and to $6,142 in 1987-88 and subsequent years.

The maximum levels of the beneficiary rebates will also be increased from $220 to $280 for married beneficiaries and from $170 to $190 for other beneficiaries. The income levels above which the rebates are to shade-out will also be increased. In addition, the Bill will extend the benefit of the beneficiary rebates to recipients of benefits or payments under the Commonwealth's Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme. The changes to the pensioner and beneficiary rebates are to take effect from the 1986-87 year.

Other amendments of the Income Tax Assessment Act will reduce the level of the rebates of tax available for net medical expenses in excess of $1,000, payments of home loan interest by a first home buyer and the assessable proceeds of certain life assurance policies. These rebates will be allowed at the rate of 29.42 per cent for 1986-87 and 29 per cent for 1987-88 and subsequent years.

Also reflecting the changes in personal tax rates, another amendment proposed will adjust the method of calculating the amount of any rebate allowable where payments in consequence of a taxpayer's termination of employment are included in his or her assessable income.

Other Acts that are proposed to be amended by this Bill as a consequence of the new personal tax rates are the Income Tax (Bearer Debentures) Act 1971, the Income Tax (Mining Withholding Tax) Act 1979, the Trust Recoupment Tax Act 1985 and the Trust Recoupment Tax Assessment Act 1985. Detailed explanations of the amendments to these Acts and others I have mentioned are contained in the Explanatory Memorandum which is being made available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF MULTICULTURAL AFFAIRS REPEAL BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act 1979 and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Amendment Act 1985. The legislation will commence on a day to be proclaimed. Its effect will be to abolish the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-AIMA.
I remind honourable members of the communique of the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983, which stated:
. . . the future well-being of this country depends upon the acceptance of the cultural, social and economic implications of a multicultural Australia.

That aspiration is an important objective of the Hawke Labor Government and our hopes were expressed during the debate last year about the proper role of AIMA. We believe that enormous improvements were made to AIMA over the ensuing year but not sufficient to avoid a further re-evaluation.

The Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services, ROMAMPAS, under the chairmanship of Dr James Jupp, which has recently reported, has convinced us of the need for a range of approaches that will more effectively ensure that multicultural principles are accepted. In dealing with diversity, we must use diverse approaches to achieve acceptance of the values and benefits of our developing identity built on multiculturalism. Government must take direct responsibility for achieving objectives, and we believe we are now embarking on an improved strategy for that purpose. Part of our strategy involves the setting up of an office of multicultural and ethnic affairs to be staffed and funded within my portfolio in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

The Government appreciates the contribution made by the Council and staff of the Institute to the cause of multiculturalism in our community. However, in our view the continuing life of AIMA is no longer the most effective means of achieving our objectives. The Institute will therefore be wound down and abolished before the end of this year at a saving of $1m during 1986-87 and $2m in a full year. This Bill protects the Commonwealth's interests in that process. In commending the Bill to the House I table a copy of the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 which is now before the House proposes the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty applicable to imports from general tariff sources under item 71.07 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This item covers gold, including platinum-plated gold, unwrought or semi-manufactured. The removal of the duty is to take effect on the third day after the legislation receives the royal assent.

The main commodity involved in the removal of the revenue duty is gold bullion. It is accepted by the Government that the duty is impeding the development of the Australian gold market by restricting imports and preventing the necessary liquidity in periods of peak demand. The gold market could become in important source or foreign exchange earnings as an export oriented service industry. With the removal of the duty, Australia could become an attractive alternative for secure storage of gold bullion because of its geographical remoteness from Europe and political stability, thus earning foreign exchange from storage fees and commissions.

The removal of the import duty should have no adverse effect on domestic producers. In accordance with the Government's commitment to simplification of the Customs tariff, the removal of the duty has been extended to the whole of the tariff item which includes gold bullion, rather than splitting the item to remove the duty from bullion alone.
Financial Impact

The removal of the duty from the relevant item is estimated to result in a loss to the revenue of the order of $20,000 per annum. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

These changes give effect to measures contained in the 1986 Budget. These proposals are operative from 8 o'clock this evening by standard time in the Australian Capital Territory.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 9 (1986) increase the rate of duty on manufactured tobacco and certain refined petroleum products for the purposes of the Excise Tariff Act. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14 (1986) make complementary changes to the Customs Tariff Act in respect of duties applying to imported manufactured tobacco and refined petroleum products. The increase of $1.90 per kilogram in the rate of duty applicable to manufactured tobacco in the Budget completes the alignment of the tobacco rate with that for cigarettes which was begun in the 1983 Budget.

Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1986) increase the export duty on uranium concentrate produced from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory from 11c to 80c per kilogram of anhydrous triuranium octoxide contained in the uranium concentrate. The duty, which has been imposed since 1980, is in recognition of the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities related to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region. The increase reflects the Government's decision, made within the budgetary context, to move closer to recovery of the costs of this monitoring and research. Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals are being circulated to honourable members.

I also advise honourable members that the rates of diesel fuel rebate will increase in conjunction with the duty changes on refined petroleum products. The new rebate rates for currently eligible use of diesel fuel will be 23.884c per litre in respect of primary production, 21.496c per litre for mining operations and 18.185c per litre for other prescribed use in residential premises, homes for aged persons, nursing homes, hospitals and other institutions providing medical or nursing care. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation paying the Legal costs in Mr G. Sims' libel suit against Mr N. Wran;
(2) If so, will any damages awarded be a private benefit for Mr Sims or will they go to the ABC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In a staff circular issued on 20 October 1983, the Board of the ABC stated that it had resolved to support Mr Sims in respect of his costs because the Board accepts the principle of support for staff who are defamed in the course of their duties.

(2) The details of the limitations on the total costs the ABC has agreed to bear and the arrangements as to the disbursement of any damages awarded in relation to this matter are the subject of a confidential agreement between the ABC and Mr Sims.

Prior to entering into the agreement, the ABC sought independent legal advice to ensure that any agreement it entered would not result in improper expenditure of public moneys and would not result in a commitment to an open-ended arrangement.

The ABC has also made a point of publicising to staff that its decision in this instance was based on the particular circumstances, merits and facts relating to this matter and must not be taken as a precedent for other cases.

Further, the ABC advised my Department on 7 March 1986 that the Corporation's solicitor has given a written opinion that a statement containing information as to any apportioning of damages between the ABC and Mr Sims may affect the current case of Sims V Wran. Therefore the ABC considers that it would be inappropriate to make further information public until the matter is resolved.
Taking account of the legal advice given to the ABC I am therefore unable to provide all of the information requested by the Honourable member.
However, I do accept that this information is of interest to the Parliament and upon resolution of the case I will advise Parliament of the conditions of the agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 22 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that his Department's staffing is to be reduced by 50; if so, in what sections will reductions occur and how many personnel will each section lose.

(2) Have the extra staff employed to clear the backlog of claims under the Export Market Development Grants Scheme been affected by the reduction; if so, how many extra staff have been put on to assist with the processing of claims since 1 May 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is a fact that the average operative staffing level for the Trade portfolio for 1985/86 will be at least 50 less than the 1984/85 level. The reductions are expected to be achieved by attrition. The areas affected are -Central Offices of the Department of Trade and the Australian Trade Commission and the State Offices of the Commission.

(2) A special task force was formed between 11 March and 30 June 1985 to assist the Export Development Grants Board process additional claims. A total of 19 officers were involved in the task force but all were provided from existing staff resources. No additional staff were recruited for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 22 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the backlog of claims expected to be under the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme by 30 June 1985.
(2) What extra funds or staff have been or will be allocated to clear the backlog of claims before 30 June 1985.
(3) Does the $48m saving from the EMDG Scheme for 1985-86 reflect a transfer of expenditure from 1985-86 to 1984-85.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1984-85 Annual Report of the Export Development Grants Board indicated that the claimed value of outstanding claims as at 30 June 1985 was $44.3m representing some 3568 claims. The Report states that the expected cash payout figure for these claims, based on estimates made by the Board, is of the order of $28m.

(2) Funds of $54m were provided by way of Advance to the Minister for Finance in June 1985 to reduce the backlog of outstanding claims. These Funds were additional to the 1984-85 Budget allocation of $125m and resulted from the Government's consideration of a recommendation by the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel (the Ferris Panel) on the EMDG claims backlog. As regards staff, a special task force was formed from within existing staff resources to assist the Export Development Grants Board (EDGB) process the additional claims. That is, no additional staff were recruited for this purpose. The task force operated during the period 11 March to 30 June 1985 and involved a total of 19 officers.

(3) As indicated by the Treasurer in his May 1985 Economic Statement, the savings of $48m under the EMDG scheme for FY 1985-86 relate to savings in the forward estimates of expenditure. These savings result from the implementation of amendments to the scheme from 20 May 1985 and a deferral of payment of some commitments into future years when the reduced cost of the amended scheme will make less of a call on the Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 20 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Which international airlines are presently allowed to interline, or provide cabotage for passengers in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Air India has rights to carry international interline traffic on flights between Perth and Sydney/Melbourne. However the airline does not currently operate through Perth and is not exercising these rights.

Singapore Airlines has rights to carry international interline traffic on flights between Darwin and Sydney/Melbourne/Perth. However the airline has not operated services through Darwin for some years and is not exercising these rights.
In regard to cabotage, in common with the practice followed by most countries, no international airlines have rights to carry domestic traffic between points in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any action been taken by his Department to investigate the potential for uniform co-operative legislation similar to that implementing the National Companies and Securities Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department has not undertaken an investigation of the potential for uniform co-operative legislation similar to that implementing the National Companies and Securities Scheme. State co-operative legislation varies from State to State; it covers a wide area including housing, credit and rural co-operatives. Whilst the ideal of uniform legislation is most commendable its achievement would require an active desire, on the part of the States, for this to be achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to establish a National Transport Safety Board to investigate transport accidents occurring under federal jurisdiction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Against the background of stringent budgetary constraints, it has not been possible to establish a National Transport Safety Board.

Arrangements for investigating transport accidents or allegations of unsafe transport equipment which are subject to federal jurisdiction have been strengthened. The Federal Office of Road Safety now includes a unit which investigates all claims that equipment or parts for motor vehicles may be hazardous. These investigations may lead to possible vehicle safety recalls. Recent amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will also facilitate safety recalls.

Provision was included (section 70) in the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 for the Minister for Transport to establish an independent Board of Inquiry to conduct investigations into accidents involving AN. Two such Boards of Inquiry have been established since then.

In the marine field the Navigation Act 1912 provides for investigation of accidents. Preliminary investigations are carried out by Departmental marine surveyors. In the light of a preliminary inquiry, I may request a Court of Marine Inquiry to investigate the accident. This is an independent judicial inquiry.

Within the Department of Aviation, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation also carries out a specialist task in investigating all accidents and incidents involving civil aircraft operating within Australia and reports directly to me.
These arrangements have proved effective in dealing with accidents subject to Federal jurisdiction.

ANSWER.PARA: AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES

Community Employment Program project applications received from State Government departments and statutory authorities, local government authorities and instrumentalities and community and other non-government organisations are assessed against established guidelines, criteria and priorities by State/Territory Consultative Committees comprising representatives of Government and community organisations. Final approval is given by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES

Jobs on Local Roads is an element of the Community Employment Program and funds are administered and allocated as for that Program except that project applications are also examined by the Federal Department of Transport within the assessment process.

The figures provided in the tables below are for the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) grant year from 1 November to 31 October.

CYSS grant funds are allocated to and administered by publicly elected Local Management Committees (LMCs) to operate a CYSS project within the local community for one year. In accepting a CYSS grant, LMCs agree to comply with the terms, conditions and procedures set out in the CYSS Guidelines and Departmental manuals. These include the provision of quarterly financial returns and an annual audit report, at the end of the grant period, to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

All applications for CYSS grants are submitted to the CYSS State Advisory Committees (SACs) which consider submissions against the CYSS Guidelines and also seek the views of local Federal Members on projects in their electorates. Grants are made to incorporated non-profit organisations or local government authorities which are required to meet the guidelines of the respective schemes and satisfy the requirements of the Audit Act.

Funds were administered by Industry Training Committees.

The Industry Training Services (ITS) Program is designed to aid and stimulate the development of training through all sectors of industry and commerce, including small business. The Program's aim is to use training to promote efficiency, productivity and safety as well as industry's capacity to cope with new equipment, new techniques and changes in processing and market requirements.

Under the Program, funds are provided for the employment of Training Development Executives (TDEs) and Training Development Officers (TDOs) by National and State Industry Training Committees (ITCs), as well as for the development of new training programs, research into training needs, the production of training manuals and the promotion of training.

ITCs also may receive training development grants. These grants are provided to enable ITCs to research training needs, develop training activities and products, to purchase minor items of training equipment and to promote ITC activities to the industry. Most projects are national in character, though some are undertaken in particular States.
The Industry Training Standing Committee of the National Training Council recommends the allocation of funds for training development grants under the Industry Training Services Program.
AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES
Funds are administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

Assistance under the Skills in Demand (SID) program (now being progressively replaced by the Adult Training Program) is provided on a project basis where the proposed training will overcome a skill shortage, the training arrangement has the acceptance of both sides of industry, trainees successfully completing the training are assured of employment and the industry concerned contributes substantially to the cost of the course.

Through its analysis of skills shortages in the labour market, the Department provides periodic information on those occupations for which training under SID may be considered. Funds have been allocated on a project basis as suitable proposals have been put forward.
AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES
Funds are administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

The wage subsidy provisions of the Program provide for the local offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service to match eligible unemployed job seekers with vacancies lodged by employers who have indicated their intention to participate in the program.
The program was subsumed under a new general wage subsidy program called JOBSTART which commenced operations on 2 December 1985.

Projects have not been funded under the wage subsidy programs. Funds are allocated to the Department's State/Territory offices having regard to past activity levels and forecast labour market trends and activities.
AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES

The School to Work Transition Program is administered jointly by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Education in collaboration with State education authorities. Courses are funded by the Department of Education. The Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) recruits eligible trainees to the courses and arranges for payment of their allowances. This involvement by the CES has continued under the Participation and Equity Program.
Approval of courses for training allowances is the responsibility of the State/Territory Training Branches of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.
AMOUNT AND PROPORTION FOR NEW SOUTH WALES
The funds are administered by the Women's Bureau, Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, Canberra.

Recommendations for funding are made to the Minister by the Women's Research and Employment Initiatives Programs Advisory Committee. Membership of this committee is drawn from the National Labour Consultative Council's Committee on Women's Employment and comprises a representative from the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Funding for projects is approved by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

Funds are not specifically allocated to individual States. In respect to New South Wales, agreement was reached with the State Government to fund 100 participants from the Western Suburbs of Sydney from a national allocation of 600 places. On a pro-rata basis the allocation to NSW is estimated at $700,000 over the two financial years 1984/85 and 1985/86.
New Enterprise Incentive Scheme funds are administered by State Offices of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

Decisions on the allocation of funds to participants are made by State assessment committees comprising Commonwealth and State Government officials and other members with specific knowledge in the area of small businesses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his decision to establish a committee to review the international air freight policy relating to export of primary produce arise from (a) a departmental request, (b) requests from primary produce exporters, (c) requests from air freight charter operators, (d) State governments or (e) some other source; if so, which source.

(2) Was the committee, either by oral direction or by the terms of reference of the review, specifically limited to investigating only those areas of air freight policy relating to charter or non-scheduled carriers.

(3) Did the committee investigate (a) possible variations to the existing scheduled services or (b) variations to Qantas' current networking philosophy and practice, as a means of increasing primary produce export; if not, why not.
(4) Does the new air freight policy depend for its success on Australian charter operators being granted access to consolidated inbound cargo.
(5) Is access to consolidated inbound cargo within his powers to grant or is such access a bilateral matter requiring the consent of the source nation of such flights.
(6) Did Qantas in its submission to the committee state that it derives no less than 83% of total cargo revenue from the carriage of inbound freight.
(7) Did Qantas also state that outbound freight contributes a meagre 17% in revenue terms to cargo yield.
(8) Do the other scheduled carriers operating to and from Australia experience similar percentages of revenue attributable to inbound and outbound freight.

(9) Has he any evidence to suggest that non-Australian scheduled carriers or their governments, will willingly allow access to consolidated cargo from their countries destined for Australia, to non-scheduled Australian charter operators.

(10) If non-scheduled outbound charter flights take place under this new policy, will each subsequent inbound flight carrying consolidated cargo result in a loss of cargo to Qantas and/or existing scheduled carriers.

(11) Did the committee state on page 77 of their report that (a) the evidence presented to the committee indicated that round trip charter operations from Australia would not be viable solely on the basis of achieveable outbound freight rates, even with access to inbound consolidated cargo the viability of round trip operations would most likely be marginal, (b) there would normally be little interest amongst shippers in using a charter to fly inbound general cargo to Australia at rates above scheduled airlines rates and (c) charter aircraft would not fly unless sufficient cargo were found for the inbound legs and therefore it would appear that charter operations would need to ensure inbound cargo by matching, or undercutting inbound freight rates being offered at points of uplift for carriage on scheduled services, before round trip charters would be contemplated; if so, does this imply that the success of this new policy is based on non-scheduled operators taking commercial decisions to negotiate charter outbound flights with exporters and to negotiate access to inbound consolidated cargo with foreign governments to achieve round trip operations which the committee asserts, on the evidence presented to it, would have marginal viability.
(12) How many new flights does he expect to operate in the 1st year of operation of this new policy.
(13) Would a lack of new flights operating in the 1st year of the new policy indicate that (a) the policy was a failure or (b) there was little demand for such flights.
(14) If there is little demand foreseen for such flights, why did he say in his press release that the new policy was a boon for primary producers.

(15) Did Qantas state in its submission to the review that (a) in a situation where genuine demand exists for the carriage of primary produce out of Australia which is unable to be met by capacity available at the appropriate time on scheduled service, Qantas cannot, nor would wish to argue that such demand remain unsatisfied, (b) in order that all major aspects of the national interest can be served in these situations, they believe there is every justification for tests of (i) genuine demand for export to a given destination exists and (ii) prior availability of capacity on designated flag carriers in each case and (c) if these elementary inquiries show demand which cannot be met there should be no im- pediment to the procurement of outside capacity.

(16) Was Qantas referring to tests to be applied to ad hoc operations; if so, are the comments of Qantas equally applicable to the consideration of applications for new scheduled services which are able to meet the tests applied by Qantas.
(17) Has Qantas announced 3 new B747 EUD ser- vices to operate from April 1986 on a Melbourne/Bombay/London route.
(18) Is Qantas investigating one-stop Australia/UK flights via Singapore, similar to flights now operated by Singapore Airlines; if so, will some load restrictions apply.
(19) Is it reasonable to assume that any load restrictions will be more likely to apply to cargo rather than passengers.
(20) How will the new Qantas frequencies referred to in part (17) provide any uplift to Australian produce exporters to (a) South-East Asia and (b) the Middle East.
(21) How do Qantas flights Sydney/Melbourne/Perth/Bombay/London assist Victorian or Western Australian produce exporters to reach (a) South-East Asian or (b) Middle East markets.
(22) How will Qantas one-stop via Singapore to London flights assist primary produce exporters if load restrictions apply.
(23) How many Qantas flights per week included a Middle East port on 1 November in (a) 1975, (b) 1980, (c) 1984 and (d) 1985.
(24) How many Qantas flights per week will include a Middle East port on 1 November 1986, on best available information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to hold the Review arose from representations received from both primary produce exporters and some State Governments regarding seasonal shortfalls in cargo capacity on scheduled services from certain Australian destinations.

(3) The Terms of Reference gave the Committee the authority to examine the role played by Qantas and other international scheduled operators in the carriage of air freight. The Committee did not provide recommendations to the Government on airlines' scheduling procedures.
(5) Approval of international charter flights involves both the country of origin and the country of destination, and where applicable, overflight approvals from countries in between.
(8) My Department does not have access to commercial information of this nature.

(9) To date there has only been one flight operated under the policy by an Australian based charter operator, namely IPEC. On that occasion IPEC did not seek approval to carry any freight on the return leg from New Guinea to Australia.

The Government of Papua New Guinea has on two occasions rejected applications from IPEC to operate 3 month programs of primary produce charters from Cairns to Port Moresby, following objections from Air Niugini. Again, IPEC did not seek approval to carry cargo on the return leg to Australia. Both applications were approved by the Australian Government.

Transcorp Airways, which has operated the majority of flights under the primary produce policy, is not regarded as an Australian based operator. Guidelines for what constitutes an Australian based operator were published in Hansard on 26 May 1986. It should be noted, however, that on each occasion that Transcorp has sought to carry consolidated cargo to Australia in conjunction with an outbound primary produce flight, approval from the country where the inbound load was collected was forthcoming.

(10) Granting charter operators access to inbound consolidated cargo will not automatically affect the loads of scheduled carriers. There could be situations, as has occurred in the past, where a temporary backlog exists for freight destined for Australia and scheduled carriers are unable to meet demand. In any case, the granting of approval to carry consolidated freight does not guarantee charter operators an inbound load. Charter flights must still compete for such loads in the market place and may not necessarily be able to match the price or level of service offered by existing scheduled services.

It should also be noted that the primary produce charters are subject to a needs-based approach, i.e. charters operate where scheduled airlines are not able to carry the freight. This is administered by the Australian aeronautical authorities giving Qantas the right of first refusal on the outbound charter flight, provided Qantas can match the price and date of departure, and indicates its willingness to do so within 24 hours of notification of the charter. It is left to the aeronautical authorities of the destination country to assess the reaction of its national carrier.

(11) Yes. However, an important objective of the policy change was to remove any unnecessary impediments to the operation of primary produce charter flights to allow exporters to test their market potential. Whether such flights actually operate is dependent on a range of factors, including buyer preference, harvest yields, and the commercial judgment of charter operators.

(12) Accurate forecasts of that nature are not poss- ible. There are a number of variables including the success of the growing season, the value of the Australian dollar, the demand for Australian exports, available capacity on scheduled services, cargo rates offered and the attitude of other Governments.

(14) Since November 1985 to the end of May 1986, my Department has approved 65 outbound primary produce flights under the new policy. This has had a significant impact on the amount of capacity available to exporters and has gone a long way towards eliminating the seasonal shortfalls in capacity and the associated delays and uncertainty which previously existed. It is now up to primary producers and their various marketing authorities to establish a more co-ordinated approach to testing and securing export markets.

(16) Qantas has advised that it was referring to other than scheduled services designed to meet ad hoc demands and/or for providing capacity for traffic destined for distribution/consumption at a port not served by scheduled carriers or to which no convenient international connections were available.
(17) No. Qantas announced the operation of one B747-EUD and two B747-200 services weekly on the Melbourne/Bombay/London route from April 1986.

(18) Qantas has advised that it is constantly evaluating the operation of fast services to UK/Europe using new and existing aircraft types. Such evaluations include consideration of optimum use of available cargo capacity.

Any load restrictions which may apply to a one stop Qantas service would not affect cargo on the Australia/Singapore sector. In such cases cargo destined for Europe may be carried on other Qantas flights.

(20) The Qantas services to Bombay/London will not provide uplift for cargo destined for South East Asia or the Middle East. However, from April Qantas will still operate thirteen flights from Sydney/Melbourne to Singapore, seven of which will pass through Bahrain en route to London. Qantas will also operate thirteen flights a week to Singapore from other Australian cities.
(21) Qantas has not operated flights on the route Sydney/Melbourne/Perth/Bombay/London since June 1981. There are no plans to reintroduce such a service in the near future.
(23) (a) Seven B747 services weekly in each direction which provided 73.5 tonnes of cargo capacity weekly in each direction to/from Australia.
(b) Ten B747 sevices weekly in each direction which provided 105 tonnes of cargo capacity weekly in each direction to/from Australia.
(d) One B747-200 and six B747-300 services weekly in each direction which provided 94.5 tonnes of cargo capacity weekly in each direction to/from Australia.

(24) Based upon current plans as at 31 May, Qantas will operate seven B747-300 services weekly in each direction which will provide 94.5 tonnes of cargo capacity weekly in each direction to/from Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedures may residents of Belrose NSW, use in objecting to the siting of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) earth satellite station and tower in the Snake Creek/Belrose Valley.
(2) Does OTC have overriding powers to site a communications facility in a residential area in opposition to residents' expressed wishes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia), is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Procedures open to the residents of Belrose to object to the construction of the Sydney Earth Station included all steps available to residents in any other construction project. OTC, though a Commonwealth business enterprise, has submitted to all of the local government planning processes. Indeed, unlike many developers, OTC convened a number of widely publicised meetings with residents by distributing invitations by letter box drop, advertising in the local papers and by writing to State and Federal Members of Parliament.

Full details of OTC's plans were displayed at the Belrose Community Centre, where OTC staff invited comments and suggestions. In addition, models of the site, plan drawings and an environmental assessment were on display at the council Chambers for almost two months (during October and November 1985). During December OTC's development application was heard by the Council and, despite wide notice, not a single resident attended in person to oppose the development. Residents with concerns or suggestions were further encouraged to make approaches to OTC, to Members of Parliament and to Local, State and Commonwealth tribunals established for these purposes.

(2) As a Commonwealth statutory authority OTC is not bound by State or Local Government laws in the establishment of international telecommunications facilities. As with other public utilities, some residents in a particular area may consider that they are adversely affected by a development. OTC has always been mindful, however, of the need to explain its plans to local residents, to take into account local comments and criticisms and to seek ways of blending its developments in with local communities' wishes and expectations. Despite wide invitations to residents to lodge objections to OTC's proposals, only two written complaints were lodged with the Council in the case of the Sydney Earth Station and as mentioned above no residents appeared at the Council meeting discussing the proposal to speak against it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does his Department measure (a) labour and (b) capital productivity (i) generally and (ii) in small business.
(2) How is increased productivity normally distributed to the community.
(3) What departmental publications and papers are available to Members on the productivity calculus.
(4) Have plans been made by him or his Department to turn productivity increases into superannuation benefits; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (i) In 1975 a Working Party on the Measurement of Labour Productivity was established by the Minister for Labor and Immigration to consider the appropriate method of measuring labour productivity for wage fixation purposes. The Working Party Report recommended that labour productivity should be measured using market sector output (as the numerator) with labour input (the denominator) being market sector employment adjusted for hours worked and changes in the quality of labour. In addition, it favoured an adjustment to the measure of output for changes in the terms of trade to yield a measure of ``effective productivity''.

Because short-term movements in productivity may be highly volatile, it was recommended that labour productivity estimates should be based on a long-term trend rather than on short-term changes. However, the current state of the economy (including short-term fluctuations in productivity and the terms of trade) should be taken into account in determining whether it is appropriate to increase wages or improve conditions of work on account of productivity growth. My Department supports use of this measure in the context of centralised wage fixation.
(a) (ii) Official data that would enable the calculation of labour productivity in the small business sector are not currently available.

(b) (i) & (ii) Estimates of the amount of capital inputs used in the production process are difficult to quantify. Among the considerations for the measurement of capital are: how to aggregrate the capital stock-whether to use net or gross capital stocks; what depreciation rate and age efficiency assumptions are appropriate; whether to include land and inventories; and whether to adjust for capacity utilization. Because of the considerable conceptual problems which arise from such considerations there is no generally agreed method to measure capital productivity.

(2) Productivity growth is normally distributed to the community in a variety of ways. It can result in improvements in the profit share and/or the wage share, or it can result in lower prices. Alternatively, the Working Party on the Measurement of Labour Productivity, noted above, suggested it can be used for other purposes ``either of a private character (such as increases in leave or reduced working hours or other improvements in conditions of employment), or of a community nature (such as expansion in the size of the non-market sector and the functions undertaken by government. . .)''.
(3) Report of the Working Party on the Measurement of Labour Productivity, AGPS, 1976, a copy of which is available in the Parliamentary Library.

(4) The question of any change in wages or conditions of employment, including employer contributions to superannuation schemes, based on national productivity grounds is for determination by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government come to a decision on the adoption of the recommendations contained in the report by Professor Kerr L. White entitled `Australia's bicentennial health initiative-Independent review of research and educational requirements for public health and tropical health in Australia'; if so, what (a) re- commendations are to be adopted and (b) are the estimated (i) establishment and (ii) full year operational costs for implementing each recommendation.
(2) Is it a fact that the full year cost of introducing all the report's recommendations is estimated to be $100.5 million.
(3) Is there a shift underway from control of the entire health sciences and health care system from the supply side to control from the demand side.

(4) Does Australian experience confirm Professor White's claim that 40 to 60 per cent of the benefits associated with nearly all interventions directed at both individuals and communities are accounted for by the placebo and Hawthorne effects.
(5) Has the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine outlived its usefulness; if so, what remedial action is proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government is still considering the recommendations made by Professor Kerr L. White.

(2) No. The figure of $100.5 million mentioned in the report includes all current expenditure on health and medical reseach including current grants of some $50 million under the Medical Research Endowment Fund.

(3) The containment of health care costs clearly requires action on both the demand and supply sides. An important contribution to this objective will be a major inquiry into medical education and the supply of doctors which will be initiated shortly.
(4) I am advised there is no Australian evidence relevant to the statement by Professor White to which the honourable member refers.

(5) The School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine has made a major contribution to Australia's health care and public health system over many years. However, the arrangements within which the School was set up jointly between the Department of Health and the University of Sydney date from 1930 and are now in need of review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 12 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government decided to assist 42 of the 150 isolated communities originally listed to receive ABC television via the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme; if so, will he consider giving Government support such as self-help schemes for translators, to the remaining 108 isolated communities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government announced on 20 January 1986 that it will be providing ABC television retransmission facilities to 42 remote communities through the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme (RUCS). The facilities are planned to be completed by 1988.

In the meantime, the Government will continue to provide retransmission facilities for ABC television through my Department's ongoing Capital Works Program. This program provides the basis for extending or upgrading ABC transmission facilities in various centres across the entire country. All communities considered, but not selected for RUCS, will be considered individually for inclusion on this program. However, they will be competing for priority with other similar projects and their inclusion will be subject to the availability of funds in the context of the budgetary process.

Any community not selected for provision of a Government-funded facility, either through RUCS or through the regular Capital Works Program, is able to consider building their own facilities under the Self-Help Broadcasting Reception Scheme. However, while every effort is made to simplify planning, licensing and administrative requirements under this scheme, Commonwealth funding through my Department is not provided under the self-help scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The Statutory Marketing Authorities (SMAs) within my portfolio have responsibilities for export marketing. This involves export control, product promotion or, in the case of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) export sales. The enabling legislation of the authorities provides them with powers to do all things necessary for the purpose of carrying out their functions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to my question No. 1558 (Hansard, 11 February 1986, pages 133-4), has the Australian Broadcasting Corporation taken steps to ensure that the copyright accreditation after its productions is written in Arabic numerals.

(2) Will he write to the management of the ABC and each of the commercial television stations asking them to use whatever influence they have among overseas television producers whose programs are destined for Australia to include as many programs as possible with the date of production in Arabic numerals; if not, why not.

(3) Will he write to the management of each of the commercial television stations asking them to conclude all Australian produced television programs with the date of production shown in Arabic numerals; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. As far as the ABC is concerned it obtains overseas program material from diverse sources and is not in a position to influence the style of captioning adopted.
Each of the Australian commercial television stations purchase their overseas programs either independently, or more commonly, through a networking arrangement.

The Government does not have any control or influence over the purchasing practices of the commercial television stations. The only external regulation would be in terms of the Program Standards of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). These standards do not, however, extend to prescribing such matters as placing the date of production in Arabic numerals.

Concluding programs with the date of production in Arabic numerals is really a matter for the producer and is not a significant matter for Ministerial representations to the ABC nor Australian commercial television stations who purchase overseas programs.

(3) No. For Australian produced programs, the date of production in Arabic numerals is a matter first and foremost for the producers themselves and also possibly for the purchasers of those programs. It is not a matter which comes within the area of my responsibility just as it is not something upon which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has specified a standard.
It would therefore be inappropriate for me to exercise any influence over how producers show the date of the production of their programs.
