QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the January 1986 edition of Australian Aviation entitled `How bad are ATC delays at Sydney Airport'; if so, what is his response to the criticisms concerning (a) standard instrument departures, (b) flow controller restrictions, (c) speed control and (d) the spacing of aircraft.
(2) What action is being taken to correct any shortcomings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Standard Instrument Departures have been devised at most airports in Australia where Air Traffic Control is in operation. They are designed to reduce pilot and air traffic controller workload by predetermining a path for an aircraft to establish itself on its outbound route. They also take into consideration other arriving or departing flight paths which may impose restriction to a pilot's preferred flight path.

Additionally the Standard Instrument Departures take special account of environmental aspects by routing aircraft, where possible, over open or less built-up areas; for example at Sydney, over Botany Bay and via Bontany Bay Heads.
The Standard Instrument Departures at Sydney are not restrictive by overseas standards and in most cases incur very little increase in distance to be flown.

The author of the article has quoted the most restrictive Standard Instrument Departure, which applies to jet aircraft departing from runway 16 and proceeding to the west. A comparable procedure at San Francisco when departing to the east would, in some runway configurations, necessitate an aircraft reaching 13000 feet west of the airport prior to taking up its eastbound track.

(b) Flow control restrictions at Sydney are more stringent than at Melbourne because Sydney is almost twice as busy an any other major airport in Australia, apart from those used exclusively or General Aviation.

Additionally, with airspace limitations in the Sydney area, the benefit of extensive radar vectoring of aircraft is not always possible. At many overseas airports, aircraft are radar vectored over greater distances, often at lower levels, to achieve an orderly flow of air traffic.

(c) Speed control is used frequently by Sydney air traffic controllers in order to reduce the need for aircraft to enter holding patterns. This cannot always be achieved when delays of more than approximately four minutes are necessary. The holding patterns usually flown are at medium levels away from residential areas alleviating noise nuisance as much as possible.

(d) The spacing of aircraft at Sydney is in accordance with international standards. The author of the article appears to overlook the fact that the runway used for arriving aircraft is often the one used for departing aircraft. Thus for equity to departing traffic, the time interval between arrivals is usually two to three minutes.

Large aircraft, such as Boeing 747s, take longer to vacate the runway after landing, and, even if departing aircraft were not a consideration, two minutes between arriving Boeing 747s would barely be sufficient. In addition, wake turbulence separation must be applied between most passenger aircraft operating in Australia. For example, the minimum distance between a departing Fokker Friendship and a Boeing 747 is six miles; or two minutes apart.
Notwithstanding the limitations mentioned above, Sydney air traffic controllers are regularly achieving movement rates of between 55 and 60 aircraft per hour.
(2) My Department has taken and is taking further steps to improve the system and alleviate delays.

Already in use is a system where, under certain conditions, aircraft can land on one runway whilst, simultaneously, others can land or take-off from the crossing runway. This system is limited to certain aircraft types by day, with specific meteorological conditions.

The taxiway augmentation program approved by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works has commenced. The program will reduce runway occupancy time to provide an estimated two per cent increase in practical runway capacity. This will achieve savings in runway operation delay costs and aircraft taxiing costs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the full implications for the redistribution of air space following the selection of Badgerys Creek as the site for the second Sydney airport, in view of the fact that the Kingswood Ammunitions Storage Facility, St Marys Munitions Factory, and Fluers Radio Observatory are all within approximately 10 nautical miles of the airport site and subject to their own air space restrictions.
(2) Are changes to military air space restrictions necessary to allow the unrestricted use of the Badgerys Creek site; if so, what are they.
(3) Is he able to say what the views are of the Department of Defence towards any proposed adjustments to military air space.
(4) Are these considerations likely to lead to restriction on the use of the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek.
(5) What are the implications for general aviation of any redistribution of controlled air space particularly for training operations from Bankstown and other Sydney airfields.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The full implications of siting the second Sydney Airport at Badgerys Creek with regard to the facilities specified are as follows:

(a) Kingswood Ammunition Storage Facility in its present form will have no adverse effect on Badgerys Creek due to a combination of normal aircraft performance operations and Air Traffic Control procedures which will keep aircraft clear of the Restricted airspace. Likewise Badgerys Creek will have no adverse effect on Kingswood.
(b) St Marys Munitions Factory will have no adverse effect as projected future flight paths will take aircraft clear of the area. Conversely Badgerys Creek will have no adverse effect on St Marys.

(c) As has already been identified in the Environmental Impact Statement the Fluers Radio Observatory could not co-exist with an airport at Badgerys Creek. Also reflected in the Statement is the fact that increased residential and industrial development in the area would seriously restrict Observatory operations in the future. Once this facility has been relocated the requirement for restricted airspace and its effect on the airport would no longer exist.
(2) The detailed airspace arrangements are matters for discussion between the Departments of Aviation and Defence through the interdepartmental Air Co-ordinating Committee.
(3) Any questions regarding the views of the Department of Defence should more properly be directed to my colleague the Minister for Defence.
(4) No. Air Traffic Control procedures will be developed and airspace will be designed to overcome restrictions.

(5) My Department is confident that by working in co-operation with the General Aviation industry, we will arrive at a fair and equitable allocation of airspace that will meet the continued and developing requirements for General Aviation training.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Departments of Transport and Aviation: Secretaries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why were the occupants of the positions of the secretaries of the Departments of Transport and Aviation exchanged.
(2) Is this a preliminary to the merging of the 2 Departments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government, as part of its statement in 1983 on the reform of the Public Service, announced its intention to adopt a more active policy on the rotation of officers from one position of Secretary to another. In doing so, the Government recognised, as had the Coombs' Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, the Reid Committee of Review of Commonwealth Administration and the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the selection and development of senior managers, that the creativity and vitality of departments could be enhanced by the deliberate movement of staff at senior management levels. The transfers of the Secretaries of the Departments of Transport and Aviation were made in accordance with this policy.
(2) There is no current proposal to merge the Departments of Transport and Aviation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation: Reports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What reports has the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation prepared since 1980.
(2) Which of the reports have been released publicly.
(3) Have any reports not been released; if so, (a) why and (b) when will they be released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A complete list of reports and papers prepared by the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation (ARRDO) since 1980 is available. As the list is substantial, it has not been included, however I have provided the honourable member with a copy.
(2) The list provided for the honourable member outlines the public availability of ARRDO reports and papers.
(a) Some papers and reports are prepared for internal use and others are not publicly available for reasons of confidentiality.
(b) Except where prevented by the dictates of confidentiality, published papers and reports are generally made available upon request.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has it been proposed that the costs of printing and distributing Air Navigation Orders, regulations and amendments be recoverable from the aviation industry; if so, will his Department ensure that each amendment is sent only to those pilots and companies which are directly affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery rcommended that the costs incurred by Government in printing and distributing Air Navigation Orders and other publications should be recovered from the aviation industry. A draft plan has been developed, in consultation with industry and unions, to implement the recommendations of the Bosch Committee to recover the costs of regulatory services. The draft plan includes, inter alia, a proposal to recover the costs of printing and distributing Air Navigation Orders, Aeronautical Information Publications and other publications and amendments. Charges are not proposed for Airworthiness Advisory Circulars nor for the Aviation Safety Digest. The draft plan has not yet been considered by Government.

The Department of Aviation is currently reviewing the policy and procedures for the distribution of operational documents in order to rationalise the process and minimise the costs involved and hence required to be recovered from individuals and the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state in his reply to my question No. 1979 (Hansard, 30 November 1985, page 4087) on Soviet forces in Afghanistan that although Australia has condemned the Soviet invasion of that country time constraints did not permit a detailed discussion of Afghanistan.
(2) If so, what discussions on Afghanistan did occur.
(3) Will he now raise the issue with the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I did state that during my visit to Moscow in May 1984 I discussed with the then Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Gromyko, a broad range of bilateral, regional and international issues, including the crucial questions of nuclear disarmament. I also stated that time restraints did not permit a detailed discussion of Afghanistan.
(2) During my visit, however, I did state to the then Foreign Minister, Mr Gromyko, Australia's unambiguous condemnation of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.

(3) Australia's strong opposition to the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan and the continuing presence of Soviet troops in that country has been made clear in Moscow, Canberra and at multilateral forums. The Government, moreover, will continue to make similar representations to the Soviet authorities until the situation in Afghanistan is favourably resolved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports that in Kampuchea persons, suspected of resistance activity, are routinely tortured in detention by Vietnamese and Heng Samrin officials; if so, what representations has he made to the Vietnamese Government regarding this matter.
(2) If representations have not been made, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the paper entitled Human Rights in Kampuchea published by the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights in December 1984. A number of reports of torture in Cambodia were based on the Lawyers Committee paper.

(2) The Government has not made any representations to the Vietnamese Government on specific cases of human rights abuses in Cambodia. It has, however, made clear to the Vietnamese Government on a number of occasions, our concern that internationally recognised standards of human rights should be observed. When and if specific cases of human rights abuses are brought to the attention of this Government, they will be pursued in the most appropriate and constructive manner in accordance with the high priority the Government places on the promotion and protection of human rights.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports that during 1985, the Vietnamese and Heng Samrin regime greatly expanded forced labour defensive work projects in support of combat operations in western Cambodia; if so, what representations has he made to the Vietnamese Government regarding this matter.
(2) If representations have not been made, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following the 1984-85 Vietnamese dry-season offensive against Khmer resistance camps along the Thai-Cambodia border work began on the construction of a defensive barrier on the Cambodian side along parts of the border. The barrier is designed to limit the entry of Khmer resistance fighters, supplies and equipment into Cambodia.
Cambodian labourers are being conscripted, along with Vietnamese civilians in Cambodia and elements of the armed forces of Vietnam and the People's Republic of Kampuchea, to construct the barrier.

(2) The Government has not made specific representations to the Vietnamese Government regarding this conscription program. The Australian Government's views on human rights matters and on the need to seek a peaceful, comprehensive and durable settlement of the Cambodian dispute are well known to the Vietnamese Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports that there have been extensive transfers of resources from Kampuchea to Vietnam such as rice, fish, logs, maize and sesame; if so, what representations has he made to the Vietnamese Government regarding this matter.
(2) If representations have not been made, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am aware of reports that Cambodian primary produce is exported to Vietnam. We do not have adequate information on the level of trade or transfers to be able to make a judgment as to whether these activities are detrimental to the Cambodian economy or whether there is any reason to consider representations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say to what extent Vietnamese immigrants have been able to use their privileged status in Kampuchea to force Khmer out of desirable occupations of land.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen no firm evidence to support claims that Vietnamese immigrants have been able to force Khmer out of desirable occupations of land. The Government has been unable to find sufficient evidence to verify the proposition that Vietnam is pursuing a deliberate policy of migration to Cambodia or of changing the ethnic balance there. We accept, however, that some movement of ethnic Vietnamese into Cambodia has taken place in recent years. Our current assessment is that there are about 300,000 Vietnamese residents in Cambodia, many of whom would appear to have been resident in Cambodia prior to the Pol Pot years.

The Australian Government has made it clear to Vietnam and the ASEAN countries that we would be seriously concerned if allegations that Vietnam intended to change the population balance of Cambodia were substantiated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say to what extent Vietnamese personnel are involved in monitoring the Heng Samrin administration's internal security apparatus.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has no specific information on this matter. However, it is believed that Vietnamese advisers are present in most, if not all, ministries of the PRK administration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to reports that (a) the Vietnamese and Heng Samrin regime have systematically conscripted Khmer civilians from throughout Kampuchea for work on military related projects in or near combat areas along the Thai-Kampuchean border and (b) the Kampuchean workers have suffered frequent loss of life from mines and malaria and other diseases in the remote border areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) I am aware of reports of conscription of Cambodian labourers to help construct defences along sections of the Thai-Cambodia border; and (b) I am also aware of reports that there has been loss of life among these labourers for the reasons mentioned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether elections under the Heng Samrin administration of Kampuchea (a) do not allow genuine political participation but rather are staged by the regime to attempt to demonstrate legitimacy through voter activity and (b) underscore the relative status of leaders by varying percentages of the vote.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) I understand that elections for the PRK National Assembly took place in mid-1981 and that there have been at least two sets of country-wide local council elections since 1979. In all these elections only members of the Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Party (KPRP) have been permitted to stand as candidates. We have received reports that more than one KPRP candidate has contested a single seat. The limited information on the internal situation in Cambodia which is available to the Australian Government, however, does not permit me to make categorical statements about the conduct of elections there. The Australian Government's views on the importance of freedom of political expression are well known.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say to what extent major Kampuchean policies are controlled by Vietnam, and whether many day to day administrative decisions, especially in internal security matters, are made unilaterally by Vietnamese officials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has no detailed information as to the extent of Vietnamese control of major Cambodian policies and administrative decisions, including on internal security matters. It is believed, however, that Vietnamese advisers are present in most, if not all, ministries of the PRK administration.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cambodia: Military Supplies to Vietnamese Army

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Soviet Union shipped 50 tanks to Kampuchea in 1985 to strengthen Vietnamese units battling resistance forces; if so, what representations has he made to the Vietnamese Government regarding this matter.
(2) If representations have not been made, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of specific reports that the USSR shipped 50 tanks to Cambodia in 1985. We believe, however, that Soviet military equipment has been sent to Cambodia in recent years.

(2) The Government has not made any specific representations to the Vietnamese Government on this matter. However, we have condemned Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia and we have made known to the Vietnamese Government, on a number of occasions, Australia's concern at actions which may increase the level of military tension in the Indo-China region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether both Vietnam and the Heng Samrin Regime have rejected any change in the Kampuchean administration imposed following the Vietnamese invasion calling the situation irreversible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Vietnam and the Heng Samrin regime have frequently referred to the Cambodian situation as irreversible, but in other statements they have referred to the holding of free elections, excluding Pol Pot and his associates, after the achievement of a settlement in Cambodia. The concept of `irreversibility' appears to be intended to imply the rejection of a return to the pre-1979 situation rather than the rejection of the possibility of future change through elections.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Khmer Rouge: Position of Pol Pot

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether power continues to be held in the Khmer Rouge by the pre-1979 leadership although Pol Pot purportedly retired as military commander in 1985 and assumed a position of adviser on national security.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Khmer Rouge's pre-1979 leadership appears to continue to hold power, despite Pol Pot's announced change of office in August 1985, when he became Chairman of the Kampuchean Republic's Technical Office of National Defence. Khmer Rouge support for the view that Pol Pot retains a substantial level of influence was implicit in a statement made on 30 December 1985 by Khieu Samphan, Vice-President of the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea, to the effect that Pol Pot would cease all military or political activities in exchange for the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia by the end of 1986.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Membership of Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Party

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to indicate the size of the membership of the Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Party (KPRP) claimed, in its Fifth Congress Political Report of October 1985, to have a total membership of 7,500. Other observers' estimates have varied, with one academic authority suggesting a figure of 3,000. None of the estimates available to the government distinguishes between alternate and full-rights membership. The KPRP has a number of ancillary organisations: the People's Revolutionary Youth Union of Kampuchea, the Young Pioneers, the Youth Association and the Women's Association. It is possible that the discrepancies between the available figures on membership stem from a lack of precision about these membership categories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether authorities in the Hen Samrin regime have not permitted investigation of charges of human rights violations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that human rights organisations such as Amnesty International and the International Commission of Jurists have not been allowed access to Cambodia in the post-1979 period. I understand from media reports that the ``Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights'', which published a report in December 1984 entitled Human Rights in Kampuchea, was denied permission by the PRK authorities to visit Cambodia, and collected information for its report in refugee camps along the Thai-Cambodia border.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What has been the Australian financial commitment to the Kampuchean Humanitarian Assistance Program each year since its inception in 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of a program by that name, but it is possible that by this is meant the United Nations Border Relief Operation (UNBRO) which is co-ordinated by the Secretary General's Special Representative for Humanitarian Assistance to the Kampuchean People. Australian assistance to UNBRO and other humanitarian assistance agencies operating inside Cambodia since 1979 is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to reports that the Vietnamese occupation forces in Kampuchea are not allowing Kampuchean children to learn their own language; if so, what representations has he made to the appropriate Vietnamese officials regarding the destruction of Kampuchean culture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of reports to the effect that Vietnamese occupation forces in Cambodia are not allowing Cambodian children to learn their own language. The Government, however, is not convinced that these reports are correct. The reports of most western visitors to Cambodia in the past few years suggest that, while the Vietnamese language and a number of other foreign languages are available in the Cambodian school system, the Vietnamese language is not being taught at the exclusion of the Khmer language.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether there is a minimum age for the employment of children in Kampuchea, and what attention has been given by authorities to ensure acceptable conditions of work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there is no minimum age of employment in Cambodia. The PRK authorities do not appear, however, to condone the use of young children in the labour force. The PRK is attempting to establish compulsory six-year primary education for all Cambodian children.
The Government has no specific information as to the attention given by the PRK to ensuring acceptable working conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say to what extent the Vietnamese continue to attempt to integrate the economies of Laos and Kampuchea with that of Vietnam, particularly the exploitation of timber, rubber and fishing resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The limited information available to the Government on conditions inside Cambodia prevents a full assessment being made of the extent to which the Vietnamese may be attempting to integrate the economies of Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, particularly in respect of the exploitation of timber, rubber and fishing resources.

Economic co-operation between Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam was formalised at the Indo-Chinese Summit in Vientiane in 1983 and is believed to be structured around a series of interlocking bilateral agreements in various fields. To date, co-operation appears to have been directed primarily at developing an integrated infrastructure to facilitate trade, for example interlocking road systems. Recent evidence suggests that the pattern of trade between the Indo-Chinese states is basically one of an exchange of Cambodian and Lao primary products for Vietnamese machinery, construction materials and consumer goods.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department considering a request for aid from Dr Sathi Arafat, brother of Yasser Arafat, for the Palestinian Red Crescent Society.
(2) Will the aid granted be in the form of university training in Australia for doctors and various specialists.
(3) Is he able to say what other Governments have granted aid to the Society.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Department of Foreign Affairs is not aware of any current request for aid from Dr Arafat for the Red Crescent Society. In 1984 and 1985 eight Palestinian and Lebanese registered nurses employed by the Red Crescent Society and working in Middle East refugee camps received practical training in Australia in the fields of hospital and community health centre services and in methods for teaching health workers. This training was organised by the non-government aid organisation Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad, funded in part from Australia Government aid monies provided under the Bilateral-Non-Government Co-operation Program.
(3) I am unable to say what other governments have granted aid to the society.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: French Military Base in New Caledonia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether France is to develop a military base in New Caledonia.
(2) If so, when is such a base likely to be completed and what facilities is it likely to contain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In a statement on 25 April 1985 relating to the future of New Caledonia, the then French Prime Minister announced that the French military presence in Noumea would be reinforced, in order to guarantee French strategic interests in that part of the world.

(2) I am unable to say when the proposed reinforcement will be completed or exactly what facilities are envisaged. However in a recent essay on French foreign policy, President Mitterrand said that the base would provide docking facilities for French submarines, wharves for French warships and an airstrip for French supersonic aircraft.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What quarantine restrictions apply to the importation of uncanned pig meat into Australia.
(2) Have these restrictions been altered in any way since 1982.
(3) Did he meet representatives of the Australian pork industry early in 1986; if so, what assurances were given to producers in relation to quarantine provisions.
(4) What disease identified overseas constitute the main threat to pork production in Australia.
(5) Do the circumstances justify an easing of the current quarantine provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The importation of uncooked pigmeat and uncooked edible parts of pigs is currently prohibited under Quarantine Proclaimation No. 90A.

(2) This Proclamation has been in force since 1977 and is unchanged. I have however recently considered a change to the Proclamation and to some associated regulations to allow the entry into Australia of uncooked frozen pigmeat from Canada.

(3) Yes. On 22 January 1986 I met a delegation from the Australian Pork Producers Federation. Members of the delegation were advised that any decision to lift the prohibition on uncooked pigmeat from Canada would be based on the development of procedures for producing the pigmeat which would ensure that no disease risk would result from any importation. Given the above the restriction on importation could no longer be sustained on quarantine grounds and Australia has international obligations not to use quarantine as a trade barrier.

(4) The major diseases capable of affecting pork production which remain exotic to Australia are foot and mouth disease, Aujesky's disease, swine vesicular disease, swine fever and African swine fever. There are a number of lesser diseases of pigs which are also exotic to Australia.

(5) In examining the feasibility of importation from Canada, it is relevant to note that Canada is free from the major diseases exotic to Australia. The remaining diseases of concern are transmissible gastroenteritis (TGE) and trichinosis. The risk from trichinosis can be eliminated through freezing requirements included in appropriate importation conditions. Although no scientific evidence exists that TGE is transmitted in uncooked pigmeat, I have asked that Canadian authorities provide additional data on this possibility. My Department is awaiting the results of transmission trials currently being conducted by Agriculture Canada in Canada. On receipt of advice from Canada on the results of these trials I will be in a position to finalise a policy on possible future importation.

The possible risk of Aujeszky's disease (which occurs in USA) has been raised as a concern by industry, however this disease does not occur in Canada. Detailed procedures can be developed for import of Canadian pigmeat which will provide ample safeguards against the theoretical risk of Aujeszky's disease. It is not a disease which has any significant history of spread to pigs through pig meat, and the evidence is that the virus survives for a limited time in frozen pigmeat. At our meeting in May 1986, the Australian Pork Producers Federation conceded that this was not a validly sustainable objection.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action is being taken to provide accurate and up to date tourism statistics.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable member will be aware, the central statistical authority for the Commonwealth is the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) which is responsible to the Treasurer.

However I assume the honourable member's question relates specifically to ABS overseas arrivals statistics, which are based on data initially compiled by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) from information contained on international passenger cards which are completed by all passengers arriving from overseas.

I have made several representations to my colleague the Honourable Chris Hurford, MP, Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and his predecessor the Honourable Stewart West, MP, urging that high priority be assigned to this issue.
This matter has also been the subject of frequent communication between my Department and DIEA and ABS.
I am informed that the delay in publication of these statistics largely reflects the time taken by DIEA processing staff to manually transcribe passenger card information into computer format.

The resources available for this function are quite limited and it is a task which has also suffered from the incidence of repetition strain injury. The workload faced has also grown as a result of increased tourist arrivals.
In order to reduce the backlog, parts of the data entry workload have been contracted out but that has not been without difficulties.
In the longer term further automation allowing capture of most data from alternative sources should significantly improve data timeliness.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas on the one hand and the domestic airlines on the other would be affected by a decision on this matter. I believe that there is considerable merit in having an independent committee of inquiry investigating this matter, including the potential effects on traffic, and identifying options for consideration by the Government. For this reason the Government has decided that it will make a decision of the question of the restoration of Qantas' `interlining' rights following the report of the Economic Review of Domestic Aviation expected later this year.

With regard to the America's Cup defence, I understand that Qantas has in place plans to cater for the extra demand during the October 1986-February 1987 defence period. These arrangements involve two additional weekly B747 services to Perth from Sydney as extensions of the Company's US services, and up to six ad hoc B747 services to Perth from Sydney, connecting with flights from the US. The Company is ready to provide on a supplementary basis additional services between Singapore and Perth, if required. Qantas will also make ad hoc calls into Perth on its 13 weekly Europe services, as demand requires.

In conjunction with these services, the Company has developed marketing strategies to promote tourism to Western Australia for the Cup Defence. These include special promotional fares and tour packages to Perth, joint marketing and advertising campaigns with the Western Australian Government, and the establishment of a special liaison officer in Western Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no special arrangements or recognition for aviation contained in the Closer Economic Relations Treaty with New Zealand. However the Treaty recognises that the development of the relationship between Australia and New Zealand will be furthered by strengthening and fostering links and co-operation in such fields as inter alia, movement of people, tourism and transport. I am advised that the Closer Economic Relations Treaty is due for review in 1988 and that transport is one of the matters which will be considered in that review.

I am aware of the role that aviation policies have in fulfilling the objectives of the CER Agreement. I firmly believe that the arrangements by which trans-Tasman air services are developed and operate are within the overall intent and spirit of the CER Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

(2) How many persons have been convicted of making offensive or obscene phone calls.
(3) Why did Telecom decide not to reveal to the victim the identity of a person who is responsible for these phone calls.
(4) Will he take action to change this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The matter was highlighted in an article in the Melbourne Age of 1 April 1986. However, the case in question was not the subject of any action by the Director of Public Prosecutions at that time. (2) I am informed by Telecom that, in Victoria during the last twelve months, 11 persons have been convicted for making offensive or harassing telephone calls.

(3) For many years Telecom operated under the assumption that call-tracing consituted an interception under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and could only be disclosed by way of a prosecution of a person for making offensive or harassing telephone calls or in response to a subpoena.

Recent advice from the Attorney-General's Department indicates that under certain circumstances a call-trace will not constitute an interception within the meaning of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Telecom is acting upon this advice to provide details of the telephone service from which an alleged nuisance call was made where this will not infringe the Telecommunications (Interception) Act.

(4) As the honourable member is aware, the Telecommunications (Interception) Act comes within the Portfolio responsibility of the Attorney-General. I have asked the Attorney-General to review that part of the Act that prevents Telecom from providing this information to the victim of offensive or harassing telephone calls.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the bounty payments on certain steel products the only Commonwealth funds provided in the assistance to the steel industry package; if not, what other funds have been provided.
(2) What further funds are still to be provided.
(3) What has been the cost of assistance to the date of answering this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Commonwealth financial assistance to the steel industry under the Steel Industry Plan takes the form of bounties on certain steel products.

Complementing the Plan, the Steel Regions Assistance Program (SRAP) was implemented in 1983 to broaden the economic and employment base of the steel regions of the Illawarra and Hunter in NSW, and Whyalla in SA. Funding over five years was allocated to infrastructure projects in these regions. The program was specifically designed to:
* support the identified regional development strategies of the States and, accordingly, contribute directly towards regional economic development
* maximise its positive impact on the regional economy by utilising, where possible, locally sourced capital, material and labour inputs.

To ease the adjustment process for workers retrenched from the steel industry, the Labour Adjustment Training Arrangements (LATA) Program was made available to steel industry retrenchees in December 1982. In August 1983, LATA was extended to people retrenched from firms within the steel regions which supply goods or services to the steel industry, and the coal industry in NSW.

* LATA provides assistance to eligible persons to undertake training or re-training, with the objective of improving their employment prospects and assisting their adjustment from the retrenching firm or industry to other firms or industries, in another location if necessary.

Under the LATA Program retrenchees may be approved for more than one training course; the number of approvals of training in the steel and related industries in each of the periods set out below, is as follows:

(2) Under the Steel Industry Plan, scheduled to terminate on 31 December 1988, bounty payments to the steel industry have an annual ceiling of $71.6m (to be adjusted annually in accordance with movements in steel prices, if necessary). Under the Steel Regions Assistance Program the Government agreed to total funding of $100 million over the five year period.

(3) Actual payments of bounty from the commencement of the Steel Industry Plan on 1 January 1984 until the end of May 1986 have totalled $78.96m, made up of $6.07m under the Bounty (High Alloy Steel Products) Act 1983 and $72.89m under the Bounty (Steel Mill Products) Act 1983. To date, under the Steel Regions Assistance Program, projects to the value of $78.8m have been approved in NSW, while projects to the value of $4.1m have been approved in Whyalla. Since the funding of the LATA Program is not allocated on an industry specific basis no costing on individual industries assisted to date can be identified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the revised system of granting tariff preferences to developing countries to be introduced on 1 July 1986 mean that the effective rate of tariffs on canned pineapple will then be 5 per cent.
(2) Is this level of protection contrary to the level recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1981-82.
(3) Does the new tariff place Australian producers at a serious price disadvantage in the home market compared with imports from the Philippines and other developing countries.
(4) Will the Minister take steps to increase the general tariff rate on canned pineapple to 15 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries to be introduced on 1 July 1986 will result in the developing country rate of duty for canned pineapples reducing from 10 per cent to 5 per cent. As developing countries supply almost all of the imports (99 per cent in 1984-5) the developing country rate will be the rate of duty applying to most imports of canned pineapples.

(2) The level of assistance for canned pineapples recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1982 and generally accepted by the Government at that time was that the long term rate of duty be phased down to 10 per cent and that no concessional developing country rate be applied.

In taking its decision to introduce the new scheme, the Government was conscious that it would introduce new preferences where none existed under the current scheme. On the other hand, reduced margins of preference will now apply to some 790 items. Furthermore, the scheme establishes important new principles such as predictability, permanence, simplicity and broad coverage.

(3) The local canned pineapple industry supplies the bulk of the domestic market. The introduction of a preference margin is not of itself expected to seriously affect the competitiveness of the Australian canned pineapple industry. It must be borne in mind that local producers are successful exporters of canned pineapples indicating that they are in the main internationally competitive. Other factors such as the level of world pineapple supply relative to demand and movements in exchange rates are likely to also effect the competitiveness of imports on the domestic market.

(4) If the canned pineapple industry considers that it is being injured by imports from developing countries or any other source, and a case for assistance can be established, a reference on assistance arrangements appropriate to that industry will be sent to the Industries Assistance Commission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: John Peu and the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front Information Office

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether members of one of the radical Kanak organisations, Mr Jean Peu and Mr Yann Uregei, attended a meeting of terrorist organisations in Libya.
(2) Is he able to say which Kanak organisation Mr Peu represents and what its relationship is with the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front.
(3) Is he also able to say what assistance has been provided to Mr Peu by the ACTU and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights' Union during his residence in Australia.
(4) Under what conditions did the Government grant Mr Peu residence in Australia.
(5) Has the Government renewed a visa for Mr Peu; if so, what factors were considered in making the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr John Peu and Mr Yann Uregei attended a conference of liberation movements in Tripoli in March.
(2) Mr Peu is a member of FULK (Front Uni de Liberation Kanake), one of the constituent groups of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS).

(4) Mr Peu was nominated by the FLNKS to staff the FLNKS Information Office which was opened in July 1985. He was issued with a temporary residence visa to enable him to work in the Information Office.
As is the usual practice regarding the opening of such offices in Australia, the FLNKS Information Office is required to abide by the following conditions, namely:
(i) that the Information Office is established for the primary purpose of disseminating information;
(ii) that the office and its staff will not advocate violence as a means of achieving their political objectives;
(iii) that the office will have no privileged status and its staff will have no special standing and will be required to abide by Australian laws; and
(iv) that the office will not request or receive any financial assistance from the Australian Government.

(5) On 6 April 1986 the Government decided to decline a request by Mr Peu for renewal of his temporary residence visa. The Government's decision took into consideration that fact that the FLNKS had in effect itself suspended Mr Peu as its representative: a decision to suspend the operations of FLNKS `Foreign Ministry' was made by the FLNKS Political Bureau on 15 March 1986 in the light of projected travel to Libya by a number of FLNKS members, including Mr Peu.
The Government remains willing to consider nominations from the FLNKS leadership for an officer to staff its Information Office in Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force: Essential Services Contingency Plan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 2942 (Hansard, 8 April 1986, page 1845) concerning the former Australian Defence Force (ADF) contingency plan for situations arising out of industrial action in essential services, what was the plan called.
(2) When was the plan (a) drawn up and (b) cancelled.
(3) Who directed the ADF to draw up the plan.
(4) What was the definition of `essential services' in the plan.
(5) Did the plan envisage the use of armed force against strikers, pickets, union officials or offices; if so, (a) under what conditions and (b) on whose authority.
(6) Under what circumstances was the plan to come into effect and on whose authority.

(7) Did the plan envisage the replacement of absent workers by ADF personnel; if so, (a) in which industries and functions, (b) under what circumstances, (c) on whose authority and (d) which ADF units or types of unit were designated for the replacement function.
(8) What provision did the plan make for treatment and evacuation of killed and wounded (a) ADF personnel, (b) strikers, picketers and union officials and (c) innocent bystanders.
(9) If not provision was made, why not.
(10) Did the plan rely on promulgated guidelines for aid to the civil power; if not, on what guidelines did it rely.
(11) On what legal basis did the plan rest.
(12) Will he make public a copy of the former plan; if not why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) The plan was initiated in 1979 and development of the Plan was finalized in October 1982, (b) The plan was cancelled in January 1986.

(3) Development of the planning document was initiated by the military staff of the Department of Defence (Central Office) based on a perceived need to provide Government, in a short time scale, information on the ADF capabilities to respond to a crisis situation and ultimately to carry out Government directives.

(4) `Essential services' were not defined in the plan but the possible areas where Defence Force assistance could be required were listed in Annex A to the plan. The areas identified were transportation, fuel supply, communications, medical, garbage collection, fire services, electrical distribution systems, air traffic control, coal mining, storage and packaging, police, gas generation and distribution and water reticulation and sewage.
(5) No. The plan specifically prohibited the carrying of arms by ADF personnel and contained no implication of the use of force.
(6) On the direction of the Minister for Defence.

(7) The plan did envisage that ADF members could be required to perform tasks normally performed by civilian workers in the areas detailed at Annex A to the Plan and listed under part (4). The Government was the sole authority for determining the type and level of assistance to be provided by the ADF and the circumstances under which the plan was to be activated. No specific ADF units were designated for the replacement function but the plan identified employment categories which could be used to maintain essential services in the areas detailed at part (4).
(9) The plan was based on `no force' assistance by the ADF.

(10) The plan was developed to provide information to Government on ADF capabilities with the potential to assist in emergency situations. The plan uses a similar methodology to that used for defence force assistance to the civil community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What guidelines does his Department use in granting unemployment or sickness benefits to applicants who are out of work as a result of an accident at work.
(2) What is his Department's policy in dealing with workers' compensation claims and section 115 of the Social Security Act.
(3) Has the policy been changed in recent years.
(4) What is the (a) amount and (b) value of claims made in each of the last 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Where a person is unemployed as a result of an accident at work it is unlikely that unemployment benefit would be payable since the person must be able to undertake suitable work to qualify for such assistance. Where this condition is met, benefit may be paid if the person is unemployed, willing to undertake employment, is taking reasonable steps to obtain suitable employment, complies with the income test and is aged 16-64 (male) or 16-59 (female).
Sickness benefits may be granted if the person is temporarily incapacitated for work, has thereby suffered a loss of income and meets the income test and age qualifications specified above.

(2) Where sickness benefit is granted to a person who has a worker's compensation claim in respect of the same incapacity for which sickness benefit is paid, section 115B of the Social Security Act requires that sickness benefit be reduced by the amount of any periodic compensation payments received, and, where a lump sum settlement is made, the settlement is apportioned over time and any sickness benefit already paid is recovered in whole or part depending upon the particular circumstances. Sickness benefit is also reduced for the remainder of the period covered by the lump sum.

(3) The basic policy has not changed over recent years though the legislation was recast in 1982 when Division 3A, Part VII of the Social Security Act was introduced. This amendment improved the mechanics for recovery and removed the condition that recoveries could only be made where compensation and sickness benefit were paid for the same period. Similarly, the legislation passed by the Parliament in May this year provides a specified formula for apportioning lump sum payments over time and effectively precludes payment of sickness benefit for the period covered by a lump sum award.

(4) No separate statistics are maintained for persons having a worker's compensation claim who claim sickness benefit or the amount of sickness benefit paid in such cases. However, as at 2 May 1986 some 15.5 per cent of current sickness benefits were identified as either receiving or having an outstanding claim for some form of compensation such as workers' compensation or third party insurance. It is estimated that recoveries in 1985-86 will exceed $25 million.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that some delays are being experienced in processing income tax returns where credit is claimed in respect of deductions made under the Prescribed Payment System.

(2) The main factor contributing to the delays is credit mismatches, i.e. where there is a discrepancy between the amount of credit claimed by the taxpayer and the amount of credit recorded on the Taxation Office files. The Commissioner explained that the majority of mismatches are caused by errors or omissions by taxpayers or their agents. However, he did acknowledge that some mismatches result from procedural problems with his Office.
The Commissioner is presently reviewing procedures for dealing with these cases and expects to significantly reduce problems associated with mismatches.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many uniformed members of his Department are waiting for the settlement of a compensation claim.
(2) What is the average length of settlement of claims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 30 April 1986 there were 4,567 claims awaiting determination.
(2) The average time to determine a claim is approximately 38 weeks.
The following information is provided as an appreciation of the position:
(a) There is a considerable back log of undetermined claims due to a major loss of experienced staff on promotion outside the department over the past 15 months.

(b) Claims received from service personnel are generally complex. The main reasons being problems associated with the interpretation of the `on duty' aspects and in respect of those lodged many years after an injury/disease has occurred; these require intensive investigation.

(c) Considerable delays occur in obtaining satisfactory medical evidence to substantiate a claim. These delays occur where Medical Referees are required to provide an opinion in respect of an injury/disease that occurred many years previously and also where examination by the National Acoustic Laboratories is necessary.
(d) Claims from service personnel generally involve:
(1) Many that are unlikely to attract any entitlement.
(2) Conditions that may possibly require medical treatment at some time after discharge.
(3) Lump sum payment for a permanent disability.
(5) Dual eligibility under both the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act and the Repatriation Act.

(6) Cases where an entitlement exists under the Repatriation Act in respect of war/operational service. Action on claims lodged under the Compensation Act for the same condition have to be deferred until a decision is given under the Repatriation Act.
(7) Claims from dependants in respect of death.

Due to the number of outstanding claims it is necessary to set priorities with preference being given to those suffering financial hardship. Where hardship occurs, claims are determined in a matter of weeks, provided sufficient evidence is available.
It is not unusual for a member to submit up to 10 claims on discharge; such action further aggravates the position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he seek information concerning allegations that the Hopi and Navajo Indian people of Arizona, United States of America, are being threatened with forced eviction from their traditional lands.
(2) Should the investigations reveal apparent breaches of human rights, will he ensure that the matter is raised by Australian representatives in appropriate United Nations forums.
(3) Will he publicly advise the results of his investigations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1974 the United States Congress addressed a long-standing dispute between the Navajo and Hopi Indian people, involving 1.8 million acres of land in northern Arizona, through the passage of the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act which:
(i) ordered the surface of the land partitioned equally between the two tribes;
(ii) provided financial assistance for those people required to relocate; and
(iii) established the `Navajo and Hopi Indian Relocation Commission' under the Secretary of the Interior to assist with relocation.

I am informed that it was the intention of Congress that benefits to relocatees would be generous. The Settlement Act provides cash incentives and compensation for voluntary moves, improvements on the land being vacated, actual moving expenses, and replacement dwellings. With this in mind, the Commission submitted a relocation plan to Congress which became effective on 6 July 1981. Since the Act provided that relocation would take place in accordance with the Commission's plan, and be completed by the end of five years from its effective date, relocation of Navajo and Hopi Indians from land partitioned to the other tribe was to occur by 6 July 1986.

This legislative settlement, however, created a number of problems, especially for Navajo Indians residing on what was established as Hopi Land. The Courts of the United States, including the Supreme Court, and the legislative and executive branches of the Federal Government have all been involved in this question.

Although most Hopies have been resettled some 250 Navajo families, for various reasons, have refused to leave the land partitioned to the Hopi tribe. It is apparent that the 6 July deadline will not be met.

A Bill to minimise relocation of Navajo families from the Hopi partitioned lands was introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives in February 1986. It would provide for land exchanges between the two tribes, require the Navajos to pay the Hopis about $300 million in mineral royalties, and settle legal disputes between the tribes. The proposed legislation has not been well received by all those concerned and its future is uncertain.

At present, therefore, the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act is the law in the United States. It requires the partitioning of land and the relocation of Indian people. Only the Congress of the United States has the power to amend the law.
(2) and (3) My Department's preliminary investigation of the United States Legislation does not reveal any apparent breaches of human rights.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say what quantity of uranium has been mined at the Manyingee mine, W.A.
(2) Where is the uranium which has been mined located and under whose control is it.
(3) What is the extent of French ownership and control of the mine.
(4) What company owns the mine and which companies have direct or indirect financial interests in the mine.
(5) Is he able to say whether the uranium is mined at the site by a solution method.
(6) Has the Australian Atomic Energy Commission been critical of this form of mining; if so, what are the criticisms.
(7) Will the Government allow the export of any uranium which has been mined at this site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During trials to test an alkaline solution mining technique, which were conducted in 1985, a small amount of uranium (less than 500 kg) was leached from the ore body at Manyingee. These trials have now ceased.

(2) The material is stored at the test site in a storage facility which conforms with the physical protection requirements of the Australian Safeguards Office. The material is controlled by Total Mining Australia Pty Ltd, the operators of the joint venture exploring the prospect.

(3) and (4) I am advised the Manyingee prospect is covered by Exploration Licence EL 08-52, issued by the Western Australian Government. This licence is held by a joint venture comprising Total Mining Australia Pty Ltd (80 per cent interest), Elf Aquitane Triako Mines (10 per cent) and Urangesellschaft Australia (10 per cent). The venture is therefore 90% owned by French controlled interests.

(6) The AAEC has made no specific comments on the Manyingee proposal nor has it made any general criticism of solution mining. It considers that this form of mining can have advantages over mining techniques in appropriate situations. The advantages or disadvantages are both site and operation specific.

(7) The Government's uranium policy permits the mining and export of uranium only from the Ranger, Nabarlek and Olympic Dam mines. The Government will not permit the export of uranium mined at Manyingee and Total Mining Australia Pty Ltd is aware of this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Five contracts directly related to construction or alteration of airports and five contracts dealing with airport management assistance, technical training, specifications and studies were let in the period, all to Australian companies.
(2) (i) ACCA (Airport Consulting and Construction Australia Pty Ltd):
Bangladesh-Kurmitola International Airport Airline Complex, Dhaka.
Vanuatu-Bauerfield Airport Upgrading Study. Upgrading of Bauerfield Airport.
Bangladesh-Management Assistance Program and Technical Apprentice Training Program for Biman
(v) Trippett, Allan and Associates Pty Ltd
Malaysia-Malaysian Air Traffic Services Facilities Implementation. Surveillance Radar Specification for Kuching Airport.
Nepal-Transfer of Airways Facilities at Kathmandu International Airport
(4) Yes, it is affiliated with MacDonald Wagner Pty Ltd.

The Factory was handed over in operational condition to the Tongan authorities in December 1985.

ACCA also has a good track record on projects conducted on ADAB's behalf. In the particular case of selection of consultants for the Fua'amotu airport project, the technical advisory panel rated ACCA ahead of other proposals by a clear margin.

These representatives are drawn from both the public and private sectors as well as a representative from the Appraisal, Sectoral Studies and Evaluation Branch of ADAB. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

(2) What organisations were contracted to carry out this work.
(3) What were the specific individual matters investigated by these organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The $165,000 for studies associated with the implementation of separate airport and airway charges outlined in the Explanations for Additional Estimates of Expenditure for the Department of Aviation in 1985-86, is comprised of two elements: $100,000 for detailed design and programming of the Separate Charges Computer System and $65,000 for data processing utilising Bureau services. The additional funds for design and programming were required firstly because the successful tender price ($338,000) exceeded the original estimated cost ($300,000) and secondly, to cover changes to the system's initial design which have arisen during the course of consultations with the aviation industry. A decision was made to contract out the data processing for the system and funds were sought to cover data processing during trial running of the system for a period in 1985-86. These funds were offset by corresponding reduction in the relevant part of the Department's salaries requirements.
(2) Computer People Pty Ltd were contracted to undertake the computer system design and programming work. Keydata Pty Ltd was contracted to undertake the data processing work.

(3) Computer People developed a detailed design for the Separate Charges computer system and undertook the associated system programming and implementation work. Keydata prepared flight data in an electronic form (tape) from manually recorded flight information for use in trialling of the Separate Charges computer system.
