QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What facilities exist at the State and federal level to control and test the consumer safety and health risk aspects of imported products.
(2) What duplication of testing procedures exist at either the State or federal level.
(3) What right does the Federal Government have to override an approval given by a State, should a product be considered to be unsafe by a federal consumer authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The range and type of product being imported into Australia varies greatly and the responsibility for the control and testing of these products rests with different areas of government. Within each of these areas, there have been established relevant legislative and administrative systems to facilitate the control of any unsafe product, including testing of products where necessary.

By way of example, responsibility for the identification of potentially hazardous health-related products rests with the Commonwealth Department of Health and relevant State Health authorities; air transport products are the responsibility of the Commonwealth Department of Aviation; products relating to road transport are the responsibility of the State transport authorities but action is co-ordinated through the Common wealth Department of Transport; electrical products are controlled and tested by relevant State and Territory authorities; firearm control is essentially a matter for relevant Police Forces; and other consumer products are the responsibility of the Attorney-General's Department at the federal level and consumer affairs agencies at the State level.

There is no single administrative organisation with sole responsibility for control and testing of imported products. If it is considered that legislative action should be taken against particular unsafe goods at the Commonwealth level, controls can be invoked under:

The enforcement of any such controls would be primarily a matter for the Australian Customs Service, the Commonwealth Department of Health, relevant quarantine authorities and the Trade Practices Commission respectively. Testing of goods for compliance with controls would generally be undertaken by appropriate independent technical experts such as the Australian Government Analytical Laboratory, State Government laboratories, Australian Federal Police, etc. Lines of communication have been established within and between relevant authorities to ensure that action to control and test imported products is co-ordinated.

(2) Commonwealth and State authorities have established communication procedures to ensure unnecessay duplication is kept to a minimum. In some instances, differences in legislative requirements may result in duplication of testing to ensure compliance with different State limits.

(3) The product safety provisions of the Trade Practices Act can be used to prohibit the supply of unsafe goods or to establish mandatory product safety or information standards. From 1 July 1986, the Act will provide the Attorney-General with the power to require mandatory recall of unsafe goods. Actions taken under these provisions apply throughout Australia. To such extent that any provisions of State and Territory law are inconsistent with actions taken under the Trade Practices Act, the Commonwealth law would prevail.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Federal Government assistance is available to (a) individual small businesses and (b) small business organisations in terms of (i) direct financial help, (ii) managerial or administrative advice, (iii) domestic and export marketing assistance, (iv) subsidy towards labour costs and employee training, and (v) pioneering new products.
(2) Has consideration been given to the establishment of a small business bank; if so, what action has been taken.
(3) What special role does the Development Bank play in providing finance to small business.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth and States are co-operating in a national program of assistance to small businesses, with States providing direct assistance and the Commonwealth responsible for support services and co-ordination.

Under this arrangement, the State Governments, through their Small Business Agencies and Corporations, provide a range of services for small business including counselling, referrals, general advice and, in certain circumstances, financial assistance.
As a general rule, the Commonwealth does not provide direct financial assistance to industry or small business. This is regarded as a matter for the banks and financial institutions.

However, in certain instances the Commonwealth does provide finance for small business under the Management and Investment Companies (MIC) Program which was introduced in early 1984. The main objectives of the program are:
-to encourage the development of the venture capital market in Australia

-to attract management and financial support for the start-up and early growth of Australian-based enterprises which generally have the potential to grow rapidly into substantial businesses, are export-oriented and use innovative technology; the Management and Investment Companies Licencing Board has so far licensed 11 MICs.

In the area of small business management education and training the Commonwealth is keen to see a major drive to reduce small business failure rates by improving the managerial skills of small business owners. A national strategy for small business management education and training is currently being considered by Ministers and we will be seeking its implementation as soon as possible. In the near future we hope to implement a National Small Business Management Program in conjunction with the States, to encourage small business owners to develop their management skills.

To assist small firms in various aspects of operating a small business the Commonwealth Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has produced a wide range of management training materials, including a series of booklets on `Managing a Small Business'.

Initiatives have been taken to assist marketing activities by local firms both in Australia and overseas. The Export Market Development Grants Scheme has been modified to ensure its cost effectiveness and to target funds towards assisting smaller firms. Separate export assistance arrangements have been made for the tourist industry, a major area of small business operations. Commonwealth purchasing arrangements have been reviewed to provide more effective preference for local industry in Commonwealth purchasing.
From July 1985, the Federal Government has, in conjunction with the State Governments, progressively established the pilot New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) in all States.

The Scheme provides a comprehensive package of training, establishment capital, income support for 12 months, and business counselling for 600 eligible partici- pants. The Commonwealth is responsible for the income support element, which is broadly equivalent to Unemployment Benefit, as well as the training element which is in the form of full-time institutionalised training in small business management skills undertaken before the commencement of the business.

Under the auspices of the National Training Council, a network of Industry Training Committees has been established covering some 80 per cent of the private sector workforce, the majority of which are employed in small businesses.

Industry Training Committees are partly funded by the Government and aim to promote and develop systematic training on an industry basis and give industries a channel they can use to advise the Government, through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, on labour force and training matters.

In recognition of the importance of training for small business owner/managers, the National Training Council established a Small Business Management Development Standing Committee in 1979 to stimulate awareness of the need for management training among small business owner/managers and intenders. The Standing Committee also facilitates communication on small business management development issues and provides advice for the National Training Council on policies, programs and priorities to meet small business management development needs.

Small businesses have been significant participants in the various wage subsidy programs which have been administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. In 1985-86 it is estimated that the number of private sector placements under these programs will be around 70,000. The new JOBSTART wage subsidy program, which was introduced on 2 December 1985 and subsumed a range of former wage subsidy programs, has maintained this pattern. The program offers wage subsidies to employers as an incentive for them to engage long-term unemployed or especially disadvantaged job seekers. Recent information is not available, but past surveys indicate that 50 per cent of participating employers had a workforce of 7 or less, 85 per cent had 60 or less and 90 per cent had 100 or less.

Under the Adult Training Program, assistance may be provided to small or other businesses under the National Skills Shortages component. Assistance is provided on an industry basis through special packages. The Heavy Engineering Adjustment and Development Program announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, will provide considerable assistance to small businesses in this industry. This will include skills enhancement retraining and relocation assistance for elements of the work force in the industry.

Another component of the Adult Training Program, that geared to meet local labour market shortages, is anticipated to provide training to more than 2,000 unemployed persons in the six months ended 30 June 1986. This will meet the needs of various employers including some small businesses where there has been difficulty in filling vacancies.

The Commonwealth is actively encouraging the development of technology oriented small firms and of the use by small firms of technological developments. There are a number of Commonwealth and State Government industry development measures to encourage pioneering of new products. These include grants for industrial research and development and encouragement to venture capital companies and financial and other assistance for enterprises developing new technology.

In answer to the second part of the honourable member's question we are not aware of any proposal to establish a small business bank. The Government's deregulation of the banking sector and the issuing of new banking licences is expected to lead to a much more competitive banking sector more attuned to customer needs and a change in focus away from security lending towards cash flow lending.

The Commonwealth Development Bank (CDB) provides finance for the establishment or development of business undertakings, particularly small undertakings, where finance is not available on suitable terms and conditions from other institutions. It is mainly concerned with the enterprise becoming or continuing to be successful and does not place the same emphasis as the banking industry on the value of the security available. All major trading banks are agents for the CDB.

In May 1985 the CDB Act was amended to extend and clarify the CDB's charter as a lender of `last resort' to small business and make provision for equity finance. These amendments reflect a recommendation of the Martin Group which saw a lending role for the CDB in a deregulated environment which would provide greater attention to borrowers' income flow prospects.

Figures as at June 1985 show the CDB as a net lender of $3 billion to 285,000 applicants since 1960. The ratio of small business to rural loan approvals has been 1:3 but in 1984-85 reflected a significantly increased trend in lending patterns to the small business sector. As at 1 March 1986 over $100 million had been loaned to small business-exceeding rural term loans for the first time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What Federal assistance is given (a) directly, (b) throught the States and (c) through community/non-profit organisations, to persons who require access to medical aids (for example, wheelchairs, renal dialysis machines, artificial limbs, hearing aids, spectacles and AME 2 home treatment units).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Department of Veterans' Affairs directly assists eligible Repatriation beneficiaries who require medical aids. These aids are provided through the Repatriation Hospital system, Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres and other Departmental facilities. The Department of Veterans' Affairs also meets the costs of treatment provided through the Local Medical Officer and Local Dental Officer Schemes, optometrical arrangements, etc. Beneficiaries who require hearing aids are supplied through the National Acoustics Laboratories.
The Department of Veterans' Affairs administers the Free Limbs Scheme which meets the cost of artificial limbs for Australians who need them.

Community patients treated in Repatriation hospitals are provided with those aids which normally would be available if the treatment were provided in a State public hospital. For example, home renal dialysis machines are provided on loan for patients who require them.

(b) No assistance in providing medical aids is given through the States but the Department of Veterans' Affairs meets the costs of approved treatment, including medical aids, provided by State hospitals for entitled Repatriation beneficiaries.

(c) No assistance in providing medical aid is given through non-profit organisations, but the cost of talking books and machines for eligible Repatriation beneficiaries provided by the Royal Blind Society of Victoria are met by the Department. The Department also meets the costs for guide dogs and training provided through the National Guide Dog and Mobility Training Centre.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Prior to the decision to introduce unleaded petrol in Australia what studies were carried out by federal and State authorities into the possible negative effects of this decision.
(2) What consideration was given to problems being experienced in other countries due to the emission of hydrogen sulphide gas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the late 1970s the need for more stringent motor vehicle emission controls was considered by two national Councils: the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) and the Australian Environment Council (AEC).

In July 1979 ATAC requested its Committee on Motor Vehicle Emissions (COMVE) to report on an effective long term national motor vehicle emissions strategy to achieve reductions in motor vehicle emissions. COMVE membership comprised relevant Federal and State environment, energy and transport authorities, representatives of the automobile and oil industries and, on behalf of consumers, the Australian Automobile Association (AAA). COMVE's study primarily involved a comparison of leaded and unleaded petrol strategies and it reported to ATAC in February 1980 that the unleaded petrol approach would be the best strategy to achieve health and environmental objectives in terms of energy conservation and overall cost. Further detailed assessments by COMVE confirmed this conclusion.
The Vehicle Emissions and Noise Standards Advisory Committee of the AEC independently assessed emission control options and arrived at similar conclusions favouring the unleaded petrol strategy.

In 1981, State and Commonwealth governments agreed to require all passenger vehicles manufactured from 1 January 1986 to be designed to operate on unleaded petrol and to comply with more stringent emission standards. The long lead-time was provided to allow the petroleum and motor vehicle industries to carry out development to meet the new requirements.

(2) COMVE's final report to ATAC reflected, inter alia, the conclusions from a study team comprising commonwealth officers and representatives of the oil and automobile industries, and from the AAA, which visited a number of other countries to investigate relevant issues. I am advised that at no time during discussions with authorities and experts in the United States and Japan was the question raised of hydrogen sulphide emissions from vehicles equipped with exhaust catalyst technology.

The COMVE report on the development of a long-term national motor vehicle emissions strategy, published in February 1981, contains no reference to potential problems attributable to emissions of hydrogen sulphide gas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do `aftermarket' exhaust systems pose significantly greater noise pollution problems than standard exhausts supplied with new motorcycles and genuine replacement parts provided by dealers; if so, has his Department considered emphasising the controls and standards for noise levels associated with these aftermarket exhaust systems, rather than original equipment.
(2) Does he intend to drop or implement the proposed Australian Design Rule `ADR N-1'.

(3) What steps has he taken to make aftermarket exhaust systems for motorcycles subject to the standards of the Australian Design Rules for the purpose of controlling noise emission pollution; if no steps have been taken, why not.

(4) What consultation with the motorycycle industry, including manufactuerers, dealers and owner-riders, does he and his Department have in formulating proposals for Australian Design Rules and other issues which concern these people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that aftermarket exhaust systems can pose significantly greater noise pollution problems than new standard exhausts and genuine replacement systems; yes.

(2) The draft Australian Design Rule (ADR) N1 has been withdrawn. A new draft ADR, based upon international standards, is now being considered by the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) and the Australian Environment Council (AEC).

(3) The proposed new ADR will require manufacturers to include noise test information on a label attached to the motorcycle. This will help noise enforcement authorities better control noisy motorcycles and aftermarket exhaust systems.
(4) There are detailed consultations between authorities, industry and user group bodies in the formulation of ADRs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Government Statement on Economic and Rural Policy: Corporate Plan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What time span will be covered by his Department's Corporate Plan referred to on page 1 of the April 1986 Government statement of economic and rural policy.
(2) Will the Corporate Plan be updated annually; if not, at what period of time is it intended to revise the plan.
(3) When does he expect (a) the first Corporate Plan to be completed and (b) to make his first progress report to Parliament.
(4) Can the primary industry statutory authorites which are required to produce their own 5 year corporate plans do so before knowing the content of his Department's Corporate Plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) the Department of Primary Industry Corporate Plan will cover a medium term period, of about 3-5 years, in the first instance from mid 1986. It will be reviewed annually and updated when appropriate, to reflect prevailing economic and rural conditions, and the Government's economic and rural policies. Its focus and priorities will fully support the Government's intention, as outlined in the April 1986 Economic and Rural Policy Statement, to provide a basis for a more cohesive approach to rural problems across the community as a whole and to lay the foundations for a continuing long-term rural contribution to Australian economic growth.
(3) (a) and (b) I expect the first Corporate Plan to be completed early in the 1986-87 financial year and that I will first report progress to the Parliament in the budget sittings in 1986.

(4) Yes. Primary industry statutory authorities operate independently of my Department and are certainly able to develop for themselves the corporate plans required by their enabling legislation. The authorities and my Department do, however, consult regularly on all appropriate matters, and are aware of the strategies and priorities affecting each other's activities. All matters of Government policy or Departmental planning that may relate to or affect the authorities are made known to them at the time and do not need to await the formal publication of the Department's Corporate Plan.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Research: Cattle Tick Vaccine and Eye Cancer

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds have been provided to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation for research in relation to the vaccine it has been developing for the control and eradication of cattle ticks.
(2) What further funds would be required to enable the vaccine to be marketed.
(3) Are funds to be allocated to the CSIRO for further research in relation to the vaccine; if not, why are they to be discontinued.

(4) Could the results of CSIRO research into a cattle tick vaccine, if carried to completion, be adopted for the control of many other parasites of live-stock such as astertagia, screw worm and sheep blowfly.
(5) Are funds for eye cancer research in cattle to be allocated in the next funding period; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Up to the present, funds have been provided from CSIRO's Appropriation, the Australian Meat Research Committee (AMRC), now succeeded by the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC), and the National Biotechnology Program Research Grants Scheme. The following funds were provided in 1985/86:
A private firm is collaborating with CSIRO and is also in receipt of research funds from the National Biotechnology Program Research Grants Scheme.
(2) CSIRO estimates that for the vaccine to be taken to the marketing stage the following total funds will be required:

(3) It is expected that Appropriation funds will continue to be allocated at the current level. AMLRDC has indicated it will withdraw support from the end of 1985-86. The reason given is a change of priorities in AMLRDC away from animal production research to processing and marketing research. The National Biotechnology Program Research Grant terminates at the end of calendar year 1986. A new three-year research proposal has been submitted to the National Biotechnology Program. If successful, this will largely compensate for the loss of AMLRDC funding.

When the stage of process development and field testing of the vaccine is reached, the firm collaborating with CSIRO will be expected to make a significant contribution to the costs of these activities. The Australian market for a cattle tick vaccine is estimated to be $30 million annually. Overseas markets would be at least three to four-fold greater.

(4) CSIRO believes that the principle of using `concealed' antigens, which is the basis for the cattle tick vaccine, could be applied to the development of vaccines against other parasitic diseases of livestock. CSIRO has already commenced research into a vaccine against sheep blowfly applying methods developed during the cattle tick research. The blowfly research is supported by a private endowment.
(5) CSIRO is not carrying out research on eye cancer in cattle. This is done by the University of Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The alteration of tender specifications is of itself uncommon, and the promulgation of such changes by telegram/telex is only utilised in exceptional circumstances, particularly where the closing time is imminent. The cost of issuing specification amendments by telegram/telex is negligible given their usage in isolated cases, and cannot be identified from the overall cost of the telegram/telex system.

(2) Where a prospective tenderer is advised of a tender specification alteration by telegram/telex, normal practice would require the subsequent issue of written confirmation of the amendment forwarded through the mail.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Telephone Concessions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

(2) Is he aware of any abuse of the system and are no concessions applied to telephone connections used in business enterprises.
(3) Does his Department reconcile its records of concession payments with Telecom records for private or business telephones.
(4) What procedures are used by his Department to ensure there is no abuse of the system.

(5) Has his Department, or any department, undertaken a recent review, investigation or program development to ensure that benefits are only paid to those entitled; if so, what was (a) the nature of the work undertaken and (b) the result.
(6) Is it proposed to adjust the controls on this concession.
(7) If investigations have revealed abuse of the concession, does this indicate that his Department is also unable to check accurately income declarations provided by pension beneficiaries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) A telephone rental concession is paid, on application, to pensioners and sickness beneficiaries who are eligible for fringe benefits (as determined under the Social Security Act) and who satisfy a household income test (as specified by a Determination pursuant to the Telecommunications Act).

All but a few of the telephone rental concessions are allowed in respect of private telephones. The exceptions relate to `business' telephones, for which the concession recipients are required to satisfy the abovementioned eligibility criteria.
I am not aware of any abuse of the system.

(3) Under current procedures Telecom submits monthly claims to the Department of Social Security for reimbursement of the concession. The fringe benefits status of the clients covered by the claims are checked using a statistical sampling methodology. My Department subsequently liaises with Telecom if any adjustments to the reimbursement claim are required.

(4) As well as the same reconciliation of payment claims, my Department checks and advises Telecom on the fringe beneficiary status of each applicant for the concession; and advises Telecom whenever a pensioner who has a telephone number loses fringe benefits or pension entitlement, or changes his/her telephone number.

(5) and (6) An Inter-Deparmental Working Party (with representation from Telecom and the Departments of Communications, Veterans' Affairs and Social Security) recently undertook a review to develop a more cost-effective means of administering the concession. The Government is currently considering the matter.
(7) As stated in (2) above, I am not aware of any abuse of the system.
The checking of (household) income declarations is a responsibility of Telecom, by virtue of the abovementioned Determination pursuant to the Telecommunications Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 23 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been made to rationalise the wide range of income payments to young people identified in the Social Welfare Secretariat's February 1984 report `Income Security for Young People'.
(2) What is the gap between TEAS allowance and unemployment benefit (a) now and (b) as at 1 March 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government undertook in 1985, a fundamental review of income support arrangements for young people, including the three general student assistance schemes-Secondary Allowances Scheme, Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme. As a result these schemes will be replaced from 1 January, 1987 by an age-related scheme with differential rates of allowances for 16-17 year olds and those aged 18 and over. Within each of these age groupings, the rates for secondary students will move progressively towards the corresponding rate for tertiary students until they are the same. This point will be reached in 1988 in the case of 16-17 year olds and in 1989 for the older age group.

In terms of actual rates, secondary students in 1987 will receive maximum allowances of $40 at ages 16-17 and $45 if aged 18 or more; for tertiary and adult secondary students, maximum rates will be $50 (at home) $73.28 (away/independent) for 16-17 year olds and $55.80 for 18+ year olds.
Education allowances will also be brought to a position of parity with unemployment benefit rates. Thus:
from 1988, the rates of allowances for 16-17 year old students will be the same as for 16-17 year old unemployment beneficiaries
from 1988, the rates for students 18 years of age or older living away from home or independently will be set at the same level as unemployment benefits for 18-20 year olds
from 1989, the rates for secondary and tertiary students 18 years of age or older living at home will be set and maintained at 63 per cent of the away from home rate for this age group.

These rate changes will remove the financial disincentives which currently discourage young people from low income families from continuing with, or returning to, education and training. Moreover, the rates of allowances will thereafter be indexed to ensure that they remain aligned and that their real value at least is maintained.

The family income threshold level, i.e., the family income level at which the education allowances begin to be reduced, will itself be indexed annually to ensure that there is no drop in the proportion of students qualifying for allowances under the income test provisions.

The Government has also rationalised from the beginning of this year the payments made under the Training Allowances administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Special schemes of student assistance including assistance for isolated children and the schemes assisting Aboriginal students have been examined by the Task Force on Youth Allowance Administration to advise on the extent to which they can be rationalised with the new allowance structure.
(2) The weekly rates of TEAS and unemployment benefits for recipients without dependants are:
Note: Figures for 1988 unemployment benefit to those under 18 are illustrative estimates only. The actual benefit will depend on indexation adjustment in the light of price movements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether a number of sacked South East Queensland Electricity Board (SEQEB) workers have stated that it is their intention to remain on unemployment benefit until they are reinstated by SEQEB.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the statements of the Queensland government and SEQEB that these workers will not be reinstated.
(3) Will he investigate these matters and give an assurance that these workers are only receiving unemployment benefit following a proper application of the work test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) I am unaware of the statement referred to in Part (1) but am aware of the statements referred to in Part (2). It should be understood that unemployment benefit may be paid only if a person satisfies the provisions of the Social Security Act. These include that the person is capable of undertaking, and is willing to undertake suitable paid work. In addition, the person must have taken reasonable steps to obtain such work. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was he aware of the Commissioner for Taxation's intention to distribute a `Guide for Employers' concerning the fringe benefits tax prior to the legislation being passed by Parliament; if so, does he approve of this action.
(2) How many copies were (a) printed and (b) posted.
(3) What was the cost of (a) printing and (b) postage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I was aware of the intention of the Commissioner of Taxation to distribute the booklet `Fringe Benefits Tax: a guide for employers' prior to the legislation being passed by Parliament.

The Commissioner advised me that faced with the short time-frame likely between the passage of the legislation and the 1 July 1986 commencement date of the new system, he felt it incumbent on him, as a responsible administrator, to give employers details of the proposed tax at the earliest opportunity. As a result, he authorised the issue of the booklet with the express caveat that it had been prepared in advance of the legislation being passed by the Parliament.

To have delayed publication until after the law had been enacted would, he considered, have been to fail in his responsibilities to employers and others affected. It would have undoubtedly given rise to large numbers of complaints that employers should have been given more time to be made fully aware of what is expected of them, to introduce systems changes and to prepare generally for the proposed new tax.

(2) The Commissioner has advised me that 750,000 copies of the booklet were printed and 440,771 copies were posted to employers. The balance have been distributed to Taxation Offices and copies are available to members of the public, upon request.

(3) The cost of printing the booklets was $180,565.66 and the cost of postage was $170,949.06. Other costs associated with the mailing of the booklets included envelopes ($10,417.23), packaging ($9,586.77), the circular to employers ($5,824), and the Request for Information form ($5,277). This resulted in a total cost of $382,619.72.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to state what scope there is for the application of Australian scientific research and technology in India.
(2) What steps have been taken to develop closer scientific links with India.
(3) What is the extent of the scientific co-operation between the two countries.
(4) Has Australia yet to fully develop its scientific links with India.
(5) Will he consider leading a delegation to India to enhance scientific and technological links.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes I believe there is considerable scope for the application of Australian science and technology in India. There are several factors which point to this. For example there are many geological similarities. India, Australia and Antarctica were once contiguous in the super continent Gondwana Land. This is significant in relation to the mineral potential of the continents and the petroleum potential of the margins to mention just a couple. Additionally Australia and India share a common ocean which has major implications in areas such as fisheries and meteorology.
The similarities augur well for the application of Australian science and technology.

(2) Several steps have been taken over recent months to develop closer scientific links with India. In November last year, Australia took the initiative in forwarding to the Indian authorities a major research proposal in each of the fields of geoscience, meteorology and space science. We invited the Indian authorities to identify which of the three proposals was of greatest interest to them and in which they would wish to enter into a co-operative research effort. Additionally, as part of a broad thrust to improve science and technology links with India, my Department has invited a delegation of Indian scientists to Australia to look at what opportunities may exist. That delegation is to visit Australia for two weeks from the 10th of July this year.

(3) Australia has had a science and technology agreement with India since 1975 but most of our exchanges since then have been in agriculture and through various aid schemes. Australia has had interactions with India in scientific and technological fields over many years. For the most part these exchanges have been individual scientists working within government laboratories and universities.

(4) I confirm that Australia has yet to fully develop its scientific links with India. Indeed moves are afoot to strengthen those linkages. India has many sophisticated elements in its economy and technological infrastructure. Its major research organisation the CSIR (Council for Scientific and Industrial Research) resembles our CSIRO in some areas. Indian universities have done well in basic research, producing three Nobel Prize winners in science, less well in industrial applications.

(5) I am grateful for the Member for Hawker's interest in my leading a delegation to India to enhance scientific and technological links, however I consider it more appropriate for the senior officers of my Department to lead such delegations. Keeping in mind the proposed visit to Australia of an Indian scientific delegation (which includes some very senior scientists indeed) it is proposed that Australia sends a similar senior scientific delegation to India in August or September this year.

(7) What is the term of Mr Delaney's appointment as director of the `Drug Offensive'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The position of Campaign Manager for the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse is a senior administrative position and forms part of the Senior Executive Service within the Public Service. Mr Delaney was selected for the position as he was the most suitable applicant having regard to his broad administrative and other relevant experience, his academic qualifications and his personal skills and abilities.
(3) I am advised by Mr Delaney that he has never been employed as a restaurant commentator for a Canberra commercial radio station.

(4) All Senior Executive Service positions are advertised in the national press and notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The position of Campaign manager for the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse was advertised on 11 January 1986. There were eight applicants for the position who were assessed by a selection committee against selection criteria. The selection committee consisted of a Deputy Secretary from my Department and two very senior officers from other departments. It was approved by the Public Service Board. Mr Delaney was ranked as the most suitable applicant and was recommended to the Public Service Board for promotion to the position. The Public Service Board confirmed Mr Delaney's promotion within the Senior Executive Service of the Australian Public Service.
(6) Yes. In the national press on 11 January 1986.

(7) Mr Delaney is a permanent officer of the Public Service. However, the Secretary of my Department may deploy staff to ensure the most effective and efficient use of human resources and it is this management of resources that will determine the period Mr Delaney heads the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to state what progress has been made in the implementation of UN Resolution 2832 (xxvi) concerning the convening of an international conference on the establishment of an Indian Ocean Zone of Peace.
(2) Is he also able to state if it is still the case that no Indian Ocean State has opposed the Zone of Peace concept.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean continues its work in preparation for a Conference on the Indian Ocean at Colombo `as a necessary step for the implementation of the Declaration of the Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace, adopted in 1971'. So far the Committee has been unable to complete preparatory work for the Conference. The fortieth General Assembly adopted resolution 40/153, which asks the Committee to complete the preparatory work and provides for the opening of the Conference at Colombo not later than 1988.
(2) No Indian Ocean State opposes the idea of an Indian Ocean Zone of Peace. Indicative of this is the fact that Resolution 40/153 was adopted by consensus.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken as a result of the report of the Australian Agricultural Council working party's report on ways of improving the legislative backing, financial structure and management of co-operatives?
(2) How does the Government propose to support co-operatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Standing Committee of the Australian Agricultural Council agreed to the establishment in February 1985 of a Working Party to undertake a Study of Agricultural Co-operatives with the following terms of reference:
(a) to identify the size and significance of the agricultural co-operative sector within Australia;
(b) to review the legislative, financial and management structure of co-operatives;
(c) to identify impediments to the successful operation of co-operatives, and to make recommendations on the appropriate changes needed.
The Working Party has not yet completed its task, but it is anticipated that the Working Party will present a Progress Report to the Standing Committee's July 1986 meeting.

(2) Legislative responsibility for co-operatives lies within the jurisdiction of State Governments and any policy changes will require co-ordination and consultation between the States and Commonwealth. It would be prudent for the Commonwealth and States to give due consideration to the recommendations of the Working Party's report before implementing any policy changes.

The Commonwealth will continue to support co- operatives by giving close consideration to those policy areas within its jurisdiction which impact on the efficiency of operations of co-operatives and which may require modification.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Korean Airlines made applications for rights to operate services to and from Australia; if so, when.
(2) Will such services commence between Australia and Korea; if so, when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Korean Air (formerly Korean Airlines) has itself made no formal application to the Government or to my Department for rights to operate services to and from Australia.

However Korean Air has held a number of discussions with Qantas Airways Ltd which have included consideration of direct air services between Australia and the Republic of Korea. Whilst the two airlines have not agreed on the question of the viability of direct services between the two countries, they have established co-operative arrangements aimed at developing traffic flows over intermediate Asian ports.

(2) The matter of direct air services has been raised by the Republic of Korea on a number of occasions at government level and at official level, most recently at the Joint Ministerial Trade Talks between Australia and the Republic of Korea in Canberra on 13-14 May 1986. In recognition of the expanding relationship between the two countries, agreement was reached at this meeting that Ministers responsible for aviation in the two countries will establish a working group of officials to improve aviation arrangements between Australia and Korea, desirably through commercially viable regular direct services between the two countries. Among the arrangements to be considered is a bilateral Air Services Agreement. It was agreed that a meeting of the working group of officials of the two Governments will take place in Canberra or Seoul before the end of 1986.
It is not possible to advise in advance of this meeting whether direct services may commence between Australia and the Republic of Korea and, if so, when this might occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Within the Federal Electorate of Corangamite there are five nursing homes approved under the National Health Act.
The following lists actual expenditure for the 1984- 1985 financial year, and estimated expenditure for the 1985-86 financial year for each of the homes.

(2) The Commonwealth provides financial assistance to nursing homes on behalf of residents to assist in meeting nursing home costs. This assistance is provided in one of two ways; either through the payment of Commonwealth nursing home benefits under the National Health Act to participating and State Government nursing homes or through deficit financing of approved costs of homes approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act conducted by religious and charitable organisations.

The 5 homes funded by the Commonwealth in the Corangamite electorate are approved under the National Health Act to receive Commonwealth nursing home benefits; 4 of the homes are participating homes conducted by private enterprise while the Lorne Nursing Home is a State Government home.

The Commonwealth usually sets nursing home benefits each November at a level whereby the benefit plus a minimum resident contribution of 87.5 per cent of the pension plus rental allowance will cover the fees charged in 70 per cent of beds in non-Government nursing homes approved under the National Health Act in each State.

In May 1985 the Government decided to freeze the level of nursing home benefits payable to all Government homes and to participating nursing homes in Victoria, South Australia and the Northern Territory where benefits were already well above those applicable in the rest of Australia. Subsequent to this, however, the Government decided to increase nursing home benefits in South Australia by $3 per day effective from 14 November 1985 to cover the costs of the 38 hour week which was introduced in South Australia earlier in 1985, and was already allowed for in the level of benefit payable in Victoria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations by the Chilean Commission on Human Rights about a political murder, 5 attempted murders, 36 political detentions and kidnappings, 200 political detentions and kidnappings in mass raids and 20 incidents of cruel and inhumane treatment of prisoners in Chile in February.
(2) What action has the Government taken to (a) investigate these and other reported violations of human rights in Chile and (b) to raise the matters with the Chilean Government in 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Department of Foreign Affairs receives regular reports on human rights in Chile from a number of organisations, including the Chilean Commission on Human Rights, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, Amnesty International, the United Nations, and the Chilean Church human rights organisation, the Vicariate of Solidarity. The figures presented by the Chilean Commission on Human Rights covering violations in February 1986 are consistent with other assessments which indicate that abuses continue in Chile at a deplorable rate.

(2) (a) The Limited resources of our Embassy in Santiago restrict Australia's capacity to carry out independent investigations of abuses of the order reported by human rights organisations. Australia therefore relies considerably on the activities and reports of the organisations mentioned above. The Embassy has however investigated a number of individual cases which have been brought to my attention and, where appropriate, has made representations to Chilean authorities and visited detainees in gaol.

(b) In 1986 Australia has continued to take a close and active interest in the human rights situation in Chile. At the forty-second session of the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva in March, Australia supported a resolution critical of the Chilean Government. It is hoped that the weight of international opinion, to which Australia contributes, will eventually be felt. In addition, our Embassy has investigated several specific allegations of human rights abuse, most recently in the case of two officials of the Vicariate of Solidarity. In Parliament on 29 May I expressed my concern at the detention of the two officials and about the human rights situation in general. Mr Beazley (representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs) commented on this issue, also in Parliament, on 20 May. Australian concerns regarding the officals have been communicated to the Chilean authorities, both in Canberra and Santiago. Officers of the Australian Embassy have visited the two officials in gaol.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industrial Disputes Involving Exports of Primary Produce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 29 May 1986, page 4243) does his Department keep records of shipping, waterfront, rail, road and grain handling industrial disputes involving exports of primary produce; if not, can he provide the name of another Department which does keep such records.

(2) If no Department keeps records of a type referred to in part (1), on what does he base his comments that it is mythology that primary producers are adversely affected by transport problems beyond the farm gate.
(3) What actions have been taken since 1941 by other than conservative party governments to improve efficiency and reduce costs on the waterfront.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Transport maintains records of industrial disputes which result in delays to shipping at Australian ports. These records do not separately identify disputes affecting exports of primary produce.

(2) I refer the honourable member to my answer to his question without notice on this matter (Hansard, 29 May 1986, page 4243). In that reply I said it was `mythology that all the problems' of farmers were transport problems. I did not say that primary producers were not adversely affected by transport problems beyond the farm gate.

(3) In 1942 a committee comprising Justice Sir Owen Dixon of the High Court, Sir Thomas Gordon, Director of Shipping and Mr J. Healy, General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation was appointed to determine what steps should be taken to overcome the problems arising from labour shortages on the waterfront. As a result of the committee's report a Stevedoring Industry Commission was established to stabilise the industry.

In 1945 Mr Justice Foster of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration was commissioned to conduct an inquiry into and whether control of the industry should continue. This led in 1947 to the establishment of a new Stevedoring Industry Commission under the Chairmanship of Mr Justice Kirby.

The Stevedoring Industry Commission was disbanded in 1949. Judicial powers were returned to the Conciliation and Arbitration Court and responsibility for administrative matters vested in the Australian Stevedoring Industry Board.

In 1973 Mr. N. K. Foster was commissioned to consult with stevedoring employers and other interested parties relating to the future of the industry. This report, presented to the Government in May 1974, provided an assessment of the principal problems requiring attention and outlined various alternatives available for permanent arrangements for the industry.
In October 1975 Mr R. M. Northrop was requested to report on the future of Government statutory involvement in the industry.

In September 1984 I established a Task Force on Shore-Based Shipping Costs to determine practical measures which would increase the operational efficiency and lower the cost of land-based elements of the movement of cargo by sea. The Task Force report is currenty being considered by the Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Development of New Australian Products and Processes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Do any Commonwealth departments or authorities have responsibility for monitoring the development of new Australian products or processes; if so, does this monitoring extend to analysing whether or not the products or processes are taken up by Australian industry or lost to companies overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has:
major responsibility for implementing industry and technology policy.
the Department does monitor product developments and new technologies and is broadly aware of the extent to which products or processes are commercialised in Australia.
The Technology Assessment Section of the Department has the function of:
identifying priority areas of technology to which particular attention should be paid in Australia; and

suggesting what action (if any) needs to be taken to encourage the adoption by Australian industry of the identified priority technologies or the establishment of new industries and/or enterprises based on these technologies.
The 150 per cent tax scheme for R&D and the Grants for Industrial R&D (GIRD) recognise the importance of new product development and gives positive support
GIRD also allows for support to `generic' technologies and to national interest projects.
In addition, there are some Commonwealth agencies or bodies supported by the Commonwealth monitoring the development of specific new products or processes. For example:
the Commonwealth supported Innovation Centres have been established to facilitate the commercialisation of Australian inventions (products or processes);

the Australian Science and Technology Council advises the Commonwealth Government on the identification and support of new ideas in science and technology likely to be of national importance, the practical development and application of scientific discoveries, the fostering of scientific and technical innovation in industry, etc.

the Technological Change Committee of ASTEC seeks to identify and evaluate new and changing technologies of importance to Australia, and factors favouring, or restraints impeding, the introduction or diffusion within Australia of new or existing technologies.
the Patent Office has the capability to monitor patenting activity related to Australian-developed products or processes both in Australia and overseas.

SIROTECH is involved in monitoring the emergence of new technologies and processes in CSIRO and a number of other institutions (hospitals, universities and research bodies). The central theme of SIROTECH'S activities is to promote the use by Australian industry of such emerging technologies and processes.
the Department of Defence carries out monitoring relating to specific defence equipment or products the Department plans to buy.

the Commission for the Future disseminates information and educates the community about new products and processes in two days. The Clearing House on Future Issues collects Australian and international information about new products and processes and disseminates the availability of this information very widely to trade unions, businesses, the education section, etc. The Communications and Education Program of the Commission is constantly raising awareness about new products and processes in the media, in the Parliament, in State Impact Seminars, etc.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Lost Working Days: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say what have been the number of working days (a) lost and (b) lost per thousand employees for (i) Australia, (ii) Canada, (iii) the U.S., (iv) the U.K., (v) Japan, (vi) West Germany, (vii) France, (viii) Italy, (ix) New Zealand, (x) the OECD and (xi) the 7 major OECD countries for each year 1966 to 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The following table has been compiled from the 1976 and 1985 editions of the International Labour Organisation's Year Book of Labour Statistics for the period 1966 to 1984, which is the latest available time period.

There are, however, relevant Australian Bureau of Statistics figures available for Australia for 1985 concerning the number of working days lost and working days lost per thousand employees. These figures are 1.255 million and 230 respectively.

In examining the table, it should be noted that there are difficulties in making comparisons between countries on the basis of the ILO figures. This is because the definitions of what constitutes an industrial dispute, the statistical bases, and data collection techniques differ markedly from country to country.

By way of example, the ABS and ILO figures for Australia include stoppages of 10 man-days or more which picks up quite small and short disputes. By contrast, whereas previously the U.S.A. used a threshold of 6 workers, since 1981 it has only recorded those disputes of more than one day's or shift's duration and involving more than 1,000 workers. It has been estimated that this change alone reduced the recorded number of days lost in the U.S.A. by between 30 and 40 per cent. Both the U.K. and West Germany count disputes involving more than 10 workers and of more than one day's duration, unless 100 or more working days are lost in which case shorter disputes or disputes involving fewer people may be counted. Canada counts disputes of 10 or more days lost or of more than half a day's duration. France has no restrictions on the size of disputes to be counted, but does not include public sector or agricultural employees in its statistics. Italy has no restrictions on the size of disputes counted.
Further, in most countries reporting of disputes is voluntary whereas in Australia employers are legally obliged to file a return on a dispute identified by the ABS for official purposes.
Sources: ILO Year Book of Labour Statistics (1976 and 1985 editions) and ABS Industrial Disputes, Australia (Catalogue No. 6321.0)
1. WDL ('000)=working days lost in thousands; WDL/1,000E=working days lost per thousand employees.
2. Australia (A)-Figures have been compiled from the ILO Year Book of Labour Statistics (1976 and 1985 editions).
3. Australia (B)-Figures have been extracted from the ABS monthly publication Industrial Disputes, Australia (Catalogue (No. 6321.0).

4. The ABS, or ``official'', figures for working days lost per thousand employees are generally higher than those derived from the ILO because the former only include, in the employment level, paid employees (and not, for example, self-employed persons and partnerships). It is recommended, therefore, that for purposes of comparison only, the ILO figures be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 April 1986 (Hansard, page 2143), Mr Duncan asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in his capacity as Acting Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister read an article in the Australian Business of 2 August 1984 entitled `Bending the tax rules with gold?' Is the Minister aware that gold bullion may be bought and sold anonymously in Australia with impunity? Is the Minister aware that anonymous trading in gold bullion is widespread and greatly facilitates tax evasion and money laundering? What steps will the Minister take to provide for the licensing of gold bullion traders and for recording the identities of all parties to each gold bullion transaction that takes place in this country?
The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Further to the response of the Acting Treasurer on 11 April 1986, I advise that Commonwealth restrictions on the freedom of Australian residents to own, buy and sell gold in Australia were removed in 1976. However legislation existed in some States to regulate gold buying and some dealings in gold.
As to the potential for tax evasion through buying and selling gold for cash, I have obtained some comments for the Commissioner of Taxation.

First, I should point out that there is nothing illegal per se about a cash business transaction; like any other commodity, gold can be bought and sold for cash. It is recognised that tax evasion is attempted by means of concealing income arising from cash transactions.

However, although cash transactions can give rise to problems in establishing a `paper trail', the Commissioner has a variety of techniques available to him to detect tax evaders and to assess their liabilities. For example, for purposes of the income tax law, he has a general right of access to records and premises that he can exercise in relation to those who provide gold sales and storage facilities . . . and he has power to require information from them. Provisions enacted in December 1984 in the Taxation Administration Act provide severe penalties for falsifying or concealing identity with the intention of deceiving the Commissioner of Taxation or hindering an investigation.

The Commissioner can also employ indirect income measurement techniques to audit returns where a taxpayer has not kept adequate records of cash transactions. Essentially these techniques involve the compilation of a statement of source and application of funds, taking into account living expenses, and do not necessarily rely on an ability to focus on specific aspects of a taxpayer's affairs or to detect specific income transactions. For its part the Government remains committed to providing the ATO with sufficient audit resources to increase the level of audit coverage from the present 0.75 per cent to 2 per cent of non-salary and wage earners by 1992.

The Government is also sponsoring the Australia Card proposal which will have an impact on the cash economy. The proposals include the expansion of information reporting to the ATO. This expansion would reduce the scope for people to place funds or valuables under false names in investments, bank accounts or safekeeping facilities and should increase the likelihood of funds being invested where reporting measures apply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken since March 1983 to require higher education institutions to undertake positive measures to (a) increase the proportion of school leavers from disadvantaged backgrounds or isolated areas who participate in higher education, (b) increase the participation in higher education of persons from disadvantaged groups such as Aborigines and migrants, (c) achieve equal opportunities and expanded roles for women in and through their higher education, (d) expand access, recognition and support for members of the workforce seeking to upgrade their skills and qualifications within their fields of work, (e) expand opportunities for later life entry and (f) assist in the provision of childcare as a means of promoting equal opportunities and improving access to those with parenting responsibilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In 1984, the Government provided $10 million for 3,000 additional places in higher education, with further increases in intakes of 1,300 in 1985 and some 2,000 in each of 1986 and 1987 being supported. After allowance is made for the flow through of these additional students into the second and later years of their courses (the pipeline effect), these measures will have provided in total over 22,000 additional places in higher education institutions. These increases have been largely directed towards institutions, such as those in outer metropolitan areas, which serve communities that have concentrations of disadvantaged groups. It has been emphasised that institutions should look to encouraging members of disadvantaged groups to take up the additional places.

The Government has also established the Equity Program, which provides funding for projects in institutions to promote equality of opportunity in respect of higher education. Projects funded under this program usually involve innovative approaches to encouraging members of disadvantaged groups to undertake higher education or to provide support for such students once they are enrolled. $1 million has been provided under this Program for each of the years of the 1985-87 triennium.

(b) In addition to the measures described in part (a), which include projects incorporating bridging and support programs for Aboriginal students, 150 of the 1985 increased intakes and 200 of those for 1986 have been set aside for Aboriginals. The places have been funded at a higher rate than the general intake, in recognition of the increased levels of support required for these students, who in general have little experience of the higher education environment.

(c) A number of projects funded under the Equity Program have been specifically directed towards increasing opportunities for women and girls in non-traditional areas such as engineering and the technologies. More generally, a condition of payments under the States Grants (tertiary Education Assistance) Act is that the State will ensure that the benefits of, and opportunities created by, such payments will, as far as possible, be equally available to male students and female students.

(d) & (e) Through the Equity Program, and more general measures, the development of a variety of entry modes to higher education is being supported. These include greater recognition of TAFE qualifications and work experience as a basis for entry into higher education, and the development of special forms of entry for mature age students who do not have a complete secondary education. Such measures recognise the needs and abilities of those who seek higher education as a means of upgrading their skills or who were denied the opportunity of higher education earlier in life.

(f) The Government recognises the importance of adequate child care in expanding opportunities for many disadvantaged students. Funding for the building of child care centres at institutions and for the inclusion of child care facilities in multi-purpose buildings is available through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's capital program. Institutions are able to provide the running costs of child care from their general recurrent grants, as is the case for other student services. Additional funding may also be provided by the Office of Child Care through its general allocations based on community needs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government opposed to (a) military bases, (b) installations, (c) fortifications, (d) weapons or (e) military movements in space and the (f) researching, (g) testing or (h) deployment of anti-satellite weapons or space-based anti-ballistic missile weapon systems by any nation including the USA and the USSR.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a)-(h) The Government has made it clear that it is opposed to any extension of the arms race into outer space. This would include military bases, military installations, fortifications, weapons and military movements, and the testing and deployment of anti-satellite weapons or space-based anti-ballistic missile weapon systems by any nation. It does not endorse the SDI research program but recognises that the research currently underway may also have wider applications.

The Government firmly believes that arms control and disarmament would provide a more effective and lasting defence against ballistic missile attack than any ABM system and has consistently called on both superpowers to enter into balanced and verifiable agreement for significant nuclear arms reduction and for the prevention of an arms race in outer space.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 14 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that action has been initiated against both Mr D. L. Price of Murray Bridge, S.A., and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) as a result of work which Mr Price undertook on behalf of the ADC.
(2) Has the ADC decided not to assist Mr Price in the defamation action, Hillock-v-Price.

(3) If the ADC will not provide financial assistance to Mr Price is it because he is not an Aboriginal; if so, is this decision inconsistent with the Government's stated policy of equality as set out in Article 1 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill.
(4) Does the Government support the decision of the ADC in this case; if not, will he ensure that the ADC provides appropriate support for Mr Price.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr D. L. Price was sued in defamation over the contents of a report he provided to the Aboriginal Development Commission in his capacity as an independent professional consultant. Mr Price settled out of court and sought financial assistance from the Commission to meet his legal expenses.

The Commission is being sued in defamation by a different plaintiff over the contents of a press release (September 1981) and a letter in the same month to the newspaper, the Adelaide Advertiser. The Commission is defending the action.

(3) It is the Commission's view that the costs were incurred by Mr Price in his capacity as an independent professional consultant. Accordingly the Commission does not have an obligation to Mr Price in this matter and consequently does not have the power to assist him under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.
(4) The Commission is an independent statutory authority and is not subject to specific direction by Government on operational decisions taken in the exercise of its statutory powers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 14 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has he taken in the development of trade with Taiwan.
(2) What guidelines does his Department follow in relation to the development of trade with Taiwan.
(3) What is the value to Australia of trade with Taiwan.
(4) Has his Department prepared any projections on the potential for trade with Taiwan; if so, will he make the results available.
(5) Has his Department been represented on an interdepartmental committee inquiring into issues affecting Taiwan and Australia; if so, what were the recommendations of the committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Province of Taiwan (Taiwan) was in 1984/85 our sixth most important trading partner and a valuable market for a number of Australian raw materials and agricultural products. I am aware of the high level of commercial interest in the market. Following representations to me from the private sector on matters concerning the trade and commercial relationship with Taiwan, an Interdepartmental Committee was convened. See (5) below.

(2) In December 1972, Australia recognised the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate Government of China, including Taiwan. The Australian Government affords no recognition to the authorities in Taiwan and there is no Trade Commissioner based there. Assistance is available to companies to develop trade from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and its office in Taipei.

(3) Strong growth rates in two way trade have been recorded in recent years reflecting a growing penetration of the Australian market by Taiwan and an expanding demand for Australian raw materials to support the development of Taiwan's industrial base. In 1984/85 Australian exports to Taiwan were valued at $856 million and imports from Taiwan were valued at $1,053 million.

(4) No. However, information available to the Department of Trade on economic developments in Taiwan suggests that the outlook for continued growth in this economy is promising. The Australian Chamber of Commerce, through its office in Taipei, has undertaken studies on the market in Taiwan for a variety of products. These reports are available from the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Canberra.

(5) Yes. The Committee was established to review various aspects of Australia's relationship with Taiwan, including the commercial relationship. The Committee was not required to make specific recommendations although a focus of activity has been the streamlining of visa issuing procedures for applications from Taiwan.
