QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are applicants for the Reserve Forces required to undergo: (a) medical and (b) psychological testing; if so, at what centres is the testing conducted.
(2) What staff at each centre are available to conduct the testing.
(3) What is the average waiting time between the submission of an application to join the Reserve Forces and the completion of the requisite testing.
(4) What percentage of applicants do not proceed with their applications after they have been lodged.
(5) Is it a fact that lengthy delays in arranging medical and psychological testing have led to drop out rates among Reserve applicants as high as 60%.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Testing centres are located in each of the capital cities at Service establishments or in Defence Force Recruiting Centres. Testing is also undertaken at Townsville and Army Reserve local testing for country applicants may be undertaken by visiting teams or by local civilian medical practitioners.

(2) Staff are provided as necessary from local Service and Reserve resources and local civilian medical practitioners. In the case of Army, Commanding Officers may waive a pre-enlistment psychology test if undue delay would otherwise result.

(3) The waiting time varies between the three Services. For Army it is around two to three weeks. For RAAF, testing is arranged on average about 5 to 6 weeks after receipt of the application by the Defence Force Recruiting Centre. For Navy the period varies considerably from State to State and depending on the type of entry, but 5 to 6 weeks would be average for sailors; direct officer entry would normally be longer because of the need to convene selection boards.
(4) In 85/86 the withdrawal rate for Army was around 20% and for Navy around 14%. Figures are not available for RAAF.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 April:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in The Australian of 27 February 1986 about a Government sponsored visit to South Africa and other destinations by senior ACTU officials in February 1986.
(2) If so, what was the (a) duration, (b) cost and (c) purpose of the trip.
(3) How many persons took part in the visit.
(4) What were their destinations.
(5) What was the (a) duration, (b) subject matter and (c) date of each meeting of discussion held and with whom was each held.
(6) Who instigated the visit.
(7) Has the Government received a report on the visit and its achievements from the ACTU delegation.
(8) It not, will he ask for a report; if not, why not.
(9) If a report has or will be received, will copies be available.
(10) Was the trip successful; if so, in what way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The duration of the visit was one month.
(b) Detailed costs are being finalised with the ACTU, but the visit is estimated to cost about $17,000.
(c) The purpose of the visit was to conduct a feasibility study in South Africa and neighbouring states to see what was the best way of providing training aid to South African black trade unionists.
(4) Zimbabwe, Zambia, South Africa and Geneva (headquarters of the International Labour Organisation).
(5) Full details of individual meetings are not yet available. However, the ACTU has provided the following details:

Zimbabwe and Zambia: 27 February to 10 March 1986-Meetings with trade union congress representatives in each country, Australian High Commissioner, South African Congress of Trade Unions, the leadership of the new Confederation of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) as well as regional representatives of the Commonwealth Trade Union Council and the International confederation of Free Trade Unions.

South Africa: 21-27 March 1986-Meetings with trade union confederations, the South African Institute of Race Relations, the Centre for Applied Legal Studies University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, the Black Sash (a women's organisation), the South African Council of Churches General Secretary, the National Sullivan Code of Conduct Co-ordinator, Professor Wiehahn of the University of Pretoria, Mr Botha, the Vice Chairman of the Federated Chamber of Industries Manpower Commission, the Registrar and a Deputy President of the Industrial Court and visits to the townships of Soweto, Alexandra and Mamelodi.

(6) The proposal to consider training black trade unionists was approved by me. Details of how this could be achieved, including the visit to South Africa, were handled by the Australian Development Assistance bureau (ADAB) and the ACTU.
(7) and (8) ADAB has been given a copy of the ACTU internal report which was received on a confidential basis. A formal report setting out specific proposals is expected from the ACTU shortly.
(9) The formal report, once submitted, would be available.

(10) The ACTU advises that the trip was most successful as it provided an opportunity to meet a cross-section of the South African community and assess the needs for training for black trade unionists. As a result of the visit the ACTU invited COSATU to send a delegation to Australia to inspect and discuss trade union training facilities. In early June three COSATU officials came to Australia and examined ACTU training facilities with a view to reporting back to the COSATU Executive in RSA prior to presenting the ACTU with a proposal for an ACTU administered training program for black South African trade unionists.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) See my answer to Question on Notice No. 629, published in House of Representatives Hansard on 23 August, 1985 page 457.

(4) Details on United States Nuclear Powered Warship (NPW) visits to Australia from December 1982 to May 1985 are included in Senate Hansard of 8 May, 1985, pages 1579 to 1581, and in House of Representatives Hansard of 31 May, 1985 page 3245. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the laws governing consumer warnings on labels of products which contain hazardous ingredients require amendment.
(2) Will he request the Australian Law Reform Commission to examine the law in this area and conduct a wide ranging inquiry into its adequacy,

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I do not consider that the present laws on warning labels require amendment. These laws cover a number of different areas but particularly Health(e.g. poisons labelling) and Consumer Affaires (e.g. labels warning of the inhalation hazard posed by beanbag filling) and are generally embodied in State/ Territory legislation. There are a number of Commonwealth/State/Territory consultative mechanisms which have made substantial progress in developing adequate and uniform requirements for hazardous ingredient labelling.

The Office of Consumer Affairs within my Department assists in the co-ordination of these efforts from the consumer viewpoint. Consumer protection legislation at the Commonwealth and State/Territory levels provides powers to require specific warnings on consumer goods where deemed necessary.

(2) As indicated in (1), hazardous ingredient labelling is controlled under a variety of legislation which is usually specific to the product type. Such legislation is complemented by Commonwealth, State and Territory consumer protection legislation under which warning labels, including ingredient warning labels, can be introduced if particular needs are identified. I do not consider it necessary to request the Australian Law Reform Commission to examine the law on this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to US laboratory tests linking methylene chloride with cancer in humans, and claiming that the risk is magnified by incorrect use of products such as paint strippers which contain the chemical.
(2) Has he referred the studies to the appropriate bodies in Australia to determine whether product warning labels are adequate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Although my attention has been drawn to recent US proposals to restrict the use of methylene chloride in aerosol containers, my Department is not aware of any valid studies linking methylene chloride with cancer in humans. The proposed US action is based, I understand, on the findings of recently conducted laboratory studies in rodents.

(2) The information relating to these new studies has been received and is currently being reviewed in my Department. It also will be considered by the relevant committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC) which advises the States and Territories on these matters. The Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee of NH&MRC has recently classified methylene chloride as a poison requiring warning labels. Further restrictions and labelling requirements will be considered by that Committee when the abovementioned information has been evaluated in the light of all other available information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) response to the Parry Report recommending the establishment of the Western Sydney State University which expressed concern about low participation rates in years 11 and 12 at western Sydney high schools.
(2) If so, when did the CTEC first become concerned about low participation rates in years 11 and 12 in south western and western Sydney high schools.
(3) Has the CTEC previously expressed concern about this matter; if so, when.
(4) Has the CTEC conveyed its concern to (a) the Schools Commission and (b) the Minister's Department; if so, when.
(5) Will the Minister make the relevant papers available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has been concerned about low retention rates to upper secondary schooling in south-western and western Sydney for some years. In June 1983 it established a Working Party to examine the higher education needs of the outer metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne with low levels of participation. The Working Party's report (Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, Report of the Working Party on Outer Metropolitan Areas, November 1983) drew attention to the below average school retention rates in both outer Sydney and outer Melbourne. The Report indicated that higher education institutions should consider ways of being involved in the operations of schools to encourage improved school-leaver participation in their programs. In its Volume 1 Report for the 1985-87 Triennium (April 1984), the Commission noted the ``disturbingly low'' school retention rates in outer metropolitan and rural areas and drew attention to the need to increase school retention in order to reduce educational disadvantage. Its recommendations for growth in higher education enrolments over the 1985-87 triennium were made on the basis that a large part of the expansion should take place in the institutions serving outer metropolitan areas-in the case of Sydney at Macarthur Institute of Higher Education, Nepean College of Advanced Education and Macquarie University.

(4) Copies of the Working Party's Report were sent to the Chairman of the Commonwealth Schools Commission (CSC) and the Acting Secretary of the Department of Education in early 1984. Copies of the Commission's Volume 1 report were also provided to the CSC and the Department and tabled in Parliament.
(5) The relevant reports were published and are readily available.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Investigation of Beam Failures in Trucks

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to my question No. 3109 (Hansard, 12 February 1986, page 421) have there been any further investigations of the failure of walking beam suspensions systems fitted to many Australian trucks, if so what have been the conclusions of these inquiries and what action is proposed?
(2) If there have been no further investigations, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The inquiries mentioned in my previous answer have been further progressed.

On the matter of bush end failures, the Federal Office of Road Safety is of the view that failures which may affect the safety of the vehicle are principally a result of inadequate maintenance of the affected parts. Agreement has been reached with the suspension supplier that revised maintenance procedure material will be disseminated and training sessions with truck dealers and workshop personnel conducted. This action has been commenced and will be monitored by the Federal Office of Road Safety.

A detailed investigation of beam failures has resulted in 22 failures being documented. The majority of these failures have been of beams which have the lowest rating. These have been frequently fitted to trucks which have been working in arduous conditions where overloading is common. Investigations are continuing but overloading appears to be a significant factor. The suspension supplier some time ago ceased supplying beams of this rating to the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to allegations made on the television program `60 Minutes' regarding a design fault which leads to a serious loss of control in some trucks manufactured by the Volvo company; if so does he intend to investigate these claims; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the allegations made on the 60 Minutes program and have requested that the matter be investigated. A Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) investigation has involved discussions between the manufacturer, State and Territory authorities, individual truck owners and an industry association. The results of extensive investigations carried out by the company and subjected to independent review indicate that the rear suspension design is not at fault as reported by 60 Minutes.
Investigations are continuing to determine if there are other problems that might have resulted in the concerns expressed by truck owners. The manufacturer is co-operating with FORS in this regard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the Minister advised that the position of Chairman of the National Aboriginal Education Commission (NAEC) was to be vacated?
(2) Was the position vacated prematurely within the term of office of the appointment; if so, why.
(3) When was the position of Chairman of the NAEC advertised and what was the closing date for applications.
(4) Was adequate time given for applications.
(5) In which newspapers was the position of chairman of the NAEC advertised and on what dates was the advertisement placed in each paper.
(6) Were Aboriginal organisations informed of the advertisement for the position of Chairman of the NAEC in advance of the closing date; if so, which organisations were informed.
(7) When and how were the organisations informed.
(8) Were regional officers of the Department of Education notified of the advertisement of the position in advance of the closing date; if so, (a) how and (b) when were they informed.
(9) Were State and Regional Aboriginal Education Consultative Groups notified of the advertisements.
(10) When were the members of the NAEC informed of the (a) advertisement and (b) closing date for applications for the position of Chairman.
(11) What (a) salary and (b) allowances are payable to the Chairman of the NAEC.
(12) How was the selection panel chosen.
(13) What are the (a) composition and (b) qualifications of each member of the selection panel.
(14) What are the selection criteria for the position of chairman of the NAEC.
(15) What is the name of each applicant for the position of Chairman of the NAEC.
(16) Which applicants were given (a) face-to-face and (b) telephone interviews.
(17) Why were telephone interviews conducted for the position.
(18) What are the formal qualifications of each applicant for the position and what weight was given in the selection assessment to an applicant's work with urban Aboriginal groups.
(19) What is the educational work experience with urban Aboriginal people of each applicant.

(20) What is the (a) educational work with traditional or remote Aboriginal communities, (b) research, (c) international teaching and educational work and (d) administrative experience of each applicant for the position and what weight was given to this experience.
(21) What are the details of membership of national education advisory committees for each applicant for the position and what weight was given in the selection process to this matter.
(22) Who was appointed to the position of Chairman of the NAEC and on what basis was the person selected.
(23) How was the consultative experience for each applicant assessed and what evidence was obtained and from what source.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The question refers to a Ministerial appointment to a senior advisory position. To answer all parts of the question as asked would entail intrusion into the privacy of individuals and would also impose a considerable workload upon officers. I will therefore respond to what I perceive to be the essence of the question, rather than deal with all twenty-three component parts.

I was advised late last year that Mr Paul Hughes, the then Chairman of the NAEC, would vacate the position before the end of the year instead of serving out his full remaining term of office to 1 May, 1986.

Although the position is a ministerial appointment, not a public service position to be filled through the normal process of competition, applications were invited through an advertisement on 26 October 1985 in The Australian. An advisory panel was formed to consider all applications and give me their advice. Membership of the panel was agreed between my Department, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, and the Chairman of the NAEC, and consisted of: Mr P. Bowler, First Assistant Secretary, Education Programs and Research Division, Department of Education (chairman of panel); Mr D. O'Rourke, First Assistant Secretary, Program Development Division, Department of Aboriginal Affairs; Mr P. Hughes, Chairman of the NAEC; and Ms Josie Crawshaw, Director, Aboriginal Development Branch of the Northern Territory Public Service Board, and a member of the NAEC.

In view of the relatively short time before the position became vacant (Mr Hughes left on 13 December), and the particular need for continuity at a time when several important developments in Aboriginal education were under way, I instructed my Department to proceed without any delay in the consideration of applications. Two had been received by the closing date of 8 November 1985, and a further two had been received by 20 November, when the advisory panel first met to conduct interviews. Arrangements were made to interview three of the applicants in person in Canberra, and the fourth, who was unavailable to come to Canberra at short notice, by telephone. A fifth application was received too late for consideration.

The panel reported to me on 3 December on the outcome of their deliberations, in which they were guided by the selection criteria set out hereunder. After considering the panel's advice and consulting Ministerial colleagues I decided on 10 December 1985 to appoint Mr Errol West, the then Deputy Chairman of the NAEC, to the position of Chairman. I announced the appointment on 11 December 1985.

I should add that, in addition to advertising the vacancy in The Australian, copies of the advertisement were sent to State and Territory Aboriginal Consultative Groups immediately after it appeared. The position carries a salary of $52,426 and an $851 Expenses of Office Allowance. The selection criteria taken into account by the panel were as follows:
(i) Experience in education strongly preferred, but experience in a related field could be acceptable if other criteria are met;
(ii) Experience in working within a formal structure and giving direction to staff;

(iii) In order to be credible in a leadership position among the members of the Committee, it would be desirable for the occupant to have at least completed a teaching qualification or an equivalent in a related field.
(i) Ability to provide leadership in a Committee composed of a diverse group of Aboriginal people;
(ii) Ability to plan and organise effectively and efficiently the Committee's business including sub-committees, working groups and other arrangements;
(iii) Ability to articulate the views and policies of the Committee and provide advice to the Minister and Department of Education and of Aboriginal Affairs;
(iv) Ability to manage the Committee's Secretariat effectively and to liaise closely with the Department of Education;
(i) Sensitivity to widely differing views on Aboriginal education issues;
(iii) Commitment to the development of good relationships with a wide range of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people concerned with Aboriginal education;
(iv) Appreciation of the need to place Aboriginal education issues in the wider context of the development of education in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the total funds made available to local authorities in (a) Queensland and (b) Australia, during each year since 1975-76.
(2) What control over the State Governments does the Federal Government have to ensure the local authorities receive Federal financial assistance on a population needs basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Commonwealth Grants to or for Local Government
Grants for the Restoration of Local Authority Assets under the Natural Disasters Program are not included.

(2) Under the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act, the Federal Government had little control over the methods by which Local Government was allocated Federal general revenue assistance. The Act established in only very broad terms the method by which funds were to be distributed.

However, under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986, which came into operation on 1 July 1986, the States are required by 1 July 1987 to formulate principles upon which they propose to distribute Federal general revenue assistance between councils. These principles are to be based on the objective of equalising each Local Government's ability to undertake its functions with respect to the average standard performance of other Local Governments in its State. I, as the responsible Minister, will be required to approve these principles.
The intention is to ensure that financial assistance is given to those local councils who are most disadvantaged in respect of their ability to raise revenue and provide services.

All other Commonwealth grants to Local Government are for specific purposes. They are administered through a variety of arrangements. The amount of direct Commonwealth control varies with the nature of these programs, however all are intended to be directed towards the areas of greatest need that the programs are addressing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are figures available showing comparisons of the number of pharmaceuticals prescribed to elderly people where the person (a) is and (b) is not eligible for free drugs.
(2) If not, will he arrange for such a study to be undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no figures available that compare the number of pharmaceuticals prescribed to elderly people where the person is (a) eligible and (b) ineligible for free drugs.

(2) The Australian Institute of Health is currently undertaking a number of projects designed to look at a variety of health issues, especially the application of economics to health and health services research. In this respect, two projects have particular relevance to the honourable member's question. Findings from the two projects when combined will give some measure of the overall prescribing and medicine usage patterns of the Australian public, including aged persons who are eligible or ineligible to receive free medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

The first project involved a recently completed household medication survey in Sydney, Melbourne, Wynyard/Burnie and Mt Gambier. The study was designed to measure the amounts and types of medications held, and used, in the household. It also sought to determine the ratio of prescribed to non-prescribed medicines and attempted to link medicine ownership and usage to the three types of basic classification of pensioner concessional beneficiary and general recipient.
Data from the survey have now been received by the Institute of Health and will shortly be analysed.

The second project involved the collating of all pharmaceutical benefits prescription drugs dispensed in the second quarter of 1985, and attributed to the population residing in two study regions (Wynyard/Burnie and Mt Gambier). The basic data from the project are available for analysis. It is intended to move on to measure the pharmaceutical benefits prescription drug usage and cost by individuals (age and sex) and by households (family economic units). As well, the extent of non-users of pharmaceutical benefits prescription drugs will be measured.

Further analysis of the two projects will provide meaningful information relative to the whole population of Australia. Considerable time and effort were expended in selecting the two study regions to enable this, and the Australian Institute of Health will be studying the data for some time to come.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answer to my question No. 3410 (Hansard, 30 April 1986, page 2833), and the continued importation of fresh brie and camembert from the Besnier Export Company of France similar to that which killed 85 people in California, (a) if the Besnier Company's fresh brie and camembert is imported into Australia, why is it considered an adequate check only to ascertain that the specific brands are different to those exported to the USA and (b) is the cheese for Australia produced in different factories to that exported to the USA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As stated in my answer to question No. 3410, a check on importation of fresh brie and camembert from the Besnier Export Company of France was undertaken by my Department. A list of all cheese of these types originating from Besnier was prepared and forwarded to the Department of Health for appropriate action.

This list was prepared on the basis that, although the specific brand of cheese which caused the problem in the USA was not imported to Australia, there was a definite possibility that the specific cheese could be imported into Australia under a different brand name.
Advice from the Besnier Company has now confirmed that cheeses exported to Australia originate from two factories which also supply for the American market.

However, as pointed out in my earlier answer, the controls exercised by my Department over imported cheeses are designed to eliminate the risk of introduction of foot and mouth disease. Human health considerations remain a matter for individual States under State food legislation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trade Promotion in the United Kingdom

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he visited the UK to promote Australia's trading interests; if so, (a) when and (b) why.
(2) Where does the UK rank in comparison with other countries as an Australian export market.
(3) What is his Department's assessment of the UK's growth potential as an export market for Australia.
(4) How many trade commissioners in the UK have been assigned to promotions (a) as at 31 March in each year since 1983 and (b) in other comparable export markets during these years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However at my invitation, the UK Minister for Trade, Mr Alan Clark, visited Australia in May 1986 as guest of the Australian Government. The objective of the invitation was to familiarise the UK Minister with current Australian concerns in the trade area and to further closer commercial links between our two countries.

While in Australia Mr Clark had discussions with myself and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin. Mr Clark also met with senior government officials as well as prominent members of private enterprise.

(3) Britain remains one of Australia's major trading partners. Australian exports to Britain in 1984/85 amounted to $923 million making this our most important market in Europe. Britain is our sixth most important market world wide taking 3.0% of Australia's total exports. In the 9 months ended March 1986, Australian exports to Britain have increased 43.1% over the same period to March 1985. However, the nature of our trade has changed considerably since Britain gained EC membership in 1973 and Australia lost its preferential market access. While Britain still offers a valuable market for wool and significant sales of meat, fruit, cheese and a few other agricultural products still take place, the dominance of agricultural products in Australia's exports to Britain has been replaced by minerals, metals and fuels.

Britain is also one of Australia's most important customers for manufactures. Australian exports of elaborately transformed manufactures have been undergoing steady growth in recent years and now comprise nearly 21% of our total exports to Britain.

The Australian Trade Commission recognises the continuing importance of the UK as an export market for Australia and the considerable potential for further development of the UK as a market for exports of manufactured products, particularly elaborately transformed manufactures. Austrade officers have recently prepared a three year strategy for the UK market which identifies product areas considered to have the best prospects for growth and includes a program of targeted activities designed to encourage and assist Australian exporters to take advantage of the opportunities for expanding their sales to the UK.
Ranked sixth as a market for Australian exports worldwide

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 May 1986:

(2) Is he aware of any US pricing errors which have cost implications for equipment or services ordered by Australia from US sources; if so,
(a) what equipment or services are involved and
(b) in each case (i) what is the extent of additional cost and (ii) what proportion of additional cost will have to be borne by Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The so called `pricing errors' stem from problems identified by US authorities involved with calculation of the total pool of costs to be recovered and with the reassessment of production run quantities of some defence equipments. The reassessment highlighted lesser numbers than those used to determine recoveries of nonrecurring costs. The dollars billion quoted in the article are in fact dollars million. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What contraceptive devices and drugs are available in Australia.
(2) Is he able to say which of these drugs and devices have been withdrawn in the U.S., and on what grounds.
(3) Why have they not been withdrawn in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are six companies who market forty-six (46) different oral contraceptive preparations in Australia. The vast majority of these have been evaluated and approved by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC). In addition I am aware that Depo-Provera, an injectable preparation containing medroxyprogesterone acetate, is being used in certain circumstances as a contraceptive agent although this is not one of the purposes for which it is marketed in Australia.

The following intra-uterine devices are currently available in Australia: Nova-T, Gyne-T, Gravigard, Mini-Gravigard and Multiload CU250. These were all evaluated and approved by the ADEC for safety and efficacy. The Lippes Loop was also available until January 1986 when the Company ceased distribution although there could well be some stocks of this device still available.

There is in addition a very wide range of condoms and a small range of diaphragms also available in Australia. It is not possible to list all of these although this information is currently being sought for inclusion on the National Register of Therapeutic Goods being compiled by my Department.

(2) Of all the drugs and devices presently available in Australia the only ones which I am aware have been withdrawn in the U.S. are the Lippes Loop and the Gravigard I.U.D. The Company manufacturing the Lippes Loop has stated that it has ceased manufacture in the U.S. because of falling sales in favour of the Copper I.U.D.s. The Gravigard was removed from the market because of the continuing litigation climate which prevails in the U.S. The Company producing the Gravigard has stated it was no longer able to obtain liability insurance cover in respect of the device. This was a voluntary withdrawal by the Company and was not as a result of any regulatory action by the Food and Drug Administration.

(3) The Lippes Loop will in due course no longer be available in Australia as the Company has ceased production. No action has been taken to withdraw the Gravigard from the Australian market as there is no evidence available to my Department that this device is a cause of serious problems in those women who are using it as a means of contraception. This device has only been withdrawn from the market in the U.S. and is still available in many other countries throughout the world, including the United Kingdom.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Air Force B52 Bombers: Operations in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did 3 US Air Force B52 bombers arrive in Darwin on the morning of 15 April 1986.
(2) Is he able to say why certain public roads around the airport were closed that morning.
(3) Was there any connection between these closures and the arrival of the B52s.
(4) Were the closures on his or his Department's authority.
(5) Is he able to say whether there was any connection between the arrival of these aircraft and the US bombing of Libya that morning, if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Two US Air Force B52 bombers undertaking standard BUSY BOOMERANG DELTA low level navigation training flights arrived in Darwin on 11 April 1986 and departed 13 April 1986. Approval for the flights was given on 26 March 1986.
(2), (3) and (4) No public roads around Darwin airport were closed during this period due to B52 operations.
(5) There was no connection whatever between the arrival of these aircraft and the US operations in Libya.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that Auscott Pty Ltd expects to reduce its cotton plantings in northern NSW by 50 per cent over the coming year.
(2) What percentage of the total Australian cotton crop is produced by Auscott Pty Ltd.
(3) Are there indications of reduced cotton plantings in other regions.
(4) What actions will the Government take over the next 6 months to overcome cuts in world cotton prices.
(5) Have Australian cotton prices declined over the past 6 months; if so, by what percentage.
(6) What is the forecast Australian cotton price for (a) July, (b) September and (c) November 1986.
(7) What is the forecast total value of Australian cotton production, including exports, for (a) 1985-86 and (b) 1986-87.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Auscott Ltd announced on 13 May 1986 that it would reduce its cotton plantings for the 1986-87 crop year by at least 50%. Auscott indicated that its decision was made necessary by reduced returns for cotton resulting from the severe price depresssing effects of the new United States cotton program.
(3) Yes. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has forecast a reduction in cotton plantings in Australia of some 25% in 1986-87.

(4) Recent sharp falls in world cotton prices are a direct consequence of high world stocks, aggravated by the new US cotton program with its substantial Payment-in-kind stock releases. Little can be done about the overall stock situation, however, the Government will continue to press on the US authorities the serious consequences which its cotton support program will have on returns to the Australian cotton industry with a view to minimising its effects. An important part of my recent visit to Washington was to reiterate Australia's concerns about US farm support programs, including the one for cotton, to the US Secretary of Agriculture and other key officials.

At home, the cotton industry is examining the possibility of seeking some form of price assistance. If the industry decides to pursue this course, it may be assured that any submission requesting assistance will be given speedy consideration by the Government. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics is currently undertaking a study of financial conditions in the cotton industry, the results of which will assist the Government's assessment of the industry's problems and provide important information for the industry.

Farmers in difficulty may seek assistance through the Rural Adjustment Scheme. Cotton production requires relatively high levels of capital, and cotton growers seeking assistance will benefit from the Government's decision to allocate a further $20 million for interest subsidies through the Scheme in 1986-87 to assist debt reconstruction, farm build-up and farm improvement.
(5) Yes. Domestic prices have declined by about 12% and export prices have declined by about 8%.

(6) Australian cotton prices are expected to follow the trend in world prices. The main world price indicator, the Cotton Outlook (`A index'), is currently US39c/lb (A59c/lb) and is expected to fall further after 1 August 1986 when US cotton stocks are due to be released onto the world market under the new US cotton program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to question No. 3272 (Hansard, 18 March 1986, page 1558) does he continue to claim that the only way impure or unsafe imported food products can be checked and, if necessary, stopped from entering Australia, is by the passage by the States of a Model Food Act and then establishing uniform regulations through a National Food Standards Council.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a reply of the Prime Minister to a question, without notice (Hansard, 8 May 1986, page 3395) where it is stated that the Australian Customs Service has the power to monitor and stop food imports; if so, how does he reconcile his claim with the response of the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have not claimed that impure or unsafe imported food products can be checked and if necessary, stopped from entering Australia by the passage by the States of a Model Food Act and by establishing uniform regulations through a National Food Standards Council. These latter mechanisms are designed to achieve uniformity on food law throughout Australia and do not constitute the basis on which the Federal Government can take direct action regarding all imported foodstuffs. Uniformity does however provide the basis for further consideration of the need for and the means of implementing such action.

(2) Under the Customs Act and the Quarantine Act certain foodstuffs can be made subject to checking and possible banning as prohibited imports. Item 23 of the Third Schedule of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations specifically deals with radioactive materials.

The Prime Minister's reply to which the honourable member refers related specifically to foodstuffs potentially contaminated with radioactive material from the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident. These foodstuffs may come under the relevant Customs Regulations and are therefore liable to checking and prohibition.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Domiciliary Nursing Care: Electoral Division of Corangamite

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

(3) How is the benefit determined.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Expenditure in the 1984-85 financial year for Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit (DNCB) paid to beneficiaries in the Electoral Division of Corangamite is estimated at $233,516.
(b) Expenditure in the 1985-86 financial year is estimated at $250,186.
(2) During the 1985-86 financial year there were an estimated 230 people in receipt of DNCB in the Electoral Division of Corangamite.

(3) The National Health Act (NHA) provides for the payment of DNCB at a rate of $42 per fortnight to approved people who care for patients at home. The NHA does not allow for any payment additional to the standard rate of DNCB.
Payment of DNCB is made to approved persons where the person receiving care:
is at least 16 years of age;
is residing in the same rsidence as the applicant;
is being cared for on a continuing basis by the applicant;
is suffering from a chronic illness, disease or disability which would require admission to a nursing home if home care was not available; and

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department supply estimates to the National Drug Summit that over 16,600 Australians die each year as a result of diseases attributable to the use of tobacco.

(2) Is it a fact that the 1977 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled `Drug Problems in Australia' estimated that 10% of all deaths in Australia are attributable to diseases resulting from the use of tobacco.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department provided estimates to the National Drug Summit indicating that 16,620 Australians died in 1983 as a result of diseases attributable to use of tobacco. These figures were estimated from data supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) using indices described by Drew (L. R. H. Drew, Death and Drug Use in Australia, 1969 to 1980, Technical Information Bulletin 69, pp. 1-44). The figures were incorporated in an information document by my Department, `Statistics on Drug Abuse in Australia', for use in association with the Special Premiers' Conference held in April 1985.

(2) The precise reference in the conclusions of the 1977 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was that . . .`there is an overwhelming weight of evidence that tobacco causes ill health. Perhaps 10 per cent of all deaths are attributable to it' (p. 103). No information was given of the methodology used in arriving at this figure.

However, since 1982, the methodology developed by Dr L. R. H. Drew has been applied to mortality data supplied by the ABS for the determination of deaths attributable to the use of a particular drug. Using this methodology my Department estimated the number of deaths attributable to tobacco use. When this method is applied to the mortality data for 1977, the estimate of deaths attributable to tobacco is 14.7% of all deaths.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Uranium Information Centre (UIC) conducted by Australian mining companies involved in uranium mining and exploration.

(2) Has the UIC, in its official publications, (a) favourably referred to or (b) been critical of, the Soviet nuclear power industry or the safety of Soviet nuclear power industry or the safety of Soviet nuclear reactors.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the UIC newsletter Number 3 of March 1986 which discusses the USSR's latest 5 year plan to increase nuclear power's share of total electricity supply from the present 10-11% to over 20% and which opines that the problems encountered earlier in implementating the Soviet nuclear power program have now been largely overcome.

(4) Does he agree that the Chernobyl accident should lead nuclear scientists and the nuclear power industry, including the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, to be more self-critical about the future of nuclear power.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Uranium Information Centre (UIC) is a non profit organisation established and funded by a number of companies associated with uranium exploration and mining in Australia. The published aims of the Centre include:
providing information about the development of the Australian uranium industry, and

promoting a flow of factual information on all aspects of the mining and processing of uranium, the role of nuclear energy in supplying part of the world's electricity needs and the associated nuclear fuel cycle.
The UIC publishes a Newsletter which largely consists of factual material drawn from other publications.
(2) The UIC is not a Government body and consequently I am unaware of all the views it may have expressed in its official publications.
(3) My attention has been drawn to the article in question which, I note, was written before the Chernobyl accident.

(4) I imagine that nuclear scientists, both in Australia and abroad, will take a close professional interest in the causes and outcome of the Chernobyl accident, and that future statements they make will reflect this.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken by the Tasmanian and Victorian State Governments towards an extension of their fishing waters limits from 3 to 20 miles.
(2) If either Government has sought such an extension, on what date did the Minister receive the application.
(3) If he had such an application for over 3 weeks, why has the decision been delayed.
(4) Have Bass Strait scallop fishing operators indicated whether they favour or oppose extension of the limits.
(5) Were talks held with the industry early in 1985 in which the Victorian fishing operators agreed to 20 mile control if it were implemented properly and if a single licence was issued.
(6) Have either of the conditions referred to in the previous part been implemented by the Federal or State Governments.
(7) Would next season's licences normally have been issued by May; if so, can he say what has been the reason for the delay in the issue in both Federal and State licences.
(8) What efforts has he made to gauge industry opinion on the issue of extending State fishing waters for the scallop industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) (3) and (6) The Commonwealth, Victorian and Tasmanian Governments announced the introduction of new management arrangements for the Bass Strait scallop fishery on 6 June 1986.

The Ministers announced in conjunction with these arrangements the implementation of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement (OCS) for the scallop and tuna fisheries. The two States had requested a delay in opening of the scallop fishery until the OCS was implemented. The change in fisheries jurisdiction under the OCS involved detailed negotiations with the States and industry and preparation of complex technical and legal documents. Implementation of the OCS for scallops was complicated further by the Victorian Government's review of fisheries licensing arrangements.

Under the new arrangements the areas generally within 20 nautical miles of each State as defined by the base lines will be managed as State fisheries by each State Government. The remainder of the fishery or the Central Zone will be managed with the joint agreement of the Victorian and Tasmanian Governments. This zone will continue to be administered under Commonwealth law with both States accepting responsibility for the cost of management and the surveillance of this zone. The Commonwealth, at the request of both States reopened the Central zone on 12 June.

(4) (5) and (8) The Commonwealth fully consulted the Victorian and Tasmanian Governments and the industry from each State before proceeding to implement the new arrangements in the Bass Strait scallop fishery.
Port meetings with the industry were conducted in October 1984.
From June 1984 the main avenue for industry consultation was through the six industry representatives on the nine member Bass Strait Scallop Task Force.

In June 1985 the 20 nautical mile State fisheries zones were proposed by the States and industry representatives on the Task Force. The Task Force recommended at that time that access to the State Zones be limited to those vessels with State scallop licences. In July 1985, Commonwealth and State Ministers meeting in the Australian Fisheries Council accepted the Task Force Recommendations.

(7) State fisheries authorities act as agents for the Commonwealth in the issue of Commonwealth Fishing boat Licences. Commonwealth licences are issued annually and the actual date of issue is dependent upon the date of receipt of each application and the time required to process those applications. Licences are usually issued by Victoria during April and May each year and licences usually issued by Tasmania in February and March each year. It is understood that there have been unforeseen administrative delays in issuing licences in each State. These delays are being overcome and all licences should be issued shortly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Supporting Parent Beneficiaries with Spouses in Prison

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many spouses of women on supporting parents benefits were (a) on unemployment benefit, (b) convicted and in prison (c) on remand in prison for each year from 1982 to 1985.
(2) In respect of these spouses, how many have no known address according to the records maintained in his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What impact is the low waterfront productivity having on the cost of imports and exports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's waterfront operations appear in many cases to be less efficient and productive than comparable port and terminal operations abroad.

In recognition of the importance of transport and handling costs in Australia's export and import trades, my colleague the Honourable Peter Morris, Minister for Transport, established in September 1984 a Task Force on Shore-Based Shipping Costs to examine and report on means for reducing costs and removing bottlenecks in the shore-based industry.
The Task Force is expected to finalise its report shortly. Its two interim reports have identified a large array of problem areas.

It is difficult to measure to cost impact of current waterfront productivity levels on imports and exports with any accuracy. The bulk of these costs are met by shipping companies and are included in sea freight rates. They are not separately charged or identified in the customer's bill. However, the proportion of door to door costs attributable to shore-based operations both here and overseas is estimated to be in the order of 50 per cent and rising to 70 per cent in some instances. Given a total bill for shipping Australia's bulk and liner imports and exports of about $6 billion in 1984-85, shore based costs could account for over $3 billion. For containerised liner export cargo, the total cost of transport and handling, from exporter's premises to ship, has been estimated at $230 million annually.

In the Prime Minister's economic statement which accompanied his recent Address to the Nation, the Prime Minister referred to a number of reports on transport and handling costs and the need to examine them in an integrated way to identify action to remove impediments to trade. It is expected that the Government will be looking closely at waterfront costs as part of that examination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the effects of the fringe benefits tax on local government councils, particularly councils in remote and isolated areas.
(2) Will the effect of the tax add to their difficulty of achieving a balanced Budget in the light of reductions in the grants to local governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government appreciates that the fringe bene-fits tax could adversely affect a number of local governments and that local governments in more isolated areas may be particularly disadvantaged. However, a tax of this nature universally affect all sectors of government and business community, and makes a case for special exemptions difficult to argue.

As you would be aware, recent amendments to the proposed fringe benefits tax legislation have significantly reduced the amount of tax payable for the private component of motor vehicle use and for subsidised travel and housing in remote areas. Local Government, particularly in isolated areas will benefits greatly from these changes.

Meanwhile, to the extent that the fringe benefits tax imposes a disability on individual councils, particularly isolated councils, I would expect that such disabilities would be fully taken into account by State Local Government Grants Commissions in assessing allocations of Commonwealth general purpose financial assistance.
Because of the importance of this tax to isolated councils I have asked my Department to keep under review the effects of its implementation on councils.

(2) Further to the answer to (1), legislation passed in the Autumn session, the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act, will allow Commonwealth general purpose funds for Local Government to be increased in 1986-87 and 1987-88 either to maintain the same real terms or to equal the percentage increase in general financial assistance being provided to the States. The formula chosen will be that which provides the best result for Local Government.

As a consequence of decisions made on the level of general purpose assistance to the States at the June 1986 Premiers' Conference, Local Government will receive the same real terms funds in 1986-87 as it did in 1985-86. In comparison, grants to the States will decrease by 1.7% in real terms.
This is a very favourable result for Local Government under current economic circumstances where all governments will have considerable difficulty in balancing their budgets.

In 1984-85, the Program was extended to all States and the Northern Territory and targeted regions were selected in consultation with the State and Northern Territory Governments. Applications dealing with local housing assessment, training, research and information were accepted from throughout Australia.

In 1985-86, the Program became the fully fledged Local Government Development Program and guidelines, application forms and publicity material were sent in September/October 1985 to every Local Government authority and regional groupings of such authorities in Australia.

(11) Individual residents are not eligible for grants under the Local Government Development Program. However, I issued a media release on 10 September 1985 about the Program which was circulated to regional and local media.

My Department produces a booklet titled ``Commonwealth Assistance for Local Projects'' which contains details of Commonwealth assistance for projects at the local level, including under the Local Government Development Program. Booklets for the 1984-85 and 1985-1986 financial years were distributed very widely including to all Local Government authorities.

(12) Information concerning grant availability and eligibility will continue to be drawn to the attention of all Local Government bodies throughout Australia. It is not intended to arrange public advertising of the Local Government Development Program, since members of the general public are not eligible for funding under the Program.

(13) Information on grant availability and eligibility for future Programs will be provided to all Local Government authorities by direct mail, in sufficient time to enable them to apply for assistance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 17 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he provide details of the censorship standards that apply to the ABC.
(2) Have the standards changed over the last 5 years; if so, what are the details of the changes.
(3) Are the standards of censorship different to those for commercial stations; if so, what are the differences.
(4) What are the procedures for public complaints concerning censorship of ABC programs.
(5) How many complaints concerning censorship did the ABC receive in each of the years 1982 to 1985.
(6) What are the details of the complaints.
(7) What action has the ABC taken to deal with the complaints.
(8) Do the censorship standards of the ABC meet the requirements of the Government; if not, what improvements will be made to rectify the situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based in part on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The honourable member's question asks specifically about censorship standards and their relationship to the ABC. The matter of censorship is properly viewed as an integral part of a broader process of assessment and classification. I do not consider that it is a particularly useful approach to single out the censorship aspect of the process and the remainder of this answer is predicated on the principles involved in program standards.

Under Section 6 (1) (a) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (the ABC Act) the ABC is required to ``provide within Australia innovative and comprehensive broadcasting and television services of a high standard.'' Section 6 (2) (a) (iii) of the ABC Act also provides that the ``Corporation shall take account of . . . the standards from time to time approved by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in respect of broadcasting and television services''.
Under Section 118 of the Broadcasting Act 1942, the ABC is prohibited from broadcasting ``matter which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene.''
The ABC has also produced the document, ``Program Policies and Practices for ABC Radio and Television'' for the guidance of staff. A revised edition of this document is now in preparation.
For locally-produced material, production departments are required to refer the product to the appropriate officers within the ABC where doubt exists as to the classification of a program.
May be televised at any time.
May be televised between 0830 and 1600 and between 1930 and 0600 weekdays and 1930-0600 Saturdays and Sundays.
May be televised between 1200 and 1500 and 2030 and 0500 weekdays and 2030-0500 Saturdays and Sundays.
`PGR' and `AO' programs must not be telecast between 0830 and 1600 or 1200 and 1500 during school holidays.
(2) The censorship standards that apply to the ABC remain as they have been over the past 5 years.

(3) As an independent statutory authority, the ABC has the responsibility for determining its programming policies and practices in accordance with the legislative provisions detailed in part (1) of this answer.

Commercial licensees are required by Section 99 (1) of the Broadcasting Act 1942 to ensure that ``as far as practicable, the programs are in accordance with standards determined by the Tribunal''. The ABC is required by section 6 (2) (a) (ii) of the ABC Act to take account of those standards. While the ABC advises that it very largely observes the ABT's standards, it is not limited by them. In fact, the ABC's charter bestows on the Corporation considerable scope in the choice of programs for broadcast as well as the responsibility for ensuring that the programs are of a ``high standard''.
All broadcasters are subject to the prohibition on the broadcasting of blasphemous, indecent or obscene matter. This is provided for in Section 118 of the Broadcasting Act.

(4) People who wish to complain about a particular radio or television program may write to the ABC. Assertions of minor infringements are referred to the appropriate executive. Where there are more serious accusations or where a complainant is dissatisfied with the ABC's response, the matter is referred to the senior executive of the ABC Department concerned. In extreme cases the senior executive may decide that a case warrants notification to the Managing Director for advice. It is usual that a response, generally from the appropriate senior program executive, is made to the complainant.

(5) and (6) Complaints in relation to censorship vary greatly from questions of taste in the use of language, in the presentation of social issues in comedy programs, to questions of law as to whether a program was indecent or obscene. These complaints are addressed variously to the ABC's Head Office, its State branches or to the program makers themselves. There is no index or other system available to retrieve these specific types of complaints from the very large volume of audience correspondence the ABC receives, other than a long and expensive manual search of all corporate, State, program department and archival files.

(7) The action taken to deal with the complaints would always include at a minimum the forwarding of the complaint to the head of the department responsible for the program for reply to the complainant. In more serious cases, if the circumstances warranted, an apology may be made and action taken to avoid repetition.
As indicated at point 4 there is provision by the ABC for complaints of major significance to be processed and dealt with at the highest executive level.

(8) There are a number of legislative provisions relating to program standards which the ABC is required to comply with or to take account of. The Government believes that this legislative framework, together with the ABC's own internal program policies and practices as noted in points 4 and 7, provides an adequate basis for ABC's programs to conform to community standards and expectations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 17 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Telecom Australia have a monopoly over the Telecommunications wiring of all premises; if not, in what circumstances does Telecom allow its customers to wire their own premises.
(2) What customers are wiring their own premises and under what Telecom requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under Section 94 (2) (g) of the Telecommunications Act 1975, a person may install and operate a communications installation on his own land. This authorisation extends to the cabling of premises. However, if the cabling is to be connected to and become part of the public telecommunications network, Telecom has extensive powers under the Act to require the cabling of premises to meet technical and other conditions, and to undertake such cabling itself.
Cabling of premises for telecommunication services is best considered in terms of:
In relation to (a), Telecom allows major cabling projects and projects in remote areas, on a case by case basis, to be undertaken by the property owner or a competent contractor on his behalf.

In relation to (b), for premises such as large commercial, industrial or residential buildings or complexes which require a permanent cabling system for the reticulation of telecommunications services, Telecom's current policy provides that the building be cabled on behalf of the owner by Telecom or by cabling contractors empowered by Telecom.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any licences been granted since the Supplementary Licence Scheme was introduced to expand regional radio; if not, why not.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No supplementary licences or new independent licences have been granted as a result of the Supplementary Licence Scheme.

The Supplementary Licence Scheme was proposed by the previous Government and then later endorsed by this Government. Unfortunately, the Scheme has proved to be complex and quite unproductive in terms of new services. In my statement to the House of 20 May 1986 I announced the Government's plans for expediting the introduction of additional commercial television services in regional areas. I also announced that provisions for supplementary television licences would be deleted from the Broadcasting Act 1942, but emphasised that this will not necessarily apply to the provisions for supplementary radio licences.
(2) Some companies interested in applying for commercial radio licences have claimed that delays involved in the present procedures are making it difficult for them to maintain interest.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States of America: Nuclear-Powered Warships

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer given by his predecessor to question No. 5096 (Hansard, 21 October 1982, page 2479) stating that the United States does not release information as to the capacity of the reactors aboard its nuclear-powered warships, is this still the position of the United States Government; if not, what is its position.

(2) If the United States Government position is unchanged (a) what are the relevant Australian authorities referred to and (b) what are the specific sources used by these authorities to draw conclusions as to whether any given nuclear-powered warship exceeds the 100 MW limit in the absence of official advice from the Government responsible for the warship.

(3) Are the assessments made by the relevant authorities referred to accurate; if so, does this result in a lack of practical significance of the United States policy on October 1982 because independent accurate assessments can be made by nations such as Australia.
(4) If the assessments are not accurate what steps have been taken or will be taken to ensure that a reliable assessment can be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is still the policy of the United States Government to withhold information about the capacity of the nuclear reactors on its warships. I would draw to the honourable member's attention that the general conditions under which United States nuclear-powered warships (NPWs) are permitted to enter Australian ports were amended in late 1982 (Hansard, 8 December 1982, pp 3078-3079) following further assessment of information available on United States warships with reactors larger than 100 MW. Pursuant to this amendment it is no longer the case that vessels with reactors larger than 100 MW are excluded from the general conditions of entry, and the relevant Australian authorities are now required only to ensure that visiting NPW's are berthed in locations which comply with the strict environmental and safety regulations.
(2) (3) and (4) See my answer to (1) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost of training a RAAF pilot.
(2) What percentage of RAAF pilots resign from the defence forces to take up employment in commercial aviation.
(3) Is he able to say whether most candidates for employment as commercial pilots in Australia, other than ex-RAAF pilots, obtained their flight qualifications with personal funds.
(4) What percentage of (a) RAAF pilots and (b) persons currently undergoing RAAF flight training are female.
(5) Is he able to say whether a growing number of US military pilots are female despite the fact that women are barred from serving in combat roles in the US defence forces.

(6) Does he support the Government's initiatives toward providing equal employment opportunities for women; if so, is it necessary that the Government itself play an exemplary role in achieving the goal.
(7) Would a wider role for women in Australian military aviation ultimately have beneficial consequences for women in commercial aviation.
(8) What steps will he take to enhance opportunities for women to become RAAF pilots.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately $1.14m to wings standard; i.e. qualified to commence operational training.

(2) Based on available information, some 3% of the RAAF pilot population are known to have taken up appointments in commercial aviation during 1985. The actual percentage could be slightly higher as Defence Force personnel, when they resign, are not obliged to furnish details about their future employment.
(3) This is a matter which is beyond the responsibility of the Minister for Defence. No information is held by my Department upon which an answer could be based.
(5) There are women pilots in the USAF performing non-combat flying roles. Detailed statistics are not readily available in Australia.
(7) Until Australia has some experience of women employed in military aviation, I am not able to state whether this would have beneficial consequences for women in commercial aviation.

(8) See my answer to question without notice on `Australian Defence Force: Women' (Hansard, House of Representatives, 5 June 1986 pp 4664-5). The Defence Force is proposing to open a small number of aircrew positions to women in 1987 without significant detriment to the present male aircrew to aircraft ratio required to meet combat requirements should the need arise. The actual number of positions, which will be available on a merit basis, is still under consideration but it is expected they will include pilots, navigators and loadmasters.

(2) Is he able to say whether following the ratification of the legislation, at least 76 academicians have been dismissed to 18 March 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

(2) What provision has been made to stem vandalism.
(3) Have any successful prosecutions been launched against vandals proven guilty of the destruction of public telephone facilities since 1983-84.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A separate account of the costs incurred in repairing public telephone booths after vandalism is not kept. However, it is estimated that on a national basis the annual cost of vandalism would run into many millions of dollars.

(2) Considerable effort and expense is devoted to the development of instruments and cabinets which will resist damage and discourage the activities of vandals. Recent improvements include armoured handset cords, steel dials and toughened handsets. A strengthened coin safe has also been developed and is currently being trialled. Public Telephones which are the subject of repeated vandalism are placed under surveillance in order to apprehend offenders. To assist this process there is close liaison and co-operation with State Police Departments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes have been made in the Government's foreign policy towards allies who have nuclear arms since the acceptance of a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone by Australia.
(2) What changes have been made in the level of support given to other South Pacific nations that have declared their ports to be nuclear free.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) None. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty does not require any change in Australian policies towards other countries, including allies. On the contrary, the legal obligations it establishes are consistent with the policies of the Australian Government. That the Treaty also accords with the policy of other South Pacific Forum Member countries is indicated by the fact that it was collectively drafted and the text subsequently endorsed by the Forum and that ten of the thirteen Member countries of the Forum have already signed it.

(2) No changes have been made in the level of support given by Australia to other South Pacific nations. The SPNFZ Treaty explicitly upholds the sovereign right of each Party to decide for itself such questions as visits to its ports and airfields by foreign ships and aircraft. Transit rights for ships and aircraft in accordance with customary international law are fully respected by the Treaty.
