ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Racist Literature on Australia Post Pillar Boxes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that several Australia Post pillar boxes in Melbourne have adhered to them printed slogans stating ``An Asian Australia? Never!'' and ``Australia's Future: An Asian Refugee Dumping Ground. Keep Australian European'' and bearing an invitation to act by contacting National Action PO Box 346, Fitzroy 3605, phone 654 4262; if so, what action has (a) he, (b) Australia Post and (c) appropriate law enforcement agencies taken against those responsible for printing and distributing this literature.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by Australia Post, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Racist slogans were adhered to some Australia Post street posting boxes in the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road area and in the Carlton South and Central Business District areas.
(a) (b) and (c). I first became aware of this matter when the honourable member asked this question.

Police authorities advised Australia Post of the slogans in the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road area in October 1985. Police later charged two offenders with bill posting and their case was heard in the Ferntree Gully Magistrates Court on 22 May 1986. An Australia Post Officer was required to attend the Court to attest that there is no provision for any signs or posters, other than those of an official nature, to be affixed to street posting boxes. The offenders were found guilty and fined.

When racist slogans were noticed on some street posting boxes in the Carlton South and Central Business District areas, an Australia Post representative contacted a member of National Action who advised that members of that group had become aware that it was illegal to place any slogan, other than that of an official nature, on a street posting box. Since that contact was made, no futher slogans have appeared.
Australia Post removed those slogans already in place as soon as they were detected.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: AM and FM Radio Frequency Planning Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Com- munications, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many staff of his Department are engaged in AM and FM radio frequency planning and the technical aspects related to that planning.
(2) Have some of these staff refused to move to Canberra when required to; if so, to what extent has this caused delays in the expansion of radio services to regional Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are a total of approximately 28 clerical and engineering staff engaged in a variety of activities which relate, either directly or indirectly, to planning associated with the development of AM and FM radio services.

Apart from staff involved in detailed planning related to the introduction of new licensed stations or to essential changes to the technical parameters of existing stations, appreciable resources are devoted to planning for the ABC's Second Regional Radio Network (SRRN) and functions such as the definition of service areas for all radio stations. To this list must be added such functions as the development of a National VHF Channel Allocation Plan, the related problem of clearing television services from Band II, and contributions to the Forward Development Unit's studies in relation to ``Future Directions for Commercial Radio''.

(2) Yes. A number of engineering and other staff involved in the planning of individual stations elected not to move from Melbourne when decisions on relocation were taken in December 1984. In the interim, while some of these staff remained in Melbourne, every effort has been made to make full use of their experience and skills. Naturally, the loss of experienced planning staff and the need to recruit and train their replacements, has had an impact on the Department's capacity to plan new services in all sectors, not just in the area of AM and FM radio.

On 20 May 1986, I informed the House that planning for the expansion of television services was my Department's highest priority, and that no new projects would be undertaken until planning for television equalisation was well advanced.

Quite apart from delays related to the availability of planning resources, the introduction of new radio services in regional areas is, in many cases, very much constrained by the need to move television services from channels 3, 4 and 5 (collectively known as Band II) to new channels, so that channels for FM radio services can be made available. This is a complex and time consuming task.

Delays to radio planning which result from the loss of Melbourne staff are unlikely to determine the opening dates of new services because, until the clearance of television services from Band II is well advanced, there will not be enough FM channels available to accommodate new radio services.

Planning for the relocation of television services presently using channels 3, 4 and 5 is closely related to planning associated with television equalisation. Both tasks are given high priority and are thus being progressed in parallel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the real value in 1986 US dollars of each International Development Association (IDA) replenishment and what amount is planned for the next replenishment.
(2) Which countries have argued for real cuts in replenishments in (a) 1984-85 and (b) 1987-89 relative to 1981-83 and what reasons did they give for their position.
(3) What is the Government's position on the new IDA replenishment and what are the reasons for it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The real value in 1986 US dollars of each International Development Association (IDA) replenishment is:
(b) The IDA-8 replenishment level is still under negotiation. The negotiations began in January 1986 and are expected to be finalised later this year.
At the most recent IDA Deputies meeting in Washington on 7-8 April 1986 there was widespread support by virtually all delegates for an IDA-8 replenishment of $US12.0 billion.

(2) (a) As the United States is the major donor to IDA its attitude is crucial for the total level of a replenishment. For IDA-7 (fiscal years 1985-87) the United States indicated that it would not take up more than a 25 per cent share of the replenishment and would not contribute more than $US750 million per annum. This implied to other donors a maximum replenishment of $US9 billion. Other donors, including Australia, expressed disappointment at a possible $US9 billion replenishment, which they considered gravely inadequate, but in view of the pressing urgency to reach an agreement allowing the replenishment to start on 1 July 1984, they finally accepted a replenishment at this level.

It should be noted that donors other than the United States established a Special Facility for Sub-Saharan African which subsequently reached $US1.4 billion. The United States later made a contribution to this Facility. Australia made an additional voluntary contribution of $A60 million to IDA-7 in lieu of contributing to the Special Facility, and in recognition of the needs of all IDA recipients for concessional resources.

(b) As indicated, IDA-8 is under negotiation and no level has yet been agreed. However, many donors, including Australia, have indicated that they would prefer a higher replenishment figure than $US12 billion; they have coalesced around this figure because it represents the level to which it is hoped all donors, including the United States, might eventually agree to contribute reasonable shares.

The United States initially considered IDA-8 should be $US9 to 12 billion but at the April 1986 IDA Deputies' meeting United States representatives were hopeful that the United States Government would be able to endorse a figure for IDA-8 in the $US10.5 to 12 billion range.
(3) Australia has supported an IDA-8 replenishment of $US12 billion given the continuing need of IDA recipients for concessional resources.

Australia has been a longstanding, strong supporter of IDA, which it believes represents an efficient and effective disbursement channel for our overseas aid. IDA has a global focus on the poorest countries and seeks to improve production and incomes through careful project investments tailored to the recipient countries' needs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether (a) there is growing concern in the USA about inadequate health and hazard warnings on many household products with regard to protection of users health from potential damage by insidious chemicals and (b) at least 4 US States require chronic and acute hazard warnings on many products such as paint, pottery and printing inks.
(2) If so, will he introduce similar warnings in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) I am not aware of any specific reports that quantify an increasing level of concern in the USA regarding inadequate health and safety warnings on household products. I am aware that there has been a general trend both in Australia and overseas for increased consumer information on hazardous products.

(b) My Department regularly reviews decisions of the US Federal Government that relate to the control of hazardous chemicals which are reported in the Federal Register. My Department, however, rarely receives information relating to the regulations of individual US States that might differ from the Federal position. Consequently my Department is not aware that four of these States require chronic and acute hazard warning labelling.

(2) In relation to the introduction of similar warnings in Australia, the labelling of potentially hazardous chemicals is the responsibility of State and Territory authorities, usually under Poisons Legislation. For the past 30 years the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee (DPSC), consisting of representatives of all States, Territories and the Commonwealth has examined the hazard and consequent labelling requirements of many household chemicals. DPSC has consistently taken the view that the public is protected by the proper scheduling of such substances. The more hazardous a substance is, the more restrictive its scheduling. Associated with a more restrictive schedule are restrictions on availability, requirements for warning statements and relevant instructions on proper use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am unaware of any approaches by the Queensland Fire Services Association to the Toowoomba Fire Brigade on this matter.

(2) On 3 October 1985, the Commanding Officer of the Australian Army Base Support Unit at Oakey approached the Chief Officer of the Toowoomba Fire Brigade with a proposal for close liaison and mutual cooperation to effectively develop disaster assistance plans for the local area. The attachment of professional, fully trained Army Fire Service personnel to the Toowoomba Fire Brigade was envisaged and a reciprocal attachment of civilian fire fighters to the Base Support Unit fire station was offered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any scheme or arrangement for on the job training of Army personnel existed between the Oakey Base Support Unit and Toowoomba QATB (Ambulance) at any time since 1978; if so, was it related to the Australian Defence Force contingency plan for situations arising out of industrial action in essential services which he referred to in answer to my question No. 2942 (Hansard, 8 April 1986, page 1845).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A scheme for on the job training of Army personnel from the Oakey Base Support Unit has existed since April 1985 with the Toowoomba Ambulance Service.
The scheme consists of a rotating one month detachment of medical assistants from the Oakey Medical Centre to act as third member observers with the two member ambulance crews.
The scheme was started with union concurrence, and is purely of a training nature to give Army personnel exposure to real emergencies.
Similar schemes have been, or are, in existence in other areas and have the purpose of providing first hand experience at emergency work which, fortunately, is not regularly available on Army bases.
No scheme existed at Oakey from 1981 to April 1985, and prior to 1981, no information is available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

The Waramungu Land Claim was lodged on 20 November 1978, on the instructions of traditional owners, by Mr Tim Morris, an employee of the Central Lands Council. Land Councils, pursuant to s. 23 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 have statutory functions to receive instructions and lodge claims on behalf of traditional owners.

(2) The Aboriginal Land Commissioner, pursuant to s. 50 (1) (a) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, is required to ascertain whether Aboriginal Claimants are traditional owners. Aboriginals may also instruct any Land Council to discontinue a land claim action.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Code of Conduct for Australian Companies with Commercial Interests in South Africa

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Australian companies trading in South Africa have agreed to comply with the formal voluntary Code of Conduct to be observed by Australian companies with commercial interests in South Africa.
(2) Have any companies refused to comply with the Code; if so (a) which companies and (b) is he able to say how each company departs from the Code.

(3) Is he able to say whether the wages and conditions of overseas employees of these Australian companies differ (a) from (i) employees of the same companies in Australia (ii) those of other South African firms within the same industry groups and (b) between (A) black and white employees and (B) females and male employees.
(4) Can he say whether any of these Australian companies employ black workers who are separated from their families, live in single sex hostels and are employed on a contract basis.
(5) Can he also say which of these companies recognise representative black trade unions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable member will be aware, the voluntary Code of Conduct for Australian companies with commercial interests in South Africa came into effect on 29 November 1985. The Code applies to Australian companies if they or their subsidiaries employ non-white labour in South Africa. Monitoring of the level of corporate adherence to the Code is being undertaken independently by an Administrator for the Code, Mr Ron Bannerman, A.O., who will report his initial findings to parliament through the Minister for Foreign Affairs later in the Budget session.

Mr Bannerman, whose appointment took effect from 1 April 1986, has written to Australian companies with commercial interests requesting information on their activities in South Africa. The information supplied to Mr Bannerman which will form the basis of the Administrator's report is being provided by companies on a ``commercial in confidence basis''. Given the as yet preliminary stage of Mr Bannerman's investigation, the independent nature of his position, and the confidentiality of the information provided at this stage, I am unable to give a more specific response to the honourable member's question.

I can say, however, that so far there have been no indications that Australian companies will not cooperate with the Code. Both in my own consultations with the business sector, and in those Mr Bannerman has conducted since his appointment, the response has been one of understanding the reasons for the introduction of the Code and of acceptance of the desirability of cooperating with the Government to make it an effective instrument.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What drugs, chemical sprays or other noxious products banned in the United States of America or European Economic Community are available in Australia.
(2) Who distributes such products in Australia.
(3) What are these products used for.

(4) Is he able to say whether there are (a) US States and (b) EEC member countries where such products are banned or their use subject to restrictions; if so what (i) States and member countries (ii) is the nature of these bans or restrictions.
(5) Do these products have any restrictions placed on their use in Australia; if so (a) what restrictions and (b) do they differ from those imposed in the US or EEC.

(6) Is information about the banning of such products communicated to Commonwealth and State authorities; if so (a) how long does this communication process take and (b) is there provision for (i) urgent notification, when necessary and (ii) the notification of the public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to answer this question in terms of specific chemicals. The variability in regulations and interpretation of the term `banned' between countries makes keeping records of controlled substances in other countries an impossible task. The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has over the past few years attempted to develop such a list but with little success. Australia operates an independent clearance and assessment systems for drugs, agricultural chemicals and food additivies. Approval for use is based on the assessment of a comprehensive toxicological data package. Cognisance is also taken of the findings of other regulatory authorities and international organisations.
(2) As indicated in (1) above, it is not possible to identify individual products.

(6) An international agreement exists within both the OECD and UNEP to provide other members of regulatory decisions taken by another member. Consequently information about decisions taken by EEC countries and the USA is frequently communicated to Australia. In addition the USA also provides information to other countries of chemicals exported from the USA that are not permitted to be used in the USA.

(a) In the event that a regulatory decision is based on important new data indicating a new health risk from the use of the chemical, such information is usually communicated urgently to other countries, including Australia.

(b) (i) In the case of agricultural chemicals and drugs this information would be urgently considered by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) or Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) and any decision to control the chemical would be communicated to State authorities. For example, in 1977 information was communicated to Australia from the USA that a fungicide caused testicular effects and sterility in workers in the manufacturing plant. In addition animal studies indicated the compound to be a carcinogen. This information was considered by the NHMRC and within the space of 1-2 weeks the product had been rescheduled in all States and arrangements made to withdraw stocks from sale.

(b) (ii) Notification of the public by Commonwealth and State authorities would take place where there is considered to be an urgent need to cease use of the product immediately and to ensure that remaining stocks are withdrawn.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he state whether a Soviet trade delegation vistited a Kockums' shipyard in Sweden last year; if so, were members of the delegation given (a) construction or performance information related to the United Sterling motor, (b) information on any other technology involved in Kockums' submarine construction or operation and (c) information or material relevant to Kockums' participation in the RAN new submarine project definition study.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a report on this visit complied by (a) Mr R. Jonsson, head of security at a Swedish Defence Department establishment or (b) any other person; if so was a report submitted to (i) the Swedish Government or a Swedish Government department, (ii) the Australian Government or an Australian Government department, (iii) any other Government or official body of that Government and what action, if any, was taken as a result.

(3) Will he confirm the accuracy of a report that following this visit, a Soviet intelligence officer visited a Kockums' subsidiary plant in the United States to inspect Kockums' Sterling engine and that as a result, the Central Intelligence Agency alerted Swedish intelligence authorities.
(4) Is he able to confirm the accuracy of a report that the Soviet Union has developed a prototype engine similar or identical to the United Sterling design.
(5) Is the RAN considering the inclusion of a Sterling engine in the new submarine project as part of the project definition study or any other study.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am asured by Kockmuns AB of Malmo Sweden that no Soviet Trade Delegation visited the submarine section of the shipyard or United Stirling, a subsidiary of Kockums, last year or at any other time. I am assured by Kockums AB of Sweden that at no time has the Soviet Union been given access to information of a restricted or confidential nature. Kockums has a strict internal security system which protects the work being carried out for the Royal Australian Navy as well as Swedish projects. Though in the same area, the Stirling closed cycle engine facility is not part of Kockums AB. However it also has strict security procedures. The most recent visit of a Soviet delegation to that facility was one decade ago, when only material of a general commercial nature was discussed.

(2) The Soviets have not been given construction or performance information relating to the United Stirling closed cycle engine or any other technology involved in submarine construction or operational information, or material relevant to Kockums participation in the RAN New Submarine Project Definition Study.

(3) I am aware of the report by Mr R. Jonson and have a report from the Swedish Government on this matter. I am also aware of relevant newspaper articles written by Mr Carson, a journalist resident in Malmo Sweden. This may be the source of the information prompting the question.

(4) The subject of the Swedish Government report relates to an incident in the USA during a commercial development programme in 1974/5/6 of a Solar Powered Stirling engine system, not a United Stirling closed cycle engine for Submarines. A subsidiary of the Swedish FFV Company was developing the solar powered system with McDonald Douglas and a member of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, posing as an American Engineer, attempted to gain access to the plant at Alexandria, Virginia USA but was identified and asked to leave the plant without receiving any information whatsoever. I am not aware that the Soviet Union is developing a Stirling Closed Cycle Engine.

(5) The United Stirling closed engine is offered as an option in the Kockums 471 submarine under study for the RAN and is being considered for Auxiliary Air Independant propulsion. Like other diesel engines the United Stirling closed cycle engine is commercially available in various versions for fitting in such vehicles as motor transport, ships, and submarines etc.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information regarding diocesan, parish or individual church income is required by the Australian Schools Commission when an application is made by a Catholic School for a grant for a capital works program.
(2) What formula is used in determining recurrent grants to independent schools.

(3) What Federal funding, other than recurrent grants for staffing and grants for approved capital works programs, is available to independent schools and what formula is used in determining such funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since September 1985 the Department of Education has administered the Commonwealth's Capital Grants Program.

As successful applicants for a Commonwealth capital grant are generally expected to contribute to projects from their own resources, information is sought on the financial operations of a school and its supporting community. This information is used to determine the maximum capacity of a school to contribute to a capital project.

In some States, Catholic systemic primary schools operate as parochial schools. The parish is therefore responsible for assisting in the provision of the school's capital facilities. Information on the parish's financial operations is sought in order to assess the level of contribution that can be made towards a Commonwealth funded project at the school. In determining the parish's contribution towards the project, account is taken of existing and projected commitments to other parish projects. Where a school is supported by a number of parishes, as may be the case with Catholic systemic secondary schools, information is obtained from all supporting parishes.

In certain circumstances, a diocese may co-ordinate a program of capital works at all Catholic systemic schools within the diocese. In this instance, financial operations of the diocese may be taken into account in determining an overall contribution to the complete program.

Where parishes are not directly responsible for capital works at their schools, reliance is placed on the advice of the system authorities in determining a school's capacity to contribute to a project.

Catholic non-systemic schools are independent schools and are therefore solely responsible for both their capital and recurrent operations. Consequently, only the financial circumstances of the school are relevant in any consideration of the financial need for a grant.

(2) The Education Resources Index (ERI) is used to determine the funding category for non-government schools. The ERI compares a school's private income with a standard level of resources representing basic educational needs of schools.

Details of the General Recurrent Grants Program, including information on the establishment grants and the Short Term Emergency Assistance Scheme components of that Program, are provided in the publication `Commonwealth Programs for Schools, Administrative Guidelines for 1986'. Chapter 2 and Appendix A are particularly relevant. A copy of this document has been forwarded to Mr Wright.
(3) In 1986 some $47.7m is available specifically to non-government schools under five Commonwealth specific purpose programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission:
In addition, Commonwealth funding is available tor both Government and Non-Government schools under the following specific purpose programs, for which some $47.1m is available in 1986.
Detailed arrangements for these programs are contained in the publication referred to under (2).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) per unit and (b) overall cost of producing and distributing the maps used for air navigation in Australia.
(2) Does his Department sell the maps to pilots and other interested parties; if so, what is the (a) per unit cost and (b) overall income from this source.
(3) Is he or his Department considering revising the number and type of these maps.

(4) Is he or his Department considering incorporating much of the information presently on separate maps (for example, world aeronautical charts, visual en route charts, visual terminal charts) onto a single map, possibly along the lines of the United States' Sectional Aeronautical Chart; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aviation produces a variety of maps for use in air navigation in Australia. The answer to this part of the question is as follows:
Distribution costs are not included in respect of AIP/MAP and VFG/MAP as these items are combined with other Departmental publications to form composite distributions.
(2) (i) The Department sells WACs to pilots and other parties

(b) sales of WACs occur at numerous `Collector of Public Monies (CPM)' facilities throughout Australia. Proceeds from this source are paid into consolidated revenue along with other monies received-thus the overall income from WACs cannot be readily obtained.
(ii) The Department does not sell AIP/MAP or VFG/MAP to pilots. The MAP package appropriate to each licence category is provided free of charge to all pilots.
The Department sells AIP Complete and VFG Complete, both of which contain the respective MAP component, to other interested parties. It is not possible to extract individual figures for these items.
(3) The number and each type of chart is continually under review in order to accommodate the particular navigation requirements which follow the changes of air routes or Air Traffic Services units.
(4) No. The Department of Aviation believes that the individual charts mentioned in the question have quite specific uses which serve the industry better than would a combined chart.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What trade shows is Austrade organising for Australian exports in 1986-87.
(2) What is the estimated cost of each show.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 22 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in Australian Society of May 1986 entitled `Lies, damned lies and mining statistics' which reveals a $13m anomaly in Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for 1983-84 mining exploration expenditure.
(2) Is the Minister quoted accurately in the article; if not, how is the article inaccurate.
(3) Is it a fact that the Northern Territory Land Rights Act has contributed significantly to a slow down of Territory exploration activity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On 16 April 1986, the ABS published a corrigendum to the 1983-84 NT exploration statistics which said that the incorrect figures resulted from a compilation error by the ABS. I responded to the article in a letter published in Australian Society, June 1986 edition, page 4.

(2) The words in quotation marks are taken directly from my Press Release of 4 March 1986. Nevertheless the article is inaccurate in implying that the revision of the statistics casts doubt on the basis for the Government's decision of 3 March 1986 to amend the NT Aboriginal Land Rights Act. The level of NT exploration expenditure recorded by ABS, whether for 1983-84 or any other year since the NT Aboriginal Land Rights Act entered into force, relates almost solely to exploration activity on non-Aboriginal land because up until July 1986 no new exploration licences have been granted on Aboriginal land.

(3) Although the decline in international commodity prices, the Government's uranium policy and the NT Government's freeze on the processing of exploration licence applications on Aboriginal land have all tended to dampen mineral exploration activity in the NT, the operation of the NT Aboriginal Land Rights Act has been an important constraint on mineral exploration in the NT. While the NT Government lifted its freeze on the processing of exploration licence applications on Aboriginal land in June 1981 it is only now that the granting of the first new exploration licence on Aboriginal land appears imminent, following approval by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in July 1986 of an agreement between a mining company and the Northern Land Council. While the conclusion of this agreement is an important precedent the fact remains that 178 other exploration licence applications remain outstanding on Aboriginal land, and in all 32 other cases (previously 26 when I issued my Press Statement of 4 March) where consultations between companies, Land Councils and traditional Aboriginal landowners have been completed, consent to exploration on Aboriginal land has been refused.

I am advised that first year exploration commitments on currently outstanding exploration licence applications in Arnhem Land alone, all of which have been unable to proceed because negotiations have led to refusal of consent or are stalled, amount to at least $19.3 million.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines: Smoking Regulations in Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 22 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the policy of Trans Australia Airlines on the smoking of cigarettes by passengers while an aircraft is in flight.
(2) Where is this policy stated.
(3) What penalties are there for passengers not observing smoking regulations.

(4) What arrangements does TAA take to ensure minimal discomfort to non-smoking passengers from the smoke of smoking passengers and has any assessment been made of the effectiveness of these arrangements; if not, why not.
(5) What action can a non-smoking passenger take to avoid being affected from the smoke of a smoking passenger.
(6) In what circumstances can smoking passengers in areas designated for this purpose be requested to refrain from smoking.
(7) What percentage of seats are currently allocated to accomodate non-smoking passengers.
(8) Will he take steps to have the policy changed to ensure that the number of seats allocated are sufficient to accommodate all passengers requiring non-smoking accommodation; if not, why not.
(9) Has his attention been drawn to proposals by the United States Government to ban smoking on short-haul aircraft.
(10) Are there any proposals by TAA to ban smoking on flights of less than one hour duration; if not, will he undertake to have the feasibility of such a proposal investigated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows (parts 1, 2, 4 to 8 and 10 were prepared from advice received from TAA):

ANSWER.PARA: (1) TAA advises that its policy is to provide smoking and non-smoking seating zones with seating capacity as close as possible to the balance of preferences.
(2) TAA also advises that its policy of separate zones is made known when passengers check in and by inflight announcements shortly before or after take off.

(3) The Air Navigation Regulations (at ANR 246 (1) (a) and (b)) make certain provisions relating to smoking in aircraft in connection with safety issues. The Air Navigation Regulations (at ANR 312 (4)) also provide for a penalty of $2,500 or 6 months imprisonment or both for any breach of ANR's prosecuted summarily.

(4) TAA has advised that the cabin atmospheric control systems installed in its aircraft provide total air replacement at high frequency quickly removing smoke. The airline has also advised that passenger comments indicate the majority of non-smokers are satisfied with existing seating arrangements.
(5) Should the non-smoking passenger be affected due to seating arrangements, TAA advised that its flight attendants would assist to alter seating if appropriate.

(6) Smoking is completely prohibited while the ``non-smoking'' indicator is lighted. Under the Air Navigation Regulations, the pilot in command of an aircraft is required to ensure that a notice indicating that smoking is prohibited is displayed during take-off, landing and refuelling, during such periods as specified for the purpose in the aircraft's certificate or airworthiness or flight manual and during a period which he or she considers that smoking should be prohibited in the interests of safety. TAA advises that the pilots in command of its aircraft have full discretion as to the use of the ``non-smoking'' indicator. Smoking during periods when the ``non-smoking'' indicator is lighted involves a breach of the Air Navigation Regulations.
(7) The airlines' present general ratio of seat allocations to smoking/non-smoking is as follows:
EWA-16:84 on F27 aircraft; 14:86 on F28 aircraft.

I am advised by TAA that where possible that TAA non-smoking zone is extended if demand is expected to be excessive. Occasionally, the airline advises, not every non-smoking preference can be accommodated.

(8) Under current arrangements, allocation of non-smoking seats is a matter for the commercial judgment of the airlines. I announced on 5 March 1986 that in view of the continuing concern expressed by many people about the perceived effects of smoking in aircraft on their health and comfort, I considered it appropriate that an attempt should be made to achieve a more acceptable compromise between the views of smoking and non-smoking passengers.

For that reason I wrote to the domestic airlines seeking their reaction to a proposal that they move as a group to introduce a ban on smoking on flights of less than one and a half hours. Further consideration is being given to the matter.
(9) I am not aware of any current proposals by the US Government to ban smoking on short-haul aircraft.
(10) TAA has no current proposals to ban smoking on flights of less than one hour duration. See also answer to question 8.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Smoking Regulations in Public and Work Areas

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 22 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports that passive smoking or sidestream smoke can be extremely hazardous to the health of non-smokers.

(2) Is his Department responsible for developing guidelines and legislation on the regulation of smoking in Commonwealth Government work areas and on Commonwealth transport; if not, which department does have that responsibility.
(3) What guidelines and legislation exist to regulate smoking in Commonwealth buildings and transport.
(4) If no legislation exists, will he take the necessary steps to develop legislation to protect Commonwealth public servants against the hazards of passive smoking; if not, why not.

(5) What action has been taken by his Department in conjunction with the relevant State authorities to develop national guidelines for the regulation of smoking in public and work areas, including public transport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Also, the matter was considered by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) at its 101st Session in June 1986. The Council endorsed the Report of its Working Party on the Effects of Passive Smoking on Health and recommended certain policies be considered by health authorities to protect the health of non-smokers from passive smoking.

(2) to (4) Responsibility for development of guidelines and legislation on the regulation of smoking in Commonwealth Government work areas and on Commonwealth transport rests with the Public Service Board and the Department of Transport, respectively. My Department provides advice on the health risks of passive smoking as such advice is sought. Additional to this are the advice and recommendations of the NHMRC. However, the honourable member will be pleased to learn that, to protect the health of its employees from injury or illness arising from the workplace, and following consultations with management and union representatives, my Department will be extending existing smoke free areas to include all office space occupied by Departmental staff from 1 December 1986.

(5) My Department works closely with the State and Territory health authorities on this issue through avenues such as the Australian Health Ministers' Advisory Council and the Standing Committee of Officials of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy. It remains, however, a matter for each State and Territory to introduce regulations to control smoking in public places and work areas within their respective jurisdictions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Christmas Island: Establishment of Resort Complex with Casino

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a referendum been conducted on Christmas Island about the establishment of a gambling casino/hotel resort; if so, what was the result.
(2) Was an organised `YES' campaign conducted on the Island; if so, by whom.
(3) What will be the licensing arrangements if the Government decides to establish a casino.

(4) Will a casino licence only be granted after public tendering and inquiry, and assurances are received from tenderers through the lodgment of fidelity bonds, that the casino will operate without undesirable elements and stand-over tactics.
(5) What preference will be given to Australian interests at the tender stage.
(6) Will he publish an annual statement of all people associated with the casino company and all casino employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes, on 19 April 1986; (b) of 1172 people eligible to vote and present on Christmas Island, 955 voted; 896 voted yes, 49 voted no and 10 votes were informal.

(2) The referendum stemmed from Christmas Island Assembly deliberations. During an interview on Christmas Island Television when asked the reasons for the referendum and how to go about voting the Chairman of the christmas Island Assembly replied:

`Firstly, to confirm that the vast majority of Christmas Islanders want a hotel/casino on Christmas Island and hopefully that will show the Department of Territories that the community is overwhelmingly in favour of it and may speed things up.
What people are being asked to do-that is every island resident over the age of 18-to go to the Assembly hall between the hours of 9 a.m. and 6 p.m. Saturday and vote in the referendum.
If you are against the idea of a hotel/casino, vote NO. But, if you wish to remain on Christmas Island and make it your home for years to come I earnestly ask you to vote YES.'

3 to 6. The Government has agreed in principle to the establishment of a resort complex with a casino on Christmas Island, subject to development and approval of a detailed proposal which provides for adequate protection of Commonwealth, Island and environmental interests. The Government has also agreed that Western Australian businessman Mr Frank Woodmore, the proponent of the project, have first right of refusal to the development.

An important element of Mr Woodmore's proposal was that Federal Hotels be the operator of the casino element of the Christmas Island project. The Government has agreed that Federal Hotels be the casino operator.

Detailed arrangements regarding licensing and control of the casino operator have not yet been determined. However these issues will be addressed during detailed feasibility studies. The Government will require the strictest controls concerning management of the casino, licensing of casino employees, scrutiny of financial transactions etc. and detailed requirements will be laid down in specific legislation which will be introduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say what the Pilatus PC-9 total contract price is; if so, (a) is it fixed or is there an escalation clause; if so, what and (b) what currency is it expressed in.
(2) Can he say what the A10B WAMIRA total contract price is, if so, (a) is it fixed or is there an escalation clause; if so, what and (b) what currency is it expressed in.
(3) What proportion of the PC-9 acquisition cost, including project supervision, will be spent in (a) Australia, (b) Switzerland or (c) elsewhere.
(4) What proportion of the A10B WAMIRA acquisition cost, including project supervision, would have been spent in (a) Australia or (b) elsewhere.
(5) What Australian employment (a) will be created under the PC-9 contract and (b) would have been created under the A10B WAMIRA contract.
(6) How many design staff were employed in Australia on A10B WAMIRA development and what has happened to the design group.
(7) What is the basis of his claim that selection of the Pilatus PC-9 will reduce the pilot training budget by $20m a year.
(8) When will these projected savings occur.
(9) Will there be any restrictions on PC-9 operations at Point Cook and Sale training bases.
(10) Will the existing CT-4 basic trainer and Macchi advanced trainer continue in service; if so, in what role.
(11) What is the projected replacement date of the CT-4 and Macchi aircraft and to what degree will they be replaced by the PC-9.
(12) Is any action proposed to extend CT-4 and Macchi aircraft life; if so, (a) what action and (b) at what cost.
(13) Is any revision of the RAAF training program planned because of PC-9 acquisitions; if so, (a) what revision and (b) are any additional costs involved.
(14) Is the Pilatus PC-9 to be modified to meet RAAF training requirements; if so, (a) how and (b) at what cost.
(15) How many hours flying training (a) will be given to PC-9 pilot trainees and (b) were envisaged for the A10B WAMIRA trainees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $231m. It is to be a fixed price contract in Australian dollars, with escalation clauses for inflation and exchange rate variations and any changes arising from translation of drawings to English.
(2) There is no contract for production of the Wamira and so no contract price can be stated. The expenditure on design and development of the Wamira was about $74m.
(3) It is estimated that the expenditure on the Pilatus PC-9 will be in the following proportions; Australia 45%, Switzerland 24% and elsewhere 31%.

(4) It was estimated that, should the A10B WAMIRA project have progressed, 55% of the project cost would have been spent in Australia and the remainder overseas for the procurement of engines, avionics and other items.

(5) The PC-9 project is estimated to generate about 1.5 million manhours of work in Australia whilst the A10B WAMIRA project was estimated to generate just over 2 million manhours. Additional workload however, will be generated by the collaboration of the Australian aircraft industry with Pilatus in global sales of the PC-9 and the development of a new utility transport aircraft should we choose to enter this programme.
(6) At the peak of the A10 design work some 120 engineers were involved. Some 75% of these engineers are still employed in the Australian aircraft industry.
(7) The higher performance of the PC-9 offers the potential for savings by reducing student flying hours in the more expensive MACCHI advanced trainer.
(10) Yes, in the general roles they now perform. A review of the pilot training syllabus and the respective aircraft's roles is planned.

(11) Replacements for the CT4 and the Macchi are not envisaged until the late 1990's. The RAAF study into pilot training will determine the final breakdown of flying hours between the three aircraft but the current 140 hours spent by students on the Macchi advanced trainer will be reduced considerably by the introduction of the cheaper to operate Pilatus PC-9.
(12) It is not proposed to take any action to extend the life of these aircraft.
(13) Yes. Less student flying time will be spent on the more expensive MACCHI aircraft.
(14) Yes. The cost of modifications is about $2.5m. The major modification is to the under carriage to give a soft field landing ability.

(15) The A10 WAMIRA project was based on a pilot training syllabus of 100 hours WAMIRA and 100 hours MACCHI. As previously stated, the training syllabus will be subject to review when the PC-9 enters service.

(11) No, but the aircraft we will acquire will substantially meet the requirements of the Air Force.
(12) The PC-9 acquired by the RAAF will have enlarged low pressure tyres to enable it to land on soft fields. The cost of all modifications is about $2.5m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he, at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities, request the Council to give priority to putting in place a range of more effective sanctions to deal with `pin-strip crime'.

(2) Has he investigated the desirability of instituting (a) corporate community service orders where a convicted company may be required to perform, as an organisation, some work of community service relevant to its expertise, (b) corporate probation where an officer of the government may be appointed to supervise implementation of corporate reforms specified by the sentencing judge, (c) publicity orders where a court may require an offending company to place advertisements in mass media outlets advising the public of the company's offence or offences and (d) equity fines where a company may be required to issue new shares to a victim compensation fund.
(3) Will he introduce amendments to the Trade Practices Act to include punishments to fit major and minor corporate crime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The effectiveness of particular sanctions is a matter which receives on-going consideration by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. This has been reflected, for example, in the amendments contained in the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1985 restraining the directors of some insolvent companies from subsequently managing other companies. The matter will be discussed at the next meeting.

(2) Generally, Commonwealth legislation at present prescribes fines, imprisonment or fines and imprisonment for criminal offences. In the case of bodies corporate imprisonment is not a sentencing option. Some legislation also provides for pecuniary penalties and other remedies such as injunctions which can be applied to corporations. Publicity orders can be made under existing legislation such as the Trade Practices Act 1974 where the court considers such an order to be appropriate. The Australian Law Reform Commission is currently considering the appropriateness of sanctions such as corporate community service orders, corporate probation orders and equity fines and also whether the option of making publicity orders in relation to corporations which commit offences should be more generally available than at present. The Commission's final report on its reference concerning the sentencing of federal and ACT offenders is expected to be presented in 1987.
(3) It is considered that at this time the sanctions provided for in the Trade Practices Act 1974 are adequate in relation to both major and minor corporate crime.

The proposal has not yet been considered by the Commonwealth.
(2) Yes. The Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists withdrew its involvement because of administrative problems associated with the acquittal of grants spent by State Program Committees.

(3) The Commonwealth does not provide funds to Trachoma Committees in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria because there are no Committees operating in those States. In Victoria and New South Wales the incidence of Trachoma-related conditions is very low and any cases are treated by the normal health services. In Western Australia treatment of Trachoma-related conditions is carried out as part of a State funded and administered Aboriginal Eye Health program.
(4) The recently released Trachoma and Eye Health Report found that:
(a) The prevalence of follicular trachoma for people aged 19 years or less is estimated at 33.6 per cent for the 1985 Review, compared with 40.0 per cent for the original NTEHP 1976-77 screenings.

(b) After making allowance for the different age structure of the population examined in 1985, the standardised prevalence ratio for the combined Review communities is estimated at 83 for 1985, compared with 100 for the original 1976-77 screenings.
(c) The prevalence of severe follicular trachoma for people aged 19 years or less is estimated at 14.9 per cent for the 1985 Review, compared with 24.7 per cent for the original 1976-77 screenings.
(d) The standardised prevalence ratio for severe follicular trachoma is estimated at 60 for 1985, compared with 100 for the original screenings.
(e) The prevalence of trachomatous conjunctival scarring for people aged 19 years or less is estimated at 13.6 per cent for the 1985 Review, compared with 27.5 per cent for the original screenings.

(f) The prevalence of severe trachomatous conjunctival scarring for people aged 19 years or less is estimated at 3.4 per cent for the 1985 Review, compared with 8.3 per cent for the original screenings.
(5) During 1985 responsibility for a national Aboriginal health statistical system was transferred from the Department of Health to the Australian Institute of Health.

Following agreement between the Treasurer, the Ministers for Health and Aboriginal Affairs a Task Force on Aboriginal health Statistics was set up to work towards the establishment of the system. The Task Force consulted with State (except Queensland) and Territory officials responsible for relevant administrative by-product collections, to secure the identification of Aboriginals in collections of health and vital statistics.

Agreements made with State and Territory officials will result in Aboriginality being included as an identifier in most major health data collections, with negotiations continuing on the provision and collation of this data into a fully compatible national system.
The Department also examined how health statistical data might be obtained from AMSs so that Health profiles of Aboriginals using the local Aboriginal Medical Services might be established.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What kinds of petroleum products are used by the
(a) Australian Defence Force and his Department, and
(b) for what purpose is each used.
(2) What stocks were held on
(a) 1 July 1985 and
(b) at the date of answering this question in each category by each user.
(3) What were the 1985-86 budget estimates for
(a) quantity and
(b) value for usage for each category for each user.
(4) Have the estimates for 1985-86 been amended in view of the changes in the costs to the Government of petroleum products; if so what are the estimates at the date of answering this question.
(5) What was the cost to the Government of a litre of
(a) distillate and
(b) petrol on the first day of each month since 1 July 1985 until the date of answering this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The main kinds of petroleum products used by the Australian Defence Force and the Department of Defence are liquid fuels and lubricants. The liquid fuels take the form of aviation turbine fuel (AVTUR), aviation gasoline (AVGAS), motor spirit, automotive distillate and Naval distillate. In addition to these, Defence currently holds stocks of Furnace Fuel Oil and a range of lubricating oils. The liquid fuels account for the bulk of current Defence requirements.

(1) (b) The aviation fuels are used in the propulsion of aircraft, both fixed and rotary wing. Automotive distillate is used in the Army's track vehicles, eg tanks and armoured personnel carriers, as well as other operational transport and commercial type vehicles. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do trade union officials and corporate representatives who participate in Government trade delegations meet their own costs for travel and sustenance.
(2) If not, what is the basis of cost recovery on such delegations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In deciding the basis for trade union and corporate representation on Government trade delegations, the underlying principle adopted by the Department of Trade and the Australian Trade Commission is whether a direct commercial benefit accrues to the organisation which provides a representative. The costs of trade union representatives are normally borne by the Government since no direct commercial benefit to the unions is involved. However, the relevant trade union authorities and the Government may agree from time to time on cost sharing arrangements. For corporate representatives, the costs are borne by the Government where the purpose of the delegation is such that firms are unlikely to obtain direct benefits. However where a direct benefit is likely, such as when the Commission organises a selling mission to enable Australian companies to pursue individual export sales prospects, the corporate representatives are required to pay their own direct travel and sustenance costs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that (a) the taxiway improvement program at Sydney Airport will yield a 2% increase in flight movements and (b) a less expensive investment in new radar and computer identity flow control systems would yield a 15% to 20% increase; if so, why is the latter investment not being accelerated to reduce the holding cost and safety problems in peak periods.
(2) What are the estimated costs and movement improvements of each program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The taxiway improvement program will reduce runway occupancy times to provide for an estimated 2% increase in practical runway capacity. However, the primary aim of the program is to reduce taxiing distance for aircraft on the ground thereby producing not only savings in runway operation delay costs but substantial benefits to airlines from savings in aircraft taxiing costs.

(b) Safety is not being compromised at Sydney Airport. The only issue is the delay of aircraft and the resultant costs. I am advised that unfavourable weather, which affects the available runways and taxiway configurations, is the most likely cause of delay at Sydney, followed closely by noise abatement and wake turbulence procedures. While new radar displays would undoubtedly assist air traffic control, nevertheless, because of the constraints previously mentioned, there would only be a marginal increase in the maximum traffic handling rate of the ATC system.
Current plans are for the timely replacement of the air traffic control radar display system at Sydney as part of a national program.
(2) (a) Taxiway improvements are estimated to cost $19m (November 1985 prices) with expenditure spread over a three (3) year program.
(b) The estimated cost of new radar displays for the Sydney Terminal Area is $5.5m.

(b) Aggregate exports of commercial firearms and ammunitions by value were as follows: 1984-$4.1m; 1985-$4.9m; 1986 (first quarter)-$1.1m.

(c) The major destinations of these exports over that period were New Zealand ($2.6m), the Federal Republic of Germany ($1.6m), Singapore ($0.8m), France ($0.8m), Malaysia ($0.8m) and the United Kingdom ($0.7m).

(3) The export of firearms, including those for non-military purposes, and defence equipment from Australia is controlled under Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations of the Customs Act 1901.
The export of commercial firearms and ammunition will only be investigated if:
(a) the Government thinks that there is a possibility that the items may be diverted to military uses;
(b) there is some irregularity noted in export pro- cedures or handling;
(c) the Government receives information that a diversion to a military use is likely.

Yes. Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations have been amended to prohibit the export to South Africa of batons, clubs, riot sticks, body armour, computer hardware (including central processing units and associated printed circuit boards), handcuffs, leg irons, riot protection shields and whips (see Statutory Rules 1985 No. 378, 19 December 1985).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What delays are expected with the delivery of taxation forms ordered earlier in 1986 by tax agents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A series of delays were experienced in the delivery of 1985-86 taxation forms to tax agents. First, there were a number of legislative changes occurring late in the year, all of which had to be accurately reflected in taxation forms in a way to enable them to be understood and administered. Industrial action was experienced during the course of printing some of the forms and this led to further delay. In the end, the delay in delivery of taxation forms was made worse by further industrial action in June affecting the distribution of supplies.

The Commissioner assures me that he is most conscious of the need to have timely supplies of taxation forms available for tax agents and will be making renewed efforts to achieve timely distribution next year. For the current year, appropriate recognition will be given to the situation of tax agents who can demonstrate that their lodgment performance is seriously affected by the delays in distribution that did occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has he had a report since February on the disparity of salaries between the management personnel of statutory authorities and the private sector; if so, (a) what does the report recommend and (b) what action does the Government intend to take on the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, the Government has received such a report.
(a) The report recommends new salary ranges and a new method of remuneration on the basis of performance-based contracts.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Electoral Division of La Trobe: Elderly Persons Accommodation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What funds have been provided to the Electoral Division of La Trobe for accommodation for the elderly since March 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Within the Federal Electorate of La Trobe there are:

Eight nursing homes of which seven are participating nursing homes approved under the National Health Act for payment of Commonwealth nursing home benefits and one, the Glengollan Nursing Home, a deficit financed nursing home approved under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. Commonwealth funding since March 1983 for the nursing homes totals $13,400,741.

Four aged or disabled persons hostels, which are approved under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act for payment of Hostel Care Subsidies (ie. Hostel Care, Personal Care and Respite Care Subsidies). Commonwealth funding to date for the hostels totals $520,412. (Note-The figure provided does not include funding made prior to January 1984.)
In addition, capital and upgrading projects totalling $76,800 have been selected for funding in the La Trobe electorate since March 1983.
